SCHEDULE OF FEES




TITLE V:  PUBLIC WORKS




Chapter 51:  Water and Sewers



§ 51.01  Monthly Charges for Water Service and Sanitary Sewer Service
 
(1)   Single-family residential user.


   (a)   Each water connection within or outside of the city limits:


      Base charge - $17 for up to 4,000 gallons.


      From 4,001 to 10,000 gallons - $1.20 per 1,000 gallons.


      From 10,001 to 20,000 gallons - $1.40 per 1,000 gallons.


      Over 20,000 gallons - $1.54 per 1,000 gallons.


   (b)   Sewer charges:


      Base charge of $24 for water consumption up to 4,000 gallons.


      Over 4,000 gallons - $1.15 per 1,000 gallons up to a maximum of
15,000 gallons.


      No additional charge for above 15,000 gallons.


(2)   Non single-family residential users (including but not limited to
commercial establishments, places of worship, institutional use such as
schools and multi-family dwelling units), within the city limits:


   (a)   Each water connection:


      Base charge - $30 up to 4,000 gallons.


      From 4,001 gallons to 10,000 gallons - $1.20 per 1,000 gallons.


      From 10,001 to 20,000 gallons - $1.40 per 1,000 gallons.


      Over 20,000 gallons - $1.60 per 1,000 gallons.


   (b)   Sewer charges:


      $37 for water consumption up to 4,000 gallons.


      Over 4,000 gallons - $1.36 per 1,000 gallons.


(3)   Municipal irrigation users:


   Base charge of $16.75 per customer plus $1 per 1,000 gallons.


   No minimum or limit on the number of meters used.


(4)   All other users who are non-single-family residential users
(including but not limited to commercial establishments, places of worship,
institutional use such as schools and multi-family dwelling units) outside
the city limits:


   (a)   Each water connection outside city limits:


      Base charge of $640.86 for up to 50,000 gallons.


      Over 50,000 gallons - $1.64 per 1,000 gallons.


   (b)   Sewer charges:


      Base charge of $640.86 for up to 50,000 gallons.


      Over 50,000 gallons - $1.64 per 1,000 gallons.


(5)   Sewer services provided to Park Meadows Townhouses and billed to
City of Houston;


   Sewer charges: $4,168.


(6)   All users with inoperative water meter:


   Charge for average daily consumption as shown by meter when it is
operative.


(7)   All users: surface water conversion fee:


   $2.18 per 1,000 gallons.


§ 51.02  Single family and non-single family application and deposit for
water and sewer service
 
(B)   (1)   New service to owner occupied single-family residences -
$150 deposit for water and sewer service.


 
(B)   (2)   New service to non-owner occupied single-family residences
- $200 deposit for water and sewer service.


(B)   (3)   Single family residences that have been disconnected - $50
reconnect fee. Additionally, a $150 deposit (owner occupied) if no deposit on
file or $200 deposit (non-owner occupied) if no deposit on file. If deposit
on file with the city, then an additional $150, not to exceed $350 per
account, prior to service being restored.


(C)   (1)   New service to non-single-family residential customers -
$250 deposit for water and sewer service.


(C)   (2)   Non-single family residential customers that have been
disconnected - $50 reconnect fee plus an additional $150 deposit, not to
exceed $350 per account, prior to service being restored.


(D)   Water meter reinstallation fee: $100 plus an additional deposit as
set forth in (B)(3) or (C)(2), as applicable.


§ 51.07  Tap Fees
 
(A)   Single family residential user: $750 per connection.


 
(B)   Non single family residential user:


   (1)   Five-eighths inch water meter - three times the cost of
installing the tap, meter and any necessary service lines and the cost of
repairing or restoring any yards, sidewalks, streets or other improvements
affected by the installation shall be paid to the city.


   (2)   One-inch water meter - three times the cost of installing the
tap, meter and any necessary service lines and the cost of repairing or
restoring any yards, sidewalks, streets or other improvements affected by the
installation shall be paid to the city.


   (3)   Larger than one inch - three times the cost of installing the
tap, meter and necessary service lines and the cost of repairing or restoring
any yards, sidewalks, streets or other improvements affected by the
installation shall be paid to the city.


      User to pay the installation costs, plus 20%, prior to the
installation of the tap.


§ 51.08  Temporary Water Service
 
(B)   Temporary water service:


   Fee: $100 base fee plus $1.82 per 1,000 gallons, plus $1,000 deposit.


§ 51.11  Late Payment Fee and Disconnection of Water Service and Sanitary
Sewer Service
 
(A)   Late payment fee of 10%.


§ 51.12  Returned Check Charge
 
$25 fee for each returned check


Appendix A - Prohibition Against Cross-Connection and Unacceptable Plumbing
Practices
 
Regulations apply to all users of the city’s potable water distribution
system.


(C)   (1)   $100 fee for testing backflow prevention assemblies prior
to installation if the test is performed by the city’s operator or its
subcontractor.


      Fee for each retest is $100.


(D)   Customer service inspections:


   $75 - single-family residential users, if performed by the city’s
operator.


   $150 - non-single-family residential users, if performed by the
city’s operator.

TITLE XI:  BUSINESS REGULATIONS

without permit

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 50.01  NON-FEE PERMITS.



   (A)   All franchise utilities, which are exempt from the payment of
permit fees for work performed in the city, shall, prior to the beginning of
any work, file such plans, specifications, documentation, drawings and other
designations as shall be required under this code of ordinances of the city
to obtain a permit for the type and nature of the work sought to be
performed. The permit as herein provided shall be issued without fee.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any franchise utility, agent,
contractor, employee or worker to perform any work upon any property in the
city without having first obtained a permit as herein provided.



   (C)   The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to
emergency work or work performed by a utility company in response to an
emergency condition, condition of public calamity or a condition of urgency;
however, the franchise utility that shall have performed the work in such a
circumstance or condition shall, as soon as practicable, notify the Mayor or
Building Official of the city that the work has been performed and shall
provide such additional information, documentation, drawings, sketches or
plans as may be reasonably requested by the Mayor and/or Building Official
relating to all the work that has been completed.



(Prior Code, § 29-1)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.02  SCOPE.



   (A) This chapter shall be applicable to all utilities, franchise
utilities, utility companies and non-utility companies providing utility
service or services within the city or utilities, franchise utilities and
utility companies transmitting or conveying utility products from points
either in the city or outside the city to customers outside the city or
points of distribution outside the city and shall be deemed to control the
conduct of business of all utilities, franchise utilities, utility companies
and non-utility companies. Additionally, this chapter shall be applicable to
all network providers, as that term is defined by Tex. Local Government Code
Chapter 284.



   (B)   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.



      CONDUCTING BUSINESS. The sale, transportation, dissemination or
conveyance of any electrical, gas, water, cable television, wireless service,
or other utility product or service intended for sale, distribution,
dissemination or conveyance for sale and distribution to utility customers
both in and out of the city.



      UTILITY. Includes electric, gas, water, sewer, cable television,
wireless service, or any other utility that has as its business the sale of
utility products or services intended for sale, distribution, dissemination
or conveyance for sale and distribution to utility customers both in and out
of the city.



(Prior Code, § 29-2)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997; Ord. 2018-06, passed 3-27-2018)



§ 50.03  FAILURE OF A FRANCHISE UTILITY TO COMPLY WITH THE CODE OF
ORDINANCES.



   The City Council shall have the exclusive right at any time to
determine whether or not a utility has fully complied with the terms and
provisions of the code of ordinances of the city, and in the event the City
Council shall determine after public hearing that compliance has not
occurred, the City Council shall be empowered to take such action as shall be
deemed appropriate, including but not limited to conditioning, limiting or
canceling any prior right or authority to operate, conduct business or convey
utility products from points in or outside the city to points outside the
city. If the utility is found by the City Council, after full and adequate
hearing, to be in non-compliance and in violation of this code, the City
Council may amend, cancel, limit, condition or otherwise modify any right
previously granted to any utility to conduct business in the city. Even if no
formal authority had been previously required by this code or other law, the
City Council may prescribe regulations or limitations on the right of any
utility to conduct business within the city.



(Prior Code, § 29-4)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.04  VIOLATION OF THIS CODE.



   Failure of any person or utility or any employee, agent, contractor or
servant thereof to comply with the terms, provisions and intent of this code
and this chapter shall constitute a violation of this code and may be
punished as in the case of any violation of this code.



(Prior Code, § 29-5)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.05  SERVICE TO COMPLY WITH TECHNICAL PROVISIONS.



   Utility service furnished and the construction of utility service
improvements or installation of equipment and other properties in the city
shall at all times be in compliance with all applicable and technical
provisions of this code, federal and state law, and any city ordinances,
rules and regulations that may at any time be adopted and/or promulgated.



(Prior Code, § 29-6)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.06  INTERPRETATION, RULES AND REGULATIONS.



   (A)   The City Council shall be the exclusive body to interpret the
terms and provisions of this chapter and other provisions of this code as the
same may relate to this chapter or the legal ability of any utility to
conduct business within the city. The City Council shall have the exclusive
authority to establish such rules, regulations, standards and specifications
as may be necessary for installation, construction or maintenance of any
utility, utility system or the conduct of business of any utility within the
city.



   (B)   Such rules, regulations, standards and specifications as shall
be adopted from time to time by the City Council in accordance with the
authority as herein granted shall remain on file at all times in the office
of the City Secretary and may be enforced as may be permitted by law.
Violation by any utility or employee, individual, servant, contractor or
subcontractor thereof of any such interpretation, rules or regulations shall
be deemed a violation of this code and may be prosecuted as herein provided
for any such violation of this code.



(Prior Code, § 29-7)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.07  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   Notwithstanding provisions in franchise agreements that waive
the necessity for the payment of fees or costs, any utility authorized to
transact business within the city, or its contractors or other persons acting
for any utility, shall at all times be required to apply for a "non-fee
permit." The city shall be permitted, in accordance with the provisions of
this code and all interpretations, rules or regulations that may have been
previously adopted, to issue a permit if the application shall be in accord
with the provisions of this code and this chapter.



   (B)   A non-fee permit shall be applied for in accordance with the
customary application process, standards and guidelines that have been
established for the permit by the Mayor or City Council of the city.



(Prior Code, § 29-8)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997) Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.08  CITY NOT LIABLE FOR ACTIONS OF UTILITIES.



   The city shall not at any time be liable for any damage to a customer
of a utility service or of a franchise utility or of the city whether the
damage shall be as a result of negligence or intentional conduct to any
person, partnership or corporation. To this extent, and to the full extent
required or permitted by law, the city claims and its employees or agents
claim, for and on behalf of the city, absolute immunity from any claims
arising out of the conduct of business of any utility or franchised utility.



(Prior Code, § 29-9)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)



UTILITY POLES



§ 50.30  ABOVEGROUND UTILITY POLES, LINES AND PROPERTY PROHIBITED WITHOUT
PERMIT.



   No new or replacement utility poles, except a network node or pole
exempted from the requirements set forth herein by Tex. Local Government Code
Chapter 284 shall be located, built or relocated aboveground within the city
without the utility first having obtained a pole placement permit from the
city. For poles over six feet in length above ground, permits shall be issued
after application and hearing and a vote of at least three members of the
City Council. For poles less than six feet in length, a pole permit can be
issued in accordance with the provisions of this code by the Mayor of the
city. The term UTILITY POLE as herein set out shall not only include utility
poles but any other devices, apparatus, facilities, wires or other
improvements necessary to transmit utility service to utility customers or
utility customers' property, whether the customer be in the city or outside
the city.



(Prior Code, § 29-31)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997; Ord. 99-06, passed 3-23-1999; Ord. 2018-06,
passed 3-27-2018)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 50.31  APPLICATION FOR POLE PLACEMENT PERMIT.



   (A)   Each person or utility desiring to erect or construct new or
relocate existing utility poles within the city shall first file an
application with the City Secretary which shall describe the proposed
location of the utility poles, the proximity of those poles to the nearest
residential structure, nearest street right-of-way, nearest utility service
provided by either the applicant or another utility company and the intended
date of construction or relocation. The application shall be filed at least
30 days prior to the intended construction and no application fee shall be
required.



   (B)   The application shall first be reviewed by the Mayor of the
city or his or her designee who shall determine its completeness and the need
for additional information. The Mayor shall have the right to request any
additional information, documentation, clarification or records as shall be
deemed necessary for the City Council to properly act upon the application as
filed and presented.



   (C)   The Mayor, after obtaining all necessary information, shall
forward the application to the City Council who shall conduct a hearing,
which shall occur at the earliest and most practicable time. At the hearing,
the City Council shall determine whether or not the proposed application and
erection or relocation of a utility pole constitutes either:



      (1)   An endangerment to the health, safety and well-being of
the residents and inhabitants of the city;



      (2)   An endangerment to property or property interests in or
adjacent to the city;



      (3)   The likely detriment to property values or property
interests because of the proximity of the pole(s) to current or contemplated
improvements and the unsightly nature of the utility poles; or



      (4)   The existence of any other conditions which, although
not enumerated herein, may cause the City Council to determine that the best
interests of the city and its citizens and inhabitants would be best served
by the relocation of the contemplated poles to another location or an
alternative method of installation of utility lines and other properties.



   (D)   If any application is found to be in violation of the criteria
as herein set out, the City Council shall reject the application and the
applicant shall be permitted to file an amended application in accord with
any decision of the City Council as may have been previously determined. No
application and/or permit shall be necessary if all devices, lines, apparatus
or other equipment is properly installed underground and no poles, devices or
apparatus is located aboveground.



   (E)   In addition to the other provisions as herein set out, the
Mayor will provide the City Council with a report describing all approvals
and permits that the city has issued or has pending from persons who received
or will receive service from the utility facilities covered by the
application, including copies of all agreements between property owners and a
utility to pay the additional cost of underground service. In accordance with
the findings as herein set out and the provisions of this chapter, the City
Council shall, in granting any application under the provisions of this
chapter:



      (1)   Modify the terms and conditions of any existing or
pending city permit or approval to be consistent with the pole placement
permit; or



      (2)   If the application for a pole placement permit is
denied, the City Council shall modify the terms and conditions of an existing
or pending permit or approval to be consistent with this code, including the
requirements of Chapter 150 of this code, requiring that an electrical permit
holder must first reach an agreement with the utility to pay the utility the
difference in cost between conventional overhead utility service and any
underground service.



   (F)   All other permits and approvals as may be required from time
to time by other provisions of this code or other municipal law shall be
issued conditionally and subject to final action by the City Council under
the provisions of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 29-32)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)



§ 50.32  NO VESTED RIGHTS.



   No utility, person, partnership or corporation shall at any time have a
vested or absolute right to the location of a utility pole or the
construction of the same unless a permit has been first issued by the City
Council as herein provided.



(Prior Code, § 29-32a)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)



§ 50.33  UNDERGROUND CABLES, CONDUITS AND FACILITIES.



   The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply to underground
cables, conduits or other facilities sought to be installed by any franchise
utility or other utility doing business in the city and the same may be
installed if in accordance with all other provisions of this code without
compliance with the terms and provisions of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 29-33)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)



§ 50.34  CITY COUNCIL EXCLUSIVE RIGHT TO DETERMINE.



   The City Council shall be the body exclusively charged with issuing
pole permits within the city and to properly interpret this code or otherwise
determine the legislative intent of this code. No appeal shall lie to any
administrative or judicial body to review actions taken or not taken by the
City Council of the city, except such right of review as may be provided by
other law.



(Prior Code, § 29-34)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)



§ 50.35  SPECIFIC PROHIBITIONS.



   (A)   No utility pole shall at any time be erected within the city
upon either public or private property, public street, right-of-way or
dedicated easement if the same shall be:



      (1)   Less than 500 yards from a residential structure;



      (2)   Less than 100 yards from a right-of-way of a public
street, highway or other public way; or



      (3)   In an area adjoining or reserved for public recreation,
including but not limited to a public park, private park, a park or
recreation area maintained by a school district or school authority, or other
area of public assembly or public gathering.



   (B)   The City Council in the proper case may hear and determine a
request for variance and may for good cause grant a variance as to the
distance restrictions as herein set out if the City Council finds and
determines that in granting such a variance the same does not constitute a
violation of any of the rules, regulations, and intent of this chapter or
such ordinances as may be from time to time duly adopted by the City Council.



   (C)   The prohibitions set forth in this section shall not apply to
a network node or pole expressly granted a right of access to the public
right-of-way by Tex. Local Government Code Chapter 284, as those terms are
defined by said chapter, provided that approval of a permit application is
obtained, if required.



(Prior Code, § 29-35)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997; Ord. 2018-06, passed 3-27-2018)



§ 50.36  EMERGENCY REPLACEMENT OF UTILITY POLES.



   The provisions of this subchapter and the sections hereunder shall not
be applicable and shall not control in the case of a bona fide emergency
and/or loss or threatened loss of utility service to utility customers, and
all previously existing utility poles may be replaced without complying with
this subchapter so long as any work relating to replacement is in accordance
with all other provisions of this code.



(Prior Code, § 29-36)  (Ord. 96-25, §§ 1 & 2, passed 7-23-1996; Ord.
97-16, § 1, passed 5-27-1997)

BILLING AND CHARGES FOR WATER SERVICE AND SANITARY SEWER SERVICE



§ 51.01  CHARGES FOR WATER SERVICE AND SANITARY SEWER SERVICE.



   Customers shall pay charges for water service and sanitary sewer
service as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees.



(Ord. 2012-16, passed 6-26-2012)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.02  SINGLE FAMILY AND NON-SINGLE FAMILY APPLICATION AND DEPOSIT FOR
WATER AND SEWER SERVICE.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to make any connection to
the city’s water or sewer system without first submitting a water and sewer
application which shall state at a minimum the uses for which water and sewer
service is desired, providing the name of the owner of the property, the
number of lots and block, and the address. Upon payment of the tapping fee
and other fees as set by ordinance and receiving a permit, the city shall
make the necessary connections and furnish appropriate devices for water and
water metering.



   (B)   Single family residential customers:



      (1)   All new owner occupied residential customers shall pay a
water and sewer deposit (non-interest bearing) as set forth by City Council
in a schedule of fees. The deposit shall be applied to the last month’s
water and sewer charges and any remaining amounts shall be refunded within 45
days of the disconnect date.



      (2)   All new non-owner occupied residential customers shall
pay a water and sewer deposit (non-interest bearing) as set forth by City
Council in a schedule of fees. The deposit shall be applied to the last
month’s water and sewer charges and any remaining amounts shall be refunded
within 45 days of the disconnect date.



      (3)   Residential customers that have water or sewer service
disconnected for non-payment or for a violation of law shall pay a reconnect
fee as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees. Additionally, if the
residential customer does not have a deposit with the city, the customer also
shall pay a deposit as set forth in subsection (B)(1) or (B)(2) of this
section, as applicable, prior to the city reconnecting water and sewer
service. If the residential customer does have a deposit with the city and
has service disconnected, then the customer also shall pay an additional
deposit as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees.



   (C)   Non-single family residential customers including but not
limited to commercial businesses, places of worship, schools, institutions,
and multifamily customers:



      (1)   All new non-single family residential customers shall
pay a water and sewer deposit (non-interest bearing) as set forth by City
Council in a schedule of fees. The deposit shall be applied to the last
month’s water and sewer charges and any remaining amounts shall be refunded
within 45 days of the disconnect date.



      (2)   For non-single family residential customers that have
water or sewer service disconnected for non-payment or for a violation of
law, a reconnect fee and an additional deposit as set forth by City Council
in a schedule of fees shall be paid prior to the city reconnecting water and
sewer service.



   (D)   In the event that the city or its authorized agent,
representative, or contractor removes a customer’s water meter due to
disconnection of service, the customer shall pay to the city a water meter
reinstallation fee and any deposit as required by subsection (B)(3) or
(C)(2), as applicable, prior to water service and sanitary sewer service
being restored.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006; Ord. 2007-09, passed 4-24-2007; Ord.
2016-11, passed 7-26-2016; Ord. 2016-22, passed 9-27-2016)  Penalty, see §
51.99



§ 51.03  UNAUTHORIZED INTERFERENCE WITH WATER METER.



   All water meters, whether privately owned or belonging to the water
works system, shall be set by employees of the system only. It shall be
unlawful for any person, other than designated employees of the city, to
remove any water meter that has been placed or to in any manner interfere
with or tamper with any water meter.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.04  OBTAINING WATER BY METHODS NOT PROVIDED HEREIN.



   It shall be a violation of this code for any person through any device,
tool, apparatus or arrangement to obtain city water by methods other than
provided for herein.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.05  ADMINISTRATIVE REGULATIONS.



   The City Council shall, from time to time, have the power to cause to
be made or to make necessary administrative rules and regulations to ensure
proper collection of water service accounts and sanitary sewer service
accounts due and the maintaining of proper reports and reporting provided
that the rules and regulations are not in conflict with the provisions of
this section or the code of ordinances. City Council adopts the initial
administrative rules included in Appendix A to this chapter.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)



§ 51.06  WATER SERVICE AND SANITARY SEWER SERVICE DUE DATES AND TIMES.



   (A)   Each water service and sanitary sewer service invoice shall be
paid and received by the city on or before the close of City Hall on the
twentieth day of the month following the billing period (due date). If the
twentieth day falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or official city holiday, then the
water service and sanitary sewer service invoice shall be paid and received
by the city no later than the next business day, on or before 9:00 a.m., that
the city is open.



   (B)   A customer that disputes the water service and sanitary sewer
service invoice shall submit to the City Secretary, before the invoice due
date and time, a written notice explaining why the invoiced amounts are
disputed. The city shall investigate the disputed invoiced amounts within 14
days and respond, in writing, to the customer informing them that the
original invoice is correct or that the city has amended the invoice. The
customer shall pay the full original invoice or the full amended invoice, as
applicable, no later than seven days after the date the city mails or
personally delivers its determination to the customer.



   (C)   If a customer fails to pay the full water and sanitary sewer
invoice by the dates and times set forth in this section, then the
customer’s account shall be deemed delinquent, and the city shall assess a
late payment fee and take any lawful action including disconnecting water
service and sanitary sewer service to the customer as set forth in § 51.11
of this chapter and the schedule of fees.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006; Ord. 2016-23, passed 9-27-2016)



§ 51.07  TAP FEES.



   (A)   Single-family residential user. Prior to connection to the
city's water system, a tap fee as set forth herein shall be paid to the city
to cover the cost of making the connection and cost of providing the water
meter. For every water meter for single-family residential use the charge
shall be a flat rate of $750 per connection.



   (B)   Non-single-family residential user.



      (1)   In the case of a five-eighths inch water meter, prior to
connection to the city water system, a tap fee equal to three times the cost
to the city of installing the tap, meter and any necessary service lines and
the cost of repairing or restoring any yards, sidewalks, streets or other
improvements affected by the installation shall be paid to the city.



      (2)   In the case of a one-inch water meter, a tap fee equal
to three times the cost to the city of installing the tap, meter and any
necessary service lines and the cost of repairing or restoring any yards,
sidewalks, streets or other improvements affected by the installation shall
be paid to the city.



      (3)   In the case of a water meter larger than one inch, a tap
fee equal to three times the city's actual cost of installing the tap, meter
and necessary service lines, and repairing or restoring any yards, sidewalks,
streets or other improvements affected by the installation shall be paid to
the city (the "installation costs"). The city's operator will provide an
estimate for the installation costs. The user shall pay the installation
costs, plus 20%, prior to the installation of the tap. If the actual
installation costs are greater than the estimated installation costs paid by
the user, the difference must be paid by the user before the city will
provide service to the user. If the actual installation costs are less than
the estimated installation costs paid by the user, a refund for the
difference shall be issued to the user.



      (4)   Connections to the city's water system shall not be
allowed prior to an approved sewer inspection, and all the connections shall
be inspected by the district's operator or its subcontractor.



      (5)   Connections to the city water system shall not be
allowed prior to an approved sewer inspection, and all the connections shall
be inspected by the city's operator.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.08  TEMPORARY WATER SERVICE.



   (A)   The city or its authorized agent, representative, or
contractor shall be authorized to make a temporary water connection to any
fire hydrant or flushing valve upon receipt of a written request for
temporary water services and approval by the Public Works Director. This
temporary service shall be supplied only through a city issued meter.



   (B)   Any person or entity applying for temporary water service
(“temporary customer”) shall pay to the city a water usage fee and a
deposit in the amount set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees. Upon
receipt of full payment for temporary water used and return of the meter in
good condition, the city shall refund to the temporary customer the deposit
no later than 30 days after the meter is disconnected, except as set forth in
division (C) of this section.



   (C)   If any unpaid water usage is outstanding or if the water meter
is not returned to the city in good condition, the city shall deduct such
amounts owed to the city from the deposit and return any remaining portion of
the deposit, if any, to the temporary customer no later than 30 days after
the meter is disconnected. If the amounts owed to the city exceeds the
deposit, the city shall invoice the temporary customer any outstanding
amounts.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006; Ord. 2016-24, passed 9-27-2016)



§ 51.09  QUALITY OF SEWAGE.



   (A)   Domestic waste. Only ordinary liquid and water-carried waste
from domestic activities that is amenable to biological treatment and that is
discharged from sanitary conveniences of buildings connected to a public
sanitary sewer system shall be discharged into the city's sanitary sewer
lines. Waste resulting from any process of commerce or industry may not be
discharged into the city's sanitary sewer lines except as authorized pursuant
to division (B) below.



   (B)   Commercial and industrial waste. All discharges other than
waste described in division (A) above are prohibited unless the user has
applied to and received written authorization from the city for the discharge.



      (1)   The applicant must file a statement with the city
containing the following information:



         (a)   Name and address of applicant;



         (b)   Type of industry, business, activity or other
waste-creative process;



         (c)   Quantity of waste to be discharged;



         (d)   Typical analysis of the waste;



         (e)   Type of pretreatment proposed; and



         (f)   Such other information as the city may request in
writing.



      (2)   The city shall have the right to reject any application
for discharge of non-domestic waste into the city's sanitary sewer lines if
the city determines in its sole discretion that the proposed discharge may be
harmful to the city's sanitary sewer system or the environment. The city also
shall have the right in approving any application for the discharge of
non-domestic waste to impose any limitations on the discharge that the city
determines in its sole discretion to be necessary to protect the city's
sanitary sewer system or the environment.



   (C)   National Categorical Pretreatment Standard. If a user is
subject to a national categorical pretreatment standard pursuant to
regulations promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency under § 307
of the Federal Clean Water Act being 33 USC 1317, the user is prohibited from
discharging pollutants into the city's sanitary sewer system in violation of
applicable categorical pretreatment standards.



   (D)   City testing; pretreatment. The city shall have the right to
sample and test any user's discharge at the discretion of the city's
operator, with no limit as to the frequency of the tests, and to charge the
user for the city's cost of the sampling and testing. The city also shall
have the right to require pretreatment, at the user's expense, of any
discharge of nondomestic waste if the city determines in its sole discretion
that pretreatment of the waste is necessary to protect the city's sanitary
sewer system or the environment, even if pretreatment is not otherwise
required pursuant to division (C) above.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)



§ 51.10  MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR.



   It shall be the responsibility of each user to maintain the water and
sewer lines from the point of connection to the city's water and sewer system
to the building served.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)



§ 51.11  LATE PAYMENT FEE AND DISCONNECTION OF WATER SERVICE AND SANITARY
SEWER SERVICE.



   (A)   The city shall invoice customers for water service and
sanitary sewer service monthly. If a customer fails to pay the water service
and sanitary sewer invoice as set forth in § 51.06 of this chapter, then
customer shall pay to the city a late payment fee as set forth by City
Council in a schedule of fees.



   (B)   If customer does not pay the water and sanitary sewer invoice,
including any late payment fees, by the fifth day of the month following the
due date, the city may, in its discretion, disconnect water service and
sanitary sewer service to the customer; provided, that prior to disconnecting
services, the city shall send a disconnection notice to the customer by
United States mail. The written notice shall inform the customer of the past
due amounts owed to the city, including any late payment fees. The notice
also shall inform the customer when water service and sanitary sewer service
will be disconnected if full payment is not made to the city.



   (C)   The city shall credit all payments received by customer in the
following order; any past due amounts owed to the city, any outstanding late
payment fees owed to the city, any current invoiced amounts due and owed to
the city, and any deposits owed to the city. Customer shall pay city with
cash, cashier’s check, money order, or credit card.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006; Ord. 2016-25, passed 9-27-2016)



§ 51.12  RETURNED CHECK CHARGE.



   The city will charge a $25 fee to any customer for each check given to
the city for payment that must be returned for any reason. Payments attempted
to be made by check which is returned shall be considered delinquent unless
cash or certified funds are presented to the city for payment within the time
period required by the previous section.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)



§ 51.13  PRESSURE OF WATER.



   The city agrees to use all reasonable efforts to supply to any user
adequate pressure of water. The city does not and will not guarantee to any
user a specific quantity or pressure of water for any purpose whatsoever. The
city is required only to furnish a connection to its system and in no case
shall the city be liable for the failure or refusal to furnish water or any
particular amount of pressure of water; however, the city shall use
reasonable efforts to supply water to all users at an acceptable minimum
pressure.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)



§ 51.14  NO FREE SERVICE.



   No free service shall be granted to any user for services furnished by
the city's system, whether the user be a charitable or eleemosynary
institution, a political subdivision or municipal corporation, and all
charges for service shall be made as required herein.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)



§ 51.15  RULE PROHIBITING DISCHARGES INTO STORM SEWERS.



   The adequate and sufficient flow of storm waters is necessary to
protect public safety and the welfare of city residents. The city hereby
adopts a rule that no discharges, including without limitation of grass
clippings, sand or mud, shall be made into the city's storm sewer system,
other than storm sewer runoff. Violation of the preceding rule shall be
considered a violation of this subchapter.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)



§ 51.16  RULE PROHIBITING OBSTRUCTION OF STORM SEWER EASEMENTS.



   The adequate and sufficient flow of storm waters is necessary to
protect public safety and the welfare of city residents. The city hereby
adopts a rule that persons are prohibited from blocking, obstructing or
impeding any storm sewer easement owned or controlled by the city and any
storm sewer easement in which city storm sewer facilities are located. For
purposes of this rule, BLOCKING, OBSTRUCTING or IMPEDING shall include,
without limitation, constructing, placing or maintaining a fence (or a
portion thereof) or any other structure in such a storm sewer easement such
that the flow of storm waters within the easement, and/or the use of the
city's facilities within the easement, are blocked, obstructed or impeded.
Violation of the preceding rule shall be considered a violation of this
subchapter. If such a violation occurs or continues, the city may, in
addition to other remedies available to it, including those remedies set out
in this subchapter, terminate water service to the person.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person, corporation or other entity who violates any of
the following divisions (B)(1) through (B)(6) shall be subject to a penalty
of $200 for each breach of the foregoing provisions. Each day that a breach
of any provision hereof continues shall be considered a separate breach:



      (1)   Violates any section of this chapter;



      (2)   Makes unauthorized use of city services or facilities;



      (3)   Causes damage to city facilities by using the facilities
in a manner or for a purpose contrary to the purpose for which the facilities
were designed, including but not limited to dumping of any material or matter
into storm drains or sanitary sewer drains;



      (4)   Uses or permits the use of any septic tank or holding
tank within the city;



      (5)   Violates the city's rules and regulations governing
sewer lines and sewer connections; or



      (6)   Constructs facilities or buildings which are not
included in the approved plans for development.



   (C)   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another
to violate any provision of § 51.01 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than
$500. Each occurrence of any such violation of § 51.01 shall constitute a
separate offense. Each day on which any such violation of § 51.01 occurs
shall constitute a separate offense.



   (D)   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another
to violate any provision of § 51.02 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than
$500 unless such violation implicates fire safety, zoning, or public health
and sanitation including dumping of refuse in which case the fine amount
shall not be more than $2,000. Each occurrence of any such violation of §
51.02 shall constitute a separate offense. Each day on which any such
violation of this section occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



   (E)   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another
to violate any provision of § 51.03 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than
$500 unless such violation implicates fire safety, zoning, or public health
and sanitation including dumping of refuse in which case the fine amount
shall not be more than $2,000. Each occurrence of any such violation of §
51.03 shall constitute a separate offense. Each day on which any such
violation of this section occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



   (F)   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another
to violate any provision of § 51.06 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction there of, shall be punished by a fine of not more than
$500 unless such violation implicates fire safety, zoning, or public health
and sanitation including dumping of refuse in which case the fine amount
shall not be more than $2,000. Each occurrence of any such violation of §
51.06 shall constitute a separate offense. Each day on which any such
violation of this section occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



   (G)   This penalty shall be in addition to the other penalties
provided by the laws of the state and to any other legal rights and remedies
of the city as may be allowed by law.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006; Ord. 2012-16, passed 6-26-2012; Ord.
2016-11, passed 7-26-2016; Ord. 2016-23, passed 9-27-2016; Ord. 2018-16,
passed 7-24-2018)



APPENDIX A: PROHIBITION AGAINST CROSS-CONNECTION AND UNACCEPTABLE PLUMBING
PRACTICES



   The city adopts the following plumbing regulations, which apply to all
users of the city's potable water distribution system. These regulations, if
in conflict with other regulations or ordinances of the city or of the
plumbing codes adopted by the city, then those ordinances or codes supersede
these regulations.



   (A)   Plumbing fixtures. A user is not permitted to install any
plumbing fixture which is not in compliance with a state-approved Plumbing
Code and the plumbing code, if any, required by the city in whose
jurisdiction the city is located.



   (B)   Prohibition against water contamination. No direct connection
between the city's potable water distribution system and a potential source
of contamination is permitted. Potential sources of contamination shall be
isolated from the city's potable water distribution system by the
installation of an air-gap or an appropriate backflow prevention device in
accordance with state plumbing regulations. In addition, all pressure relief
valves and thermal expansion devices must be in accordance with state
plumbing codes and the plumbing code, if any, required by the city in whose
jurisdiction the city is located.



   (C)   Backflow prevention assemblies. All sprinkler systems, spas
and pools must have backflow prevention assemblies installed by the user at
the user's sole cost and expense. In addition, the city, in its sole
discretion, may require a non-single-family residential user to install a
backflow prevention assembly at any meter(s) servicing such a user's
property. The city, in its sole discretion, also may require any user to
install other backflow prevention assemblies at any fixture in order to
prevent contamination of the city's potable water distribution system or if
the user's plumbing system poses a high health hazard. A HIGH HEALTH HAZARD
is defined by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality ("TCEQ") as a
"cross-connection, potential cross-connection, or other situation involving
any substance that could cause death, illness, spread of disease, or has a
high probability of causing such effects if introduced into the potable
drinking water supply." If the city determines that a user must install a
backflow prevention assembly as a protection against a high health hazard,
the backflow prevention assembly used must comply with a state approved
plumbing code and the plumbing code, if any, required by the city in whose
jurisdiction the city is located, and must be tested and certified at least
annually by a recognized backflow prevention assembly tester. A list of
certified backflow prevention assembly inspectors can be obtained from the
local office of the TCEQ.



      (1)   The user is responsible for insuring that all backflow
prevention assemblies are tested upon installation by a recognized backflow
prevention assembly tester. If this test is performed by the city's operator
or its subcontractor, the cost will be $100, which is due and payable prior
to the test. The user is solely responsible for the cost of this test. If the
city requires the installation of a backflow prevention assembly in order to
prevent a serious threat to the city's public water supply, then the city, in
its sole discretion, may immediately terminate service to the user. In that
event, service will not be restored until the backflow prevention assembly
has been installed and tested and a signed and dated original of a "Backflow
Prevention Assembly Test and Maintenance Report" in the form attached to this
Rate Order as Exhibit "B," which is hereby adopted by reference as if set out
in full herein, has been provided to the city's operator. Each retest will be
charged at the same $100 rate.



      (2)   If the city determines that a backflow prevention
assembly must be installed pursuant to this Rate Order for reasons other than
to eliminate a serious threat to the city's public water system, the user
must install the backflow prevention assembly within five working days after
receipt of notice from the city that the installation is required. In
addition, the user must provide the city's operator with a signed and dated
original of a "Backflow Prevention Assembly Test and Maintenance Report" in
the form attached to this Rate Order as Exhibit "B" within three working days
of the installation of the backflow prevention assembly and within three
working days of any subsequent repair, maintenance or testing of the
assembly. If the user fails to provide the testing certificate within this
time, the city, in its discretion, may terminate service to the user pursuant
to the terms of this Rate Order. The city's operator will retain the reports
for a minimum of three years.



   (D)   Customer service inspections.  A customer service inspection
is required prior to the time the city provides continuous water service to
new construction, provides water service to private plumbing facilities that
have been added to existing construction or materially improved or corrected,
or  continues service to a user when the city has reason to believe that
cross-connections or other unacceptable plumbing practices exist. The cost of
the customer service inspection will be the sole responsibility of the user.
Only those individuals allowed and qualified by law may perform the
inspection. If the customer service inspection is performed by the city's
operator, the cost will be $75 for single-family residential users and $150
for non-single-family residential users, and will be determined on an
individual basis for other users. All fees relating to the customer service
inspection shall be paid by the user prior to the inspection, and if the
inspection is made in connection with new construction, the fee will be
collected with the tap fee.



   (E)   Prohibition against cross-connections.  No cross-connection
between the city's potable water distribution system and. A private water
system is permitted.



      (1)   Where an actual air gap is not maintained between the
public water supply and a private water supply, an approved reduced
pressure–zone backflow prevention assembly must be properly installed and
the assembly must be annually inspected and tested by a certified backflow
prevention device tester. A list of certified backflow prevention device
testers may be obtained from the local office of the TCEQ. By accepting
service from the city, all users agree to allow the annual inspection and
testing of backflow prevention assemblies to take place during normal
business hours. If any user refuses to allow the annual inspection and
testing, service to the user will be discontinued until the inspection and
testing is completed.



      (2)   No connection which allows water to be returned to the
city's potable water distribution system is permitted. This includes but is
not limited to any device pursuant to which water is removed from the city's
potable water distribution system, circulated through a user's system for
condensing, cooling and heating of fluids or industrial processes, including
but not limited to a heat exchange system, and routed back to the city's
potable water distribution system.



   (F)   Notice of unacceptable plumbing practices. The city shall
notify the user in writing of any cross-connection or other unacceptable
plumbing practice which has been identified during the customer's service
inspection, the final plumbing inspection, any periodic reinspection, or any
other inspection. At its sole cost and expense, the user shall immediately
correct any unacceptable plumbing practice on its premises and properly
install, test and maintain any backflow prevention device required by the
city within two working days of receipt of notice of the improper
cross-connection. The user shall provide copies of all testing and
maintenance records on such devices to the city within three working days of
the testing or maintenance. If the user fails to correct the noted
unacceptable plumbing practice, the city may immediately terminate water
service or, at the user's sole cost and expense, eliminate the
cross-connection or correct the unacceptable plumbing practice.



   (G)   Penalty for violation. The failure of a user to comply with
the terms of this section will be considered a violation of this Rate Order.
If such a violation occurs, or if the city determines the existence of a
serious threat to the integrity of the city's water supply, the city, in its
sole option, may, in addition to all other legal remedies available to it,
including those remedies set out in this Rate Order, immediately terminate
service or, at the user's sole cost and expense, install the plumbing
fixtures or assemblies necessary to correct the unacceptable plumbing
practice. If the city terminates service in order to preserve the integrity
of the city's water supply, service will be restored only when the source of
the potential contamination no longer exists or until paid by the user, the
difference must be paid by the user before the city will provide service to
the user. If the actual installation costs are less than the estimated
installation costs paid by the user, a refund for the difference shall be
issued to the user.



(Ord. 2006-15, passed 5-23-2006)

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 70.01  OFFICE OF THE TRAFFIC ENGINEER.



   There is hereby established the Office of the Traffic Engineer of the
city.



(Prior Code, § 30-1)  (Ord. 84-024, § 1, passed 2-28-1984; Ord. 84-041, §
1, passed 5-22-1984)



§ 70.02  INSTALLATION OF TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.



   The following provisions are hereby adopted for the installation of
traffic-control devices, signals and signs within the city.



   (A)   All traffic-control devices, including signs, signals and
markings (pavement and/or curb) installed or used for the purpose of
directing and controlling traffic within the city, shall conform to the Texas
Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways
(hereinafter called "the Manual"), pursuant to Tex. Transp. Code Ch. 544. All
signs, signals and markings erected or used by the city shall be uniform and
be located, so far as practicable, according to the directions and
specifications shown in the Manual throughout the city. All existing
traffic-control devices, and those erected in the future pursuant to the
authority of this section, shall be consistent with the Manual, state law and
this section and shall be deemed to be official traffic-control devices.



   (B)   All traffic-control devices, signs and signals (hereinafter
called devices), existing prior to the date of adoption of this section,
shall be deemed to be valid, official traffic-control devices.



   (C)   All persons and operators of any vehicles of any type shall
obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device, sign, signal or
marking applicable thereto, placed in accordance with this section, unless
otherwise directed by a police officer.



   (D)   (1)   No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in
view of any highway, street or alley any unauthorized sign, signal, marking
or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official
traffic-control device or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic,
or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any
traffic-control device. No person shall maintain or allow to be maintained
any obstacle which interferes with or hides from view an official
traffic-control device.



      (2)   No person shall place or maintain, nor shall any
authority permit, upon any highway, street or alley, any traffic sign or
signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. Any such prohibited sign,
signal or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and any officer
of the city is empowered to remove the same or cause the same to be removed
without notice.



   (E)   No person, except as shall be otherwise authorized by the
Traffic Engineer, shall attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock
down or remove any official traffic-control device, sign or signal.



   (F)   (1)   The City Council does hereby direct that the Traffic
Engineer shall have the duty of erecting or installing upon, over, along or
beside any highway, street or alley, traffic-control devices, signs, signals
and markings, or to cause the same to be erected, installed or placed in
accordance with this section and consistent with the Manual and the
provisions of law. These traffic-control devices shall be installed by the
Traffic Engineer as soon as practicable after he or she shall determine the
necessity for the same in accordance with the Manual.



      (2)   Whenever the Traffic Engineer has erected and installed
an official traffic-control device, sign or signal at any location in the
city, or has allowed such a traffic-control device, sign or signal to be
maintained as existing, or has caused the same to be done under his or her
direction in obedience to this section, a written report shall thereafter be
filed with the City Secretary, signed officially by the Traffic Engineer,
stating the type of traffic-control device, signal or sign and where the same
was erected or installed. In addition, he or she shall file, as a part of his
or her report, a certification that the traffic-control device, signal or
sign is in accordance with the warrants specified in the Manual, or in the
case where no warrants are specified or no provisions are contained in the
Manual, then in accordance with law.



(Prior Code, § 30-2)  (Ord. 84-06, § 2, passed 1-31-1984; Ord. 84-024, §
1, passed 2-28-1984; Ord. 84-041, § 1, passed 5-22-1984)  Penalty, see §
70.99



SPEED LIMITS



§ 70.15  GENERAL REGULATIONS.



   All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the
Manual and specifications as approved by the State Department of Highways and
Public Transportation.



(Ord. 2004-31, passed 10-25-2004)



§ 70.16  SCHOOL ZONE HOURS.



   Speed limits in all designated school zones shall be 20 miles per hour
between the hours of 7:15 a.m. and 8:15 a.m. and 3:15 p.m. and 3:45 p.m.



(Ord. 2004-31, passed 10-25-2004; Ord. 2011-01, passed 1-25-2011; Ord.
2016-18, passed 9-6-2016)



§ 70.99  GENERAL PENALTY.



   (A)   Whenever in this title an act is prohibited or is made or
declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or wherever in this
title the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is
declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is otherwise provided in
this code of ordinances, the violation shall be punished by a fine not
exceeding $500, provided, however, that no penalty shall be greater or less
than the penalty provided for the same or a similar offense of the laws of
the state.



   (B)   Any person violating any provision of § 70.16 shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $1
nor more than $200.



(Ord. 2011-01, passed 1-25-2011; Ord. 2016-18, passed 9-6-2016) 



   (C)   Each day a violation of this code or of any ordinance
continues shall constitute a separate offense.



CHAPTER 71:  PARKING REGULATIONS



Section



   71.01   General regulations



   71.02   Liability of owner and/or operator of illegally parked
vehicle



   71.03   Parking for the disabled



   71.04   No parking zones



 



   71.99   Penalty



§ 71.01  GENERAL REGULATIONS.



   (A)   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when
necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or
the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the
following places:



      (1)   On a sidewalk;



      (2)   In front of a public or private driveway;



      (3)   Within an intersection;



      (4)   Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant;



      (5)   On a crosswalk;



      (6)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or
obstruction, when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; or



      (7)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at
the edge or curb of a street.



   (B)   No person shall park any vehicle upon a street or alley in
such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten
feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic.



   (C)   No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the
purpose of:



      (1)   Storing the vehicle for a period of more than 48 hours,
without the prior written consent of the Chief of Police, the Traffic
Engineer or the Mayor;



      (2)   Displaying the vehicle for sale; or



      (3)   Greasing or repairing the vehicle, except such emergency
repairs as may be necessary to enable the vehicle to be moved off the roadway
at the earliest possible moment.



   (D)   No person shall park any vehicle that is not displaying
current valid motor vehicle registration numbered plates and a current valid
motor vehicle safety inspection sticker upon any street or alley within the
city limits of the city.



   (E)   No person shall park any trailer, which shall be any type of
wheeled device that may be pulled by a motor vehicle, upon any public roadway
within the city limits of the city.



   (F)   No person shall park an oversized vehicle upon a public
roadway within the city limits between the hours of 20 minutes after sunset
and 20 minutes before sunrise, without the written approval of the Chief of
Police, the Traffic Engineer or the Mayor. As used herein, the term OVERSIZED
VEHICLE shall be defined as that:



      (1)   Which is eight feet or more in width;



      (2)   Which is 20 feet or more in length;



      (3)   Which is 14 feet or more in height;



      (4)   Which weighs 10,000 pounds or more;



      (5)   Which is a truck tractor;



      (6)   Which is a truck tractor and trailer combination; or



      (7)   Which is any other commercial vehicle.



   (G)   No person shall park or store any vehicle in a commercial
parking lot within the city limits between the hours of 20 minutes after
sunset and 20 minutes before sunrise, without the written authorization of
the commercial parking lot owner.



(Prior Code, § 30-20)  (Ord. 2004-16, passed 6-8-2004)  Penalty, see §
71.99



§ 71.02  LIABILITY OF OWNER AND/OR OPERATOR OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLE.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person having registered in his
or her name, owning, operating or being in charge of any motor vehicle, to
knowingly allow or permit the same to stop, stand or be parked upon any
public street or commercial parking lot within the city in violation of any
provisions of this code or ordinance of the city regulating or controlling
parking.



   (B)   When any person is charged with having parked or left standing
a vehicle upon any street in the city, or upon a public passageway, where
parking of vehicles is prohibited, or with parking the vehicle upon a street
in a manner which violates the designated manner of parking a vehicle, or
with parking the vehicle for a length of time in excess of that allowed in
the space where the vehicle was parked, proof that the vehicle was, at the
time of the offense alleged, owned by the person charged with the offense,
shall constitute prima facie evidence that the vehicle was parked or left
standing at the place charged, by the owner. The owner of the vehicle shall
have the right to introduce evidence to show that the vehicle was not parked
by him or her as charged in the complaint.



   (C)   The owner and/or operator of any vehicle shall, in addition,
be liable for all charges and expenses incurred by the city in removal of the
vehicle to a storage facility, in addition to all costs and expenses assessed
by the storage facility. Any police officer of the city is authorized to
remove any vehicle parked in violation of this code to an approved public
compound or storage facility.



(Prior Code, § 30-21)  (Ord. 2004-16, passed 6-8-2004)  Penalty, see §
71.99



§ 71.03  PARKING FOR THE DISABLED.



   (A)   Any person or entity owning or having control of any property
or premises located within the incorporated limits of the City of Meadows
Place, Texas, may designate one or more of the parking spaces required for
the property for use by disabled persons. If the person or entity chooses to
do so, any parking spaces so designated shall conform to the rules
promulgated by the State Purchasing and General Services Commission under
subsection (c) of § 7.05 of the State Purchasing and General Services Act
(Tex. Rev. Stat. Art. 9102), relating to the identification and dimensions of
parking spaces for the disabled.



   (B)   The city hereby provides for the application of Tex. Transp.
Code § 681.011, which enumerates the specific categories of offenses which
may be charged for the unlawful use of parking spaces set aside for the
disabled, to all parking areas or spaces for the disabled on private property
within the city, which have been designated in compliance with the
identification requirements referenced in division (A) above.



(Prior Code, § 30-22)  (Ord. 84-041, § 2, passed 5-22-1984; Ord. 88-033,
§ 1, passed 8-23-1988)



Statutory reference:



   Authority, see Tex. Transp. Code § 681.009



§ 71.04  NO PARKING ZONES.



   (A)   Definitions.  For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.



      PARKING or PARK.  To stand, halt or locate an occupied or
unoccupied vehicle, other than temporarily while actively loading or
unloading passengers or property.



      VEHICLE.  A device that can be used to transport or draw persons
and/or property on a highway or street, including but not limited to a car,
truck, trailer, truck tractor or motorcycle.



   (B)   No parking zones and offense established. The location of the
no parking zones are set forth in Chapter 72, Schedule I. A person commits an
offense by violating any provision of this section.



   (C)   Signs.  The city shall be responsible for installing signs
and/or markings to properly notify the public of the location of the no
parking zone.



   (D)   Enforcement.  The no parking zone provided herein shall in no
way be obstructed and no parking shall occur therein. The Police Chief, or
his or her authorized representative(s), is authorized to issue citations
and/or remove or cause to be removed any material or vehicle obstructing the
no parking zone at the expense of the owner of the material or vehicle. The
city shall not be responsible or liable for any damage to any vehicle or
personal property removed from the no parking zone pursuant to this section
and shall not be responsible for any damage resulting from the failure to
exercise the authority granted under this section.



(Ord. 2009-10, passed 5-26-2009; Ord. 2009-11, passed 5-26-2009)  Penalty,
see § 71.99



§ 71.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person violating § 71.04 shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined a sum of not more
than $250. The city retains all legal rights and remedies available to it
pursuant to local, state and federal law.



(Ord. 2009-10, passed 5-26-2009; Ord. 2009-11, passed 5-26-2009)

CHAPTER 73: TRUCK TRAFFIC



Section



   73.01   Definitions



   73.02   Through truck traffic



 



   73.99   Penalty



§ 73.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY TRUCKS.  Fire department trucks, police trucks,
public ambulances for which permits have been issued by the State Board of
Health, emergency trucks of municipal departments or public service
corporations as are designated or authorized by the governing body of an
incorporated city, private trucks operated by volunteer firemen or certified
emergency medical volunteers while answering a fire alarm or responding to a
medical emergency, and trucks owned by the state or by a political
subdivision engaged in emergency utility repair or electric, water or
wastewater services.



   BUSINESS OR WORK RELATED DESTINATION.  The place where a truck
operator picks up or drops off cargo as part of its work related duties.



   LIGHT TRUCK.  Any truck with a manufacturer’s rated carrying
capacity of 2,000 pounds or less, including trucks commonly known as pickup
trucks, panel delivery trucks, and carryall trucks.



   TRUCK.  Any motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for
the transportation of property, including “truck tractors,” “road
tractors,” “trailers,” “semitrailers,” “pole trailers,” and
“special mobile equipment” as those terms are defined in the Texas
Transp. Code § 541.201.



   Terms not defined herein shall be construed in accordance with
customary usage.



(Ord. 2013-03, passed 2-26-2013)



§ 73.02 THROUGH TRUCK TRAFFIC.



   (A)   Regulation. A person commits an offense if the person operates
a truck upon a public street designated as a no through truck street.



   (B)   Affirmative defenses.  It is an affirmative defense to
prosecution under this section if:



      (1)   The truck was an authorized emergency truck;



      (2)   The truck was a bus or light truck;



      (3)   The truck was a moving van;



      (4)   The truck was a utility vehicle;



      (5)   The truck was operated by a government or political
subdivision;



      (6)   The truck was providing food carrier service; or



      (7)   The truck;



         (a)   Was being driven to fulfill a local commercial
obligation to a buyer or seller at a business or work related destination; and



         (b)   The prohibited public street was the only route to
such destination.



   (C)   Streets prohibited. Through truck traffic is prohibited on the
following streets:



 


Street

 

Extent



Dorrance
 
Bloomington west to Dairy Ashford



 



   (D)   The Traffic Engineer is directed to erect and place signs
designating the above streets as “No Through Trucks” streets.



(Ord. 2013-03, passed 2-26-2013) Penalty, see § 73.99



§ 73.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another to violate
any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500. 
Each occurrence of any such violation of this chapter shall constitute a
separate offense. Each day on which any such violation of this chapter occurs
shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 2013-03, passed 2-26-2013)

CHAPTER 90:  ANIMAL CONTROL REGULATIONS



Section



   90.01   Definitions



   90.02   Reserved



   90.03   Animal defecation on property of another



   90.04   Running at large prohibited



   90.05   Rabies inoculation required



   90.06   Number of dogs and cats limited



 



   90.99   Penalty



§ 90.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   AT LARGE.  Not confined within the owner’s premises, owner’s fence
or under the control of the owner or keeper or his or her agent at heel or by
means of a leash, chain, rope or cord not more than ten feet in length, and
of sufficient strength to control the conduct of the animal.



   CAT. Both male and female.



   DOG. Both male and female.



   INOCULATED. An injection of a type of rabies vaccine approved by the
State Veterinarian and applied by a veterinarian licensed under state law.



   OWNER. Any person or persons, firm, association or corporation owning,
keeping or harboring an animal.



(Prior Code, § 6-1)  (Ord. 84-049, § 1, passed 6-12-1984)



§ 90.02  RESERVED.



§ 90.03  ANIMAL DEFECATION ON PROPERTY OF ANOTHER.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in control of an
animal to allow such animal to defecate on any public property, including any
right-of-way, or private property, other than that of the owner of the
animal. If the animal was at large at the time it defecated on any property,
then that shall constitute prima facie evidence that the owner or person in
control of the animal allowed the animal to so act.



   (B)   It shall be a defense to prosecution under this section that
the owner or person in control of the animal immediately removed and cleaned
up such animal’s feces from the public or private property.



(Ord. 2016-28, passed 10-25-2016)



§ 90.04  RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for the owner to permit any dog to be at
large upon the streets, alleys or public grounds of the city, or upon the
premises of any person not the owner of the dog, unless the dog is under the
control of the owner or keeper or his or her agent by means of a leash,
chain, rope or cord not more than ten feet in length and of sufficient
strength to control the conduct of the dog.



   (B)   This section shall not be applicable wherein a dog is engaged
in an obedience school, dog show or similar activity, under the direct
supervision of the owner of the dog or at such times when the owner of the
dog is showing or exhibiting the dog in a recognized dog show or exhibition.



(Prior Code, § 6-4)  (Ord. 84-049, § 1, passed 6-12-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 90.05  RABIES INOCULATION REQUIRED.



   Dog and cat owners and keepers shall have the dog and cat inoculated
against rabies by a licensed veterinarian qualified to practice in the
state.  Dogs and cats shall have current rabies inoculation at all times. 
Each dog or cat inoculated shall wear a tag affixed to its collar at all
times showing it has been inoculated and the date of inoculation.



(Prior Code, § 6-5)  (Ord. 84-049, § 1, passed 6-12-1984; Am. Ord.
2012-17, passed 6-26-2012)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.06  NUMBER OF CATS AND DOGS LIMITED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, possess,
maintain or allow to be kept, harbored, possessed or maintained more than
four dogs or four cats or a combination of such animals with the total number
not exceeding four, over four months old, upon or within any premises owned,
occupied or under the control of the person within the city.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, possess,
maintain or allow to be kept, harbored, possessed or maintained more than two
dogs or two cats or a combination of those animals with the total number
exceeding two, over four months old, upon any premises or within any
apartment or a multiple dwelling structure within the city. The animal
control officer shall have full authority to limit the number of dogs, cats,
and any and all other animals per apartment, in any specific area of the
complex, or in the multiple dwelling complex as a whole, and he or she shall
have the authority to enforce any such regulation as he or she may deem
necessary for the control of rabies and for the health and safety of the
people within the multiple dwelling complexes.



   (C)   The provision of this section limiting the number of dogs and
cats shall not apply to the following:



      (1)   Veterinary hospitals;



      (2)   Pet shops;



      (3)   Kennels;



      (4)   Circuses; or



      (5)   Animal shelters.



   (D)   It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the
prohibited animal was kept in a kennel, veterinary facility, pet store,
research facility or other nonresidential land use permitted by the city's
zoning regulations that provides for the keeping of the animal.



(Ord. 2003-19, passed 6-9-2003)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 90.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another to violate
any provision of § 90.05 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.  Each
occurrence of any such violation of § 90.05 shall constitute a separate
offense.  Each day on which any such violation of § 90.05 occurs shall
constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 2012-17, passed 6-26-2012)

Abandoned Property and Vehicles
