GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 91.001  SCOPE.



   The terms and provisions of this chapter shall apply to the
accumulation, storage and collection of any solid waste, including garbage
and trash, and to the growth, accumulation, cutting and storage of grass,
weeds and any other vegetative material, upon property in the city, to the
end that property shall be maintained in a sanitary and healthful condition
for the benefit of all residents and citizens of the community.



(Prior Code, § 16-1)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)



§ 91.002  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   BRUSH. All uncultivated shrubs, bushes and small trees.



   DEFACE. Writing, carving or scratching on the varnish, paint, plaster
or other surface of any trash receptacle or staining the receptacle with
paint or any other material which will produce a discoloration of the paint,
plaster or other surface thereon.



   EARTH AND CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS. Earth, rocks, concrete and similar
materials and waste materials resulting from construction or remodeling.



   GARBAGE. Rubbish, trash, kitchen and household waste, ashes, bottles,
cans, rags, paper, food, food containers, lawn trimmings, tree trimmings,
hedge trimmings, leaves, grass, weeds and refuse, not including sewage or
animal waste, swills, slops, toxic or corrosive materials, or any other
material which may be found to be harmful to garbage collection and handling
personnel or equipment.



   INJURE. Any and all character of physical damage, whether caused by
fire or force, and which shall be done or caused willfully by any person.



   LOT. In addition to land within the boundaries of the property lines,
all land adjacent to and extending beyond the property lines of any lot or
parcel of land to the curb lines or adjacent streets where curb lines have
been established or, where no curb lines have been established, to eight feet
beyond the property lines.



   PUBLIC TRASH RECEPTACLE. All cans, boxes, tubs or barrels placed on the
streets and sidewalks by the city or by anyone else under the direction of
the city or by contract or agreement with the city for placing receptacles
for trash or waste of the general public.



   REFUSE. See GARBAGE.



   RUBBISH. All refuse, rejected tin cans, old vessels of all sorts,
useless articles, abandoned pipe, discarded clothing and textiles of all
sorts, and in general all litter. The words "any and all objectionable or
unsanitary matters," not included within the meaning of the other terms as
herein used, mean those which are liable to produce or tend to produce an
unhealthy, unwholesome, or unsanitary condition to the general locality where
the same are situated.



   SOLID WASTE. Household garbage and refuse and commercial garbage and
refuse, brush cuttings and weeds.



   TRASH. See GARBAGE.



   UNWHOLESOME MATTER. All stagnant water, filth, carrion, impure matters
and any condition liable to produce disease.



   WEEDS. All rank and uncultivated vegetable growth or matter which is
liable to become an unwholesome or decaying mass or breeding place for flies,
mosquitoes or vermin.



(Prior Code, § 16-2)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)



GARBAGE AND TRASH



§ 91.015  COLLECTION BY PRIVATE CONTRACTOR.



   (A)   The city may enter into a contract with a private contractor
for the collection of all garbage throughout the city, which contract shall
provide, at a minimum, for regular collection twice weekly, for the type of
garbage containers to be used and for the placement of containers for
collection purposes.



   (B)   Any owner of non-single-family residential property (including
but not limited to commercial establishments, churches and multi-family
dwelling units) within the city may enter into a contract with a private
contractor for the collection of garbage upon the owner’s non-single-family
residential property.  Upon entry into such contract, the property owner
shall advise the city of the existence of the contract and that the owner
does not intend to utilize the garbage collection services provided by the
city, either directly or through contract with a private contractor.



   (C)   Any owner of single-family residential property within the
city shall be required to use the service offered by the city or the city’s
private contractor for the collection of garbage upon the owner’s
single-family residential property and shall be charged a fee therefor.



(Prior Code, § 16-11)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984; Ord. 2013-31,
passed 12-17-2013)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.016  HOURS OF COLLECTION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to perform the
service of trash or refuse collection within the city limits except between
the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. daily.



(Prior Code, § 16-12)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 91.017  COLLECTION REQUIREMENTS AND LIMITATIONS.



   (A)   To facilitate efficient collection and sanitary storage prior
to collection, all garbage shall be placed in containers or receptacles of a
type specified, or bundled in a manner specified, by administrative order of
the Mayor.



   (B)   No person, firm or corporation shall place for regular
collection by the city or the city's private contractor any earth and
construction materials as defined in this chapter.



   (C)   No person, firm or corporation shall place for regular
collection by the city or the city's private contractor any automotive parts
or related materials.



   (D)   No person, firm or corporation shall place for regular
collection by the city or the city's private contractor any material not
included within the definition of the term "garbage" as set out in this
chapter.



   (E)   No broken glass, ashes or manure shall be placed in any
container or receptacle for collection by the city or the city's private
contractor without first wrapping the same securely in paper or other
combustible material.



   (F)   The Mayor may, by administrative order, establish dates for
special collection by the city or the city's private contractor at which
times certain items, as specified in the order and which are not otherwise
permitted to be placed for regular collection, will be collected.



(Prior Code, § 16-13)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 91.018  SANITATION.



   (A)   All reusable and disposable receptacles and containers and the
location in which they are stored shall be kept in a clean condition and free
of fly and other insect breeding.



   (B)   When reusable or disposable receptacles and containers are
placed at a common pickup location upon a lot or tract of property upon which
there are located multiple residential and/or nonresidential units, wherein
garbage and trash are generated by more than one unit for placement and
storage at the common pickup location, then it shall be the responsibility of
the owner or manager of the site to maintain the receptacles and area around
that location in a sanitary condition.



   (C)   Reusable receptacles and containers must be maintained in good
repair, free of holes, cracks and splits, and shall at all times be kept
covered with tightly fitting lids.



   (D)   It shall be the duty of every owner, manager, tenant and/or
occupant of any dwelling unit, building and/or premises to provide a
sufficient number of receptacles to contain the solid waste produced at the
dwelling unit, building and/or premises from one pickup time to the next
pickup time.



(Prior Code, § 16-14)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)



§ 91.019  BURNING PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager, tenant and/or occupant of
any dwelling unit, building and/or premises to burn solid waste on any
premises within the city.



(Prior Code, § 16-15)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 91.020  DEPOSITING ON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY; ACCUMULATIONS
PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, manager, tenant and/or
occupant of any lot, building or premises, in person or by his or her
servant, agent or employee, to cast, throw, drop, place, sweep, deposit or
allow to accumulate, or allow the same to be done in any manner whatsoever,
any solid waste, rubbish, weeds, brush, offal or other substance or thing
whatsoever of any offensive nature or deleterious to health, in or upon any
street, sidewalk, park, other public place, vacant lot or any yard space of
privately owned premises, or in or upon the waters of any canal, stream or
other watercourse or public waters, or in any drain, sewer or receiving basin
within the city, or in, upon or about any building or premises within the
city, except as herein provided.



(Prior Code, § 16-16)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 91.021  PUBLIC TRASH RECEPTACLES.



   Upon consent of the Mayor, it shall be lawful to place trash
receptacles of a design and construction approved by the Mayor, upon public
property within the city, upon the streets, plazas, parks and other public
property, for the reception of trash. The receptacles shall be placed for the
use and benefit of persons using such public areas within the city; and it
shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to transport garbage
and trash from private property to the site of a public trash receptacle for
the purpose of dumping garbage and trash or for the purpose of disposing of
garbage and trash in excess of that quantity of garbage and trash generated
during the person's, firm's or corporation's use of the public area.



(Prior Code, § 16-17)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 91.022  DEPOSITING GARBAGE OR TRASH WITHOUT CONSENT.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to place or
deposit garbage, trash or refuse into any garbage can or receptacle or
garbage collection device located upon private property when the receptacle
or device is not owned by, rented or leased to or under the control of the
person, firm or corporation, without the consent of the owner or person
exercising control thereof.



(Prior Code, § 16-18)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 91.023  TRANSPORTING GARBAGE OR REFUSE INTO THE CITY.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to haul,
transport or carry rubbish, trash, kitchen and household waste, ashes, paper,
food, food containers, tree trimmings, hedge trimmings, leaves, grass, weeds
and refuse from any place outside the city limits to any place within the
city limits for the purpose of causing the same to be collected by the city
or the city's private contractor.



(Prior Code, § 16-19)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 91.024  TAMPERING WITH CONTAINER OR RECEPTACLE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, molest, remove,
handle, displace, injure, deface, destroy, uncover, move or otherwise disturb
any garbage or trash container or receptacle, either upon public or private
property, or to in any manner remove, withdraw or disturb any part or portion
of the contents thereof; provided that this section shall not apply to any
person authorized by the city to collect garbage and trash or to any person
who owns or has responsibility for the placement and maintenance of the
container or receptacle.



(Prior Code, § 16-20)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 91.025  CONTAINER OR RECEPTACLE DECLARED A NUISANCE.



   Other than authorized public trash receptacles, containers and
receptacles for solid waste or trash which are permitted or suffered to be
and remain in or upon any street, sidewalk or public place in violation of
this chapter are declared to be public nuisances. The city shall have the
right to abate these nuisances by removing any container and receptacles
allowed to remain in any public place in violation of this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 16-21)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)



WEEDS AND OFFENSIVE CONDITIONS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY



§ 91.035  NUISANCE DECLARED; DUTY TO ABATE.



   Whenever weeds, brush, rubbish and all other objectionable, unsightly
and unsanitary matter of whatever nature shall exist, covering or partially
covering the surface of any lots or parcels of any real estate situated
within the city, or when any of the lots or parcels of real estate as
aforesaid, shall have the surface thereof filled or partly filled with holes
or be in such condition that the same holds or is liable to hold stagnant
water therein, or if from any other cause shall be in such condition as to
cause disease, or produce, harbor or spread disease germs of any nature or
tend to render the surrounding atmosphere unhealthy, unwholesome or
obnoxious, or shall contain unwholesome matter of any kind or description,
the same is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance, the prompt
abatement of which is hereby declared to be a public necessity. Any such
nuisance shall be removed from the property by the owner or other person in
possession or control of the property.



(Prior Code, § 16-41)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)



§ 91.036  RIGHT TO INSPECT.



   The Building Official or his or her representative is authorized to
inspect any property within the city limits, at any reasonable time, subject,
however, to the restrictions against such inspection and entry of private
residence for health inspection as provided for in the laws of the state.



(Prior Code, § 16-42)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)



§ 91.037  VIOLATIONS; NOTICE; FAILURE TO ABATE.



   (A)   In the event that the officer charged with enforcement of this
subchapter shall determine that a situation exists which immediately affects
the health, safety and well-being of the general public and that immediate
action is necessary, the officer may take such action as shall be necessary,
including issuing citations for violations of the terms and provisions of
this code to the owner or occupant of the property upon which the condition
exists, as may be deemed appropriate and necessary.



   (B)   However, where a condition is not judged to be an emergency or
a matter requiring immediate attention, a notice to correct a condition
described in this subchapter shall be given either in writing to the owner or
occupant by letter addressed to the owner or occupant at his or her post
office address or by publication in the official newspaper of the city twice
within ten consecutive days. If personal notice by letter may not be had or
the owner's address is not known, notice shall not be necessary.
Notwithstanding the provisions of this section providing for notice, proof
that notice has actually been given shall not be a prerequisite for
prosecution under the terms and provisions of this code.



(Prior Code, § 16-43)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)



§ 91.038  ABATEMENT BY CITY; COLLECTION OF COSTS.



   Cumulative of the city's remedy by fine, as set forth in the preceding
section hereof, the city may do the work or cause the same to be done to
remedy the condition or remove the matter from the owner's premises at the
city's expense and may charge the same to the account of the owners of the
property and assess the same against the real estate or lot or lots upon
which the expense is incurred. Upon filing with the County Clerk a statement
by the Mayor of the expenses, the city shall have a privileged lien upon the
real estate or lot or lots, second only to tax liens and liens for street
improvements, to secure the expenditure so made and 10% interest on the
amount from the date of the payment so made by the city. The city may
institute suit and recover the expenses and foreclose the lien in any court
of competent jurisdiction, and the statement so filed with the County Clerk
or a certified copy thereof shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended
in any such work or improvements to remedy the condition or remove any such
matter.



(Prior Code, § 16-44)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)



§ 91.039  LIMITATION ON HEIGHT OF GRASS AND WEEDS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person who shall own or occupy
any lot or lots in the city to allow weeds and/or grass to grow on the lot or
lots to a height of more than nine inches. Weeds and/or grass of a height
exceeding nine inches are declared a nuisance.



(Prior Code, § 16-45)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984) 



   (B)   The requirements of this section apply to any public
right-of-way or easement or portion thereof located on the real property or
portion thereof required to be cut, including specifically the areas of any
real property that extend to or abut upon any curb or paved portion of a
public street, the area between a public sidewalk and a public street or
highway, and ditches and drainage channels located thereon.



(Ord. 2004-42, passed 11-22-2004)



Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 91.040  DISCHARGE OF SEWAGE.



   Any person who shall allow or permit sewage to discharge into the
ground or subsurface soil, which shall have the effect of causing odors,
obnoxious, unhealthy and unwholesome conditions to exist, is declared to have
caused a public nuisance and shall be in violation of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 16-46)  (Ord. 84-074, § 1, passed 11-8-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



TREE STUMPS



§ 91.050  REMOVAL OF TREE STUMPS.



   (A)   All premises and exterior of a property shall be maintained
free from tree stumps of any height. Upon the removal of the tree, all tree
stumps shall be ground or cut to ground level.



   (B)   Upon failure of the owner or agent having charge of the
property to cut, destroy or grind the tree stump after service of notice of a
violation, he or she shall be subject to prosecution in accordance with the
city code and prescribed by the authority having jurisdiction. Upon failure
to comply with the notice of violation, any duly authorized employee of the
jurisdiction or contractor hired by the jurisdiction shall be authorized to
enter upon the property in violation and cut and grind the tree stump down,
and the cost of the removal shall be paid by the owner or agent responsible
for the property.



(Ord. 2005-22, passed 5-24-2005)



JUNKED VEHICLES



§ 91.065  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   DEMOLISHER. Any person whose business is to convert a motor vehicle
into processed scrap or scrap metal, or otherwise to wreck or dismantle motor
vehicles.



   JUNKED VEHICLE. A vehicle that is self-propelled and:



      (1)   Does not have lawfully attached to it both an unexpired
license plate, including annual registrations certificate, and a valid motor
vehicle inspection certificate issued by the proper authority under the laws
of the state; or



      (2)   Is wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled or
discarded; or has remained inoperable and not moved from the property upon
which it has been parked for more than 30 consecutive days. Movement shall
not be deemed to have occurred unless the vehicle is operated upon a public
street of the city for a distance of at least five miles, displaying a valid
license numbered plate, registration certificate and a valid Texas inspection
sticker.



(Ord. 97-20, passed 6-24-1997)



   MOTOR VEHICLE. Any motor vehicle subject to registration pursuant to
the Texas Certificate of Title Act.



(Prior Code, § 18-16)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.066  NUISANCE DECLARED.



   (A)   Junked vehicles which are located in any place where they are
visible from a public place or public right-of-way are hereby declared to be
detrimental to the safety and welfare of the general public. Such junked
vehicles tend to reduce the value of property, to invite vandalism, to create
fire hazards, to constitute an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the
health and safety of minors, and are detrimental to the economic welfare of
the city by producing urban blight which is adverse to the maintenance and
continuing development of the city. Such junked vehicles are hereby declared
to be a public nuisance.



   (B)   The covering of a motor vehicle by the use of a tarpaulin
(tarp) or other similar cover which is visible from a public place or public
right-of-way, and not in any fully screened enclosure, is prohibited, unless
that cover is made of a durable fabric, which is custom fitted to the
particular vehicle to which it is attached. The motor vehicle cover shall
have tailored mirror pockets, antennae grommets, and eyelets to allow the
cover to be pulled securely around the body of the vehicle. The motor vehicle
cover shall not obscure the vehicle’s license plate, motor vehicle
inspection certificate, or motor vehicle registration certificate. Clear
vinyl or cutouts shall be sewn into the cover to ensure the visibility of the
vehicle's license plate, inspection, and registration certificate.



   (C)   Motor vehicle covers shall be kept in good repair and free
from staining, rips, or other damage to the cover. Motor vehicle covers shall
be secured properly to the vehicle and shall not dangle loosely onto the
vehicle. Motor vehicle covers shall be a neutral color and shall not be a
color considered loud, obnoxious, or excessively bright.



   (D)   Motor vehicle covers shall not be used to cover a junked
vehicle as that term is defined in this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 18-17)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§§ 1, 6, passed 7-23-1991; Am. Ord. 2012-01, passed 1-24-2012)



§ 91.067  ABATEMENT.



   The City Council hereby adopts the following procedures for the
abatement of the public nuisance defined in § 91.036 above, as authorized by
Tex. Transp. Code Ch. 683.



   (A)   Administration. This subchapter shall be administered by the
Chief of Police or any other regularly salaried, full-time employees of the
city designated by him or her. However, the removal of vehicles or parts
thereof from property may be performed by any other person designated in
writing by the Chief of Police.



   (B)   Notice to owner.



      (1)   For a nuisance on either private property or public
property, ten days' notice shall be given, which notice shall state:



         (a)   The nature of the public nuisance on private
property, on public property or on a public right-of-way;



         (b)   That the nuisance must be removed and abated
within ten days; and



         (c)   That a public hearing before the City Council may
be requested, provided that the request is filed, in writing, in the office
of the City Secretary prior to the expiration of the ten-day period.



      (2)   (a)   For a nuisance on private property, the notice
shall be mailed, by certified mail with a five-day return requested, to the
last known registered owner of the junked vehicle, any lienholder of record
and the owner or occupant of the private premises on which the public
nuisance exists.



         (b)   For a nuisance on public property, the notice
shall be mailed, by certified mail with a five-day return requested, to the
last known registered owner of the junked vehicle, any lienholder of record,
and the owner or occupant of the public premises or to the owner or occupant
of the premises adjacent to the public right-of-way on which the public
nuisance exists.



      (3)   If any notice, as above required, is returned
undelivered by the United States Post Office, official action to abate the
nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than ten days after the date
of the return.



   (C)   Hearing. If a request for hearing is filed within ten days
after service of notice to abate the nuisance, a public hearing shall be held
before the City Council. Notice of the hearing shall be posted on the city's
official bulletin board in accordance with the Texas Open Meetings Law, and a
copy of the notice shall be mailed to the party requesting the hearing at
least three days prior to the commencement of the hearing.



   (D)   Order.



      (1)   At the conclusion of the hearing, the City Council may,
by order, require the removal of the junked vehicle or part thereof. The
order shall specify the date by which removal shall be accomplished and shall
include a description of the vehicle and the correct identification number
and the license number of the vehicle if the identification number and
license number are available at the site.



      (2)   If the City Council declines to enter such an order or
if no action is taken by the City Council, the proceedings shall be abated
and no further action shall be taken by the Chief of Police or his or her
designated employees with regard to the abatement of the public nuisance.



   (E)   Removal.



      (1)   When the owner or occupant has failed to abate a
nuisance within ten days after service of notice to abate the nuisance and no
request for hearing has been filed within the ten-day period, the city may
file a complaint in a court of competent jurisdiction seeking a declaration
of public nuisance and an order permitting the city to abate the same. Upon
order of the court or, in the case of hearing and order of the City Council,
when the owner or occupant has failed to abate any nuisance within the period
of time provided in the order, the Chief of Police or his or her designated
employee shall arrange for the removal of the junked vehicle or part thereof,
either by the city employee or by any other duly authorized person. The
junked vehicle or part thereof shall be removed to a location designated by
the Chief of Police.



      (2)   It is specifically provided that any junked vehicle or
part thereof which has been removed under the terms of this subchapter shall
not be reconstructed or made operable after the same has been removed.



   (F)   Notice to state. Notice of the removal shall be given by the
Chief of Police or other designated employee to the State Department of
Highways and Public Transportation not later than the fifth day after the
date of removal. The notice shall cite this subchapter and shall set forth
all identification numbers and description of the vehicle or parts thereof as
may be available at the site and shall request cancellation of the
certificate of the title to the vehicle, pursuant to the Certificate of Title
Act.



(Prior Code, § 18-18)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.068  DISPOSAL OF JUNKED VEHICLES.



   The Chief of Police or other designated city employee shall arrange for
the disposal of junked vehicles or parts thereof in accordance with Tex.
Transp. Code Ch. 683, providing for removal to a scrap yard, demolisher or
any suitable site operated by the city for processing as scrap or salvage.



(Prior Code, § 18-19)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§§ 2, 6, passed 7-23-1991; Ord. 92-31, § 8, passed 7-28-1992)



§ 91.069  EXEMPTIONS.



   This subchapter shall not apply to:



   (A)   A junked vehicle or part thereof which is completely enclosed
within a building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street
or other public or private property;



   (B)   A junked vehicle or part thereof which is stored or parked in
a lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a
licensed vehicle dealer or junkyard; or



   (C)   An unlicenced, operable or inoperable antique or
special-interest vehicle stored by a collector on the collector's property,
if the vehicle and the outdoor storage area are maintained in a manner so
that they do not constitute a health hazard and are screened from permanent
view by means of a permanently attached fence, rapidly growing trees,
shrubbery or any other means which is permanently attached or affixed to the
ground or the existing house structure as a fixture. No screening of the type
as herein provided shall occur beyond the outermost wall or surface of the
residential structure and the nearest abutting public street.



(Prior Code, § 18-20)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-21,
§ 1, passed 7-23-1991; Ord. 91-22, § 6, passed 7-23-1991)



ABANDONED PROPERTY AND VEHICLES



§ 91.080  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ABANDONED MOTOR VEHICLE. A motor vehicle that is inoperable and more
than eight years old and left unattended on public property for more than 48
hours, or a motor vehicle that has remained illegally on public property for
a period of more than 48 hours, or a motor vehicle that has remained on
private property without the consent of the owner or person in control of the
property for more than 48 hours, or a motor vehicle left unattended on the
right-of-way of a designated county, state or federal highway for more than
48 hours.



   ABANDONED PROPERTY, OTHER THAN A MOTOR VEHICLE. Any such property lying
and remaining unattended on any of the public streets, alleys, sidewalks,
parks, grounds or ways of the city for 48 hours.



(Prior Code, § 18-31)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.081  NUISANCE DECLARED.



   (A)   Abandoned motor vehicles and abandoned property are hereby
declared to be a detriment and a menace to traffic and a hazard to the
health, safety and well-being of the residents and citizens of the community,
and the same shall constitute a nuisance per se.



   (B)   The maintenance of any nuisance existing under this section
shall constitute a violation of this code and may be punished in accordance
with the provisions of this code, and the city may seek the abatement and/or
punishment for such a nuisance in any court of competent jurisdiction.



(Prior Code, § 18-32)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.082  REMOVAL OF VEHICLES FROM STREETS AND HIGHWAYS.



   (A)   Whenever any vehicle, which is not disabled, is found standing
upon the paved, main-traveled portion of a street, when it is possible to
move the vehicle off the same, any police officer of the City Police
Department is hereby authorized to move the vehicle, or to require the driver
or other person in charge of the vehicle to move the same, to a position off
the paved, main-traveled portion of the street.



   (B)   Any police officer of the City Police Department is hereby
authorized to provide for the removal of any vehicle parked or standing in or
on any portion of a street or highway when, in the opinion of the police
officer, the vehicle constitutes a hazard or interferes with a normal
function of a governmental agency or, by reason of any catastrophe, emergency
or unusual circumstance, the safety of the vehicle is imperiled.



(Prior Code, § 18-33)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.083  IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES.



   (A)   Pursuant to Tex. Transp. Code, Ch. 683, the City Police
Department may take into custody any abandoned motor vehicle found on public
or private property. Any police officer of the City Police Department is
further hereby authorized to provide for the removal of any vehicle from a
public street, alley, sidewalk, park, grounds or way, to a garage or place of
safety, under any of the following enumerated circumstances:



      (1)   When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge,
viaduct or causeway or in any other public place where the vehicle
constitutes an obstruction to traffic;



      (2)   When any vehicle is illegally parked so as to block the
entrance to any private driveway and it is impracticable to move the vehicle
from in front of the driveway to another point on the street or highway;



      (3)   When any vehicle is found upon a street or highway and
it has been previously reported that the vehicle has been stolen or a
complaint has been filed and a warrant thereon issued charging that the
vehicle has been embezzled;



      (4)   When any police officer has reasonable grounds to
believe that any vehicle has been abandoned;



      (5)   When any vehicle upon a street is so disabled that its
normal operation is impossible or impracticable and the person or persons in
charge of the vehicle either are not in the immediate vicinity of the
disabled vehicle or are not so incapacitated by reason as to be unable to
provide for its removal and custody;



      (6)   When any police officer arrests any person driving or in
control of a vehicle for an alleged offense and the officer is required,
either by this code or other law, to take the person arrested immediately
before a magistrate; or



      (7)   When any vehicle is illegally parked in violation of any
ordinance of the city or any law of the state.



   (B)   For any vehicle impounded pursuant to the provisions of
division (A) of this section, the city and its Police Department shall comply
with all procedures specified in Article V of the Texas Litter Abatement Act,
Tex. Transp. Code, Ch. 683, pertaining to notification of owners and
lienholders and to storage, redemption and auction of abandoned motor
vehicles.



   (C)   (1)   The redemption of a vehicle and payment of all
charges, fees and costs incurred by the city in the impoundment of the same
shall not constitute a waiver or dismissal of any fine due for violation of
any ordinance or law by reason of the unlawful parking of the vehicle. If the
owner of the motor vehicle so desires, he or she may pay the fine established
for the offense at the time of payment of all other charges and costs herein,
and a receipt shall be issued therefor.



      (2)   In the event that the owner does not desire to pay the
fine and shall demand that the case be heard before the Municipal Court, he
or she may obtain the release of the motor vehicle by posting security in the
amount of all charges, fees and costs plus the amount of the fine. This
security shall be in the form of cash, cashier's check, certified check or
money order. The receipt for the security, to be signed by the owner and the
Chief of Police or his or her designee, shall authorize the city to apply the
security in satisfaction of the impounding charges specified above in the
event that the owner or person charged with the violation leading to the
impounding of the vehicle shall be found guilty of the charge or shall
forfeit any case security which may have been posted or if a warrant for the
arrest of the person has been issued because of his or her failure to appear
in Municipal Court. In the event that trial results in a finding of not
guilty or the charge is dismissed, the security tendered for the release of
the motor vehicle shall be refunded, and the city shall assume the obligation
to pay all impounding charges.



(Prior Code, § 18-34)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.084  REMOVAL OF ABANDONED PROPERTY FROM PUBLIC PROPERTY.



   Any police officer of the City Police Department is hereby authorized
to provide for the removal of any abandoned property, as that term is defined
in this subchapter, from a public street, alley, sidewalk, park, any public
grounds or way, to a storage facility or place of safety.



(Prior Code, § 18-35)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.085  NOTICE OF REMOVAL.



   (A)   Whenever abandoned property is removed from a place, as
authorized in this subchapter, and it is possible to ascertain the name and
address of the owner thereof, notice of the removal shall be mailed, by
certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner. The notice shall
contain a description of the property removed and shall state the reasons for
removal, the date of removal, the location from which the property was
removed and the location of the place to which the property has been removed.
The notice shall further state that the property may be redeemed at any time
within 60 days from the date of removal in accordance with the redemption
provisions of § 91.086.



   (B)   In the event that it is not possible to ascertain the name and
address of the owner of the property, no notice shall be required.



(Prior Code, § 18-36)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.086  STORAGE AND REDEMPTION OF ABANDONED PROPERTY.



   (A)   Abandoned property, removed from public property under this
subchapter, shall be stored by the city in a place of safekeeping for a
period of 60 days from the date of removal and first storage thereof.



   (B)   At any time within the 60-day period, the owner of any such
property may present himself or herself at the Police Department and demand
return of his or her property. An employee of the city on duty at the Police
Department shall first satisfy himself or herself that the person so claiming
the property is the true and lawful owner thereof and is entitled to
possession thereof. The employee may require the person claiming ownership to
produce proper identification and any reasonably available proof of
ownership, including but not limited to a bill of sale for the property in
question.



   (C)   Upon being so satisfied and obtaining payment from the owner
of all charges, fees and costs incurred by the city in the removal and
storage of the property, the employee shall cause the property to be released
to the owner. The owner shall execute a receipt therefor upon a form provided
by the city, and the city's employee shall issue a receipt to the owner for
the payment of the fees and charges so collected.



(Prior Code, § 18-37)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.087  SALE OF ABANDONED PROPERTY.



   (A)   Upon the expiration of 60 days from the date of removal and
storage of any abandoned property, the city may undertake to sell the
unredeemed property at public sale. The date and time of the public sale,
together with a description of the property to be sold, shall be advertised
in the official newspaper of the city at least three days prior to the date
of the sale; and at the sale, property shall only be sold for the highest and
best bid received.



   (B)   An accurate record of each piece of property sold, the name
and address of the purchaser, the price paid therefor, the date of sale and
any other pertinent information shall be made and kept on file in the office
of the City Secretary.



(Prior Code, § 18-38)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.088  DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS OF SALE.



   (A)   The proceeds from the sale of property under § 91.087 above
shall first be applied to payment of all costs of removal, storage and sale
as incurred by the city herein. The sum shall be placed in the General Fund
of the city and thereafter, shall be disbursed as the City Council shall
determine and direct.



   (B)   In the event that the proceeds exceed the total of the costs
referenced above, the excess shall then be placed on deposit in a separate
fund maintained by the city; and upon demand made by the true owner of the
property (having owned the property prior to the date of sale by the city),
the excess shall be delivered to the owner. If no demand is made by the true
owner for the excess sum within two years from the date of sale, the sum
shall become the property of the city and shall be transferred to the General
Fund of the city to be used as the City Council shall determine and direct.



(Prior Code, § 18-39)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.089  WORTHLESS PROPERTY.



   Any motor vehicle or other piece of property which has been offered for
sale at public auction or sale and for which no bids have been received,
shall, upon a finding by the City Council that the same is worthless
property, be disposed of by the Mayor in such a manner as he or she deems
advisable. A record of the disposition of all such vehicles and property
shall be maintained on file in the office of the City Secretary, which record
shall include a description of the property, the date and manner of
disposition and the amount received therefor, if any.



(Prior Code, § 18-40)  (Ord. 84-078, § 1, passed 12-11-1984; Ord. 91-22,
§ 6, passed 7-23-1991)



NUISANCE



§ 91.100  NUISANCE DEFINED.



   A NUISANCE shall be defined as any circumstance or condition existing
within the city limits which shall, because of its existence or the
circumstances and conditions occurring as a result of its existence,
negatively affect the health, safety and well-being of the residents,
citizens and inhabitants of the city or in some way constitute an actual and
direct detriment to the safety and welfare of the general public and/or the
value of property and/or tend to invite vandalism, to create fire hazards
and/or to constitute an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health,
safety and well-being of minors and/or is detrimental to the economic welfare
of the city by producing urban blight which is adverse to the maintenance and
continuing development of the city.



(Prior Code, § 18-55)  (Ord. 91-22, § 3, passed 7-23-1991)



§ 91.101  SPECIFIC APPLICABILITY.



   (A)   Nuisance of general applicability declared to be a violation.
Wherever a circumstance, condition, property interest, property or a
possession of a natural person or legal entity shall be permitted to exist
under circumstances which constitute a natural and direct hazard to the
health, safety and well-being of the residents, citizens and inhabitants of
the city and/or a detriment to the safety and welfare of the general public
or a detriment to the value of the property, it shall constitute a nuisance
and be a violation of this code and be punished as herein provided.



   (B)   Nuisances in and around residential structures. A nuisance
shall be deemed to occur wherever there exist circumstances around
residential structures or houses which, because of their existence,
constitute an actual and potential hazard to the health, safety and general
well-being.



      (1)   In the event of the existence of this nuisance, any
police officer of the police force of the city is directed and empowered to
take action, including making immediate entry, to cause the immediate
abatement and removal of the offense caused by the existence of the nuisance
if the action is deemed necessary to prevent further injury or harm.



      (2)   A nuisance shall exist if any building materials and/or
raw materials and/or parts of buildings, foundations or improvements shall be
permitted to remain in an open, unsecured or unprotected area at such time
when construction is not ongoing and the materials are not being then and
there used for the construction. The maintenance of any debris, rubble,
wrappings, cord, boxes or other means of storage or delivery on residential
property in any manner shall constitute a nuisance. The maintenance of any
items of personal property in a quantity in excess of what may be reasonably
necessary for use by the owner, occupant or members of the immediate family
of the owners and occupants in an open yard or part of a residential lot or
improvement shall constitute a nuisance.



   (C)   Nuisance by noise. Any sustained or unusual noises exhibited
at hours customarily reserved for rest, sleep and repose are hereby declared
to be a nuisance.



   (D)   Nuisance by noise in the operation of any motor vehicle. The
operation of a motor vehicle within the city in such a manner as to exhibit
the emission of noise either through music or other noise of any kind,
including but not limited to any words or symbols, to a degree as herein
specified, shall constitute a nuisance and violation of this code. No one
shall operate a motor vehicle or be a passenger in a motor vehicle wherein
noise, music or vocal renditions from a radio or car stereo or other device
constitutes a nuisance as herein provided. A nuisance shall exist at any time
when the noise, music or vocal renditions can be heard in any manner by
persons not in the vehicle from which the noise is emanating. If this
circumstance exists, no other proof shall be necessary in order for a
violation to occur.



(Prior Code, § 18-57)  (Ord. 91-22, § 5, passed 7-23-1991)  Penalty, see
§ 91.999



§ 91.999  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   Any person convicted of a violation of §§ 91.100 and 91.101
of the code of ordinances of the city shall be punished by a fine not less
than $100 for each time a violation shall occur.



   (C)   Any person violates or causes, allows, or permits another to
violate any provision of § 91.066 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than
$500.  Each occurrence of any such violation of § 91.066 shall constitute a
separate offense. Each day on which any such violation of § 91.066 occurs
shall constitute a separate offense.



(Prior Code, § 18-56)  (Ord. 91-22, § 4, passed 7-23-1991; Am. Ord.
2012-01, passed 1-24-2012)



CHAPTER 92:  ALARM SYSTEMS
