AUTOMATED BURGLAR/THEFT ALARM PROTECTIVE SERVICES



§ 92.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ALARM DIALING DEVICE. Any device connected to an alarm system which
automatically sends a pre-recorded message or coded signal to a
pre-determined location, indicating the activation of the alarm system.



   ALARM SITE. The specific property or area of the premises upon or
within which an alarm system is or is to be installed.



   ALARM SYSTEM. A device or system that transmits a signal intended to
summon police of the city in response to a burglary. The term includes an
alarm that emits an audible signal from the exterior of a structure.



   CENTRAL STATION. The part of an alarm system business which intercepts
signals indicating the activation of an alarm device and which relays this
information by live voice to the Police Department.



   FALSE ALARM. Any alarm which was not the result of an emergency or
threat of emergency of the kind for which the alarm system was designed to
give notice.



   FIFTEEN-MINUTE SHUT-OFF. An automatic device associated with a local
alarm or any alarm system which automatically causes the alarm to shut off
and discontinue the emission of an audible signal after a period of time not
to exceed 15 minutes of continuous operation.



   LOCAL ALARM. Any alarm emitting audible and/or visual signals in, at or
on the alarm site when activated and which causes notification to be made
directly or indirectly to the Police Department.



   PERMIT. A certificate of authorization issued by the City Secretary to
the person in control of the property which authorizes the operation of an
alarm system.



   PERMIT HOLDER. The individual, corporation, partnership or one other
legal entity to whom an alarm system permit is issued.



   PERSON. Any individual, partnership, corporation or other legal entity.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-1)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.02  APPLICABILITY.



   This subchapter and the regulations contained thereon shall be deemed
to all alarm systems, alarm sites, alarm dialing devices and local alarms and
shall not be deemed to regulate or cover:



   (A)   An alarm system installed on a motor vehicle;



   (B)   An alarm designed so that no notification is given either
audibly or by phone until after the occupants or an agent of the owner or
lessee have checked the alarm site and determined that there is physical
evidence at the site showing that the alarm was the result of criminal
activity of the kind for which the alarm system was designed to give notice,
if a person who is able to grant access to the alarm system remains at the
site until police arrive whenever the police are notified; or



   (C)   An alarm installed upon premises occupied by the United States
Government, the State of Texas, the County of Fort Bend, the City of Meadows
Place, or the Fort Bend County Independent School District, or any other
governmental entity.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-2)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.03  PERMIT REQUIRED; ANNUAL RENEWAL.



   (A)   Required. No person shall cause to be operated or permit the
operation of an alarm system unless a current permit has been issued by the
City Secretary for the system and the person shall pay a fee as set forth by
City Council in a schedule of fees.



   (B)   Multiple alarm systems. Any person in control of property at
an alarm site may obtain a separate permit for each alarm system or may
obtain a single permit for all alarm systems on as much of the one premises
as is under the control of the applicant for the permit, except that one
permit shall not authorize the operation of both hold-up alarms and burglar
alarms. If both hold-up alarms and burglar alarms are operated on one
premises, a single permit may be obtained for all hold-up alarms on as much
of the premises as is under the control of the applicant and a separate
permit for all burglar alarms on the premise under the applicant’s control.



   (C)   Annual renewal. All permits issued shall expire on December 31
of each year. Permits shall be automatically renewed upon completing a
renewal application which shall be in a form prescribed by the City
Secretary. The renewal application shall verify the current accuracy and/or
specify any changes in the original application on file. The established
annual fee shall be paid at the time of renewal. (Any permit that is not to
be renewed because of the failure of the permit holder to properly apply for
renewal or pay the prescribed annual fee shall be deemed cancelled on
December 31 of the year in which it expires.) The Mayor of the city as
provided for under § 92.19 shall have the power to delay the implementation
of this section by appropriate rules.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-3)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992; Am. Ord.
2012-18, passed 6-26-2012)  Penalty, see § 92.99



§ 92.04  PERMIT APPLICATION.



   (A)   Application for a permit shall be made to the City Secretary
on a form as prescribed by the City Secretary, for the operation of an alarm
system by the person having control over the property on which the alarm
system is to be installed and operated. The application shall be made in
writing and in duplicate to the City Secretary.



   (B)   The application shall set forth:



      (1)   The name, address and telephone number of each person in
control of the property;



      (2)   The street address of the property on which the alarm
system is located and operated;



      (3)   Any business name used for the premises on which the
alarm system is to be installed and operated;



      (4)   Whether the alarm system or systems are or are not local
alarms and whether the alarm system or systems are designed to give notice of
burglary, hold-up or other type of emergency;



      (5)   The name of the person or alarm system business who will
install the alarm system and/or who will monitor the alarm system; and



      (6)   The names and telephone numbers of an alarm system
business or of two persons who are able to and have agreed to:



         (a)   Receive notification at any time;



         (b)   Come to the alarm site within one-half hour after
receiving a request to do so from any member of the Police Department of the
city; and



         (c)   Grant access to the alarm site and deactivate the
alarm system if it becomes necessary.



   (C)   The form prescribed by the City Secretary shall provide that
the applicant acknowledges that he or she has received a copy of this
subchapter providing regulations for alarm systems and is knowledgeable
thereof and agrees to comply with the provisions of law relating to such
alarms.



   (D)   The City Secretary may issue a permit to the individual,
corporation, partnership or other legal entity in control of the property
(alarm site) upon receipt of the application as herein provided and payment
of the permit fee as provided for herein.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-4)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.05  DUTY OF PERMIT HOLDER.



   Whenever a person listed on the application or listed on an amendment
to the application is unable or unwilling to perform the duties as set out
herein, the permit holder shall immediately upon such event file an amendment
to the permit application listing a person or company who is able and willing
to perform those duties so that at all times the application on file with the
City Secretary designates at least two persons and/or an alarm system
business who are able and willing to perform those duties.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-5)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.06  PERMIT REQUIRED FOR EXISTING ALARM SYSTEM.



   No person shall operate or shall permit the operation of an alarm
system which was installed at an alarm site prior to January 1, 1992, unless
a permit for the alarm system is obtained prior to June 30, 1992, or such
later date as may be established by the Mayor of the city under applicable
rules issued under the authority contained in § 92.19. To obtain such a
permit, the person in control of the property shall file an application and
proceed as herein provided in the case of a new application.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-6)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.07  PERMIT NOT TRANSFERABLE; NEW PERMIT REQUIRED UPON TRANSFER OF
PROPERTY; PERMIT FORM.



   (A)   Each permit issued in accordance with this subchapter shall be
valid until such time as the control of the property is transferred from the
permit holder. Upon transfer of control of the property, a new permit shall
be required. Each permit issued hereunder shall be personal as to the holder
thereof and not transferable.



   (B)   The City Secretary shall cause a distinctive form to be
created for an alarm permit, the form shall bear the seal of the City of
Meadows Place and shall provide on its face in large, conspicuous letters the
year or portion thereof for which it is valid.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-7)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.08  PRODUCTION OF PERMIT FOR INSPECTION.



   The permit holder for an alarm system shall keep the permit at the
alarm site and shall produce the permit for inspection upon the request of
any member of the City Police Department.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-8)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.09  DUTIES OF PERMIT HOLDER GENERALLY.



   The person in control of the property and the holder of a permit on
which an alarm system is installed (alarm site) shall do both of the
following:



   (A)   Ensure that any person listed with the City Secretary for the
purpose of notification as herein provided is able to:



      (1)   Receive notification at any time;



      (2)   Come to the alarm site within one-half hour after
receiving a request to do so from any member of the Police Department of the
city or the City Secretary; and



      (3)   Grant access to the alarm site and to deactivate the
alarm system if it becomes necessary.



   (B)   Train all persons who may activate the alarm system in the
proper operation of the alarm system.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-9)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.10  DUTY TO REPAIR OR DEACTIVATE SYSTEM.



   (A)   The permit holder and any persons in control of the alarm site
shall ensure that the alarm system is repaired within 72 hours of receipt of
written notification that the system is malfunctioning, which notice to be
given on a form designated by the Police Department or the City Secretary.



   (B)   The person in control of the property may cause the system to
be deactivated rather than repaired if the procedure is determined to be
appropriate. If the system is deactivated, the system shall not be
reactivated until it has been repaired.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-10)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.11  DUTY TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO ALARM SITE.



   Any person who is notified by the City Secretary or by any member of
the Police Department of activation of an alarm system and who is able to
give access to the alarm site shall come to the alarm site within one-half
hour of the time the person is notified of the activation and shall provide
the City Secretary and/or a member of the Police Department with necessary
access or assistance.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-11)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.12  ALARM SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS.



   No person shall apply for a permit, nor shall any person install, cause
to be installed or permit to be installed any alarm system unless the
requirements of this section are met.



   (A)   Any alarm system may be activated as a result of different
types of emergency situations and shall give a unique signal to designate
activation as a result of a hold-up, a burglary, a fire, medical emergency or
any other type of emergency situation so that the proper notification and
proper response can be made.



   (B)   Any local alarm system shall have a 15-minute shut-off and
must not make a sound similar to that of a siren or any emergency vehicle or
similar to a civil defense warning system.



   (C)   Any hold-up alarm shall be designed so that it may be
activated only by intentional and deliberate human action and shall not be
activated by springs, clips or similar devices.



   (D)   No local alarm shall be activated by a hold-up alarm.



   (E)   No person shall use or permit the use of any telephone device
or telephone attachment which automatically selects any telephone line
leading into the City Hall and/or the communication center of the Police
Department of the city and/or the communication center of the Sheriff's
Department of the county, or any number leading into the offices of any
public service organization that transmits any prerecorded message or signal.



   (F)   No person shall use or permit the use of any system which
gives notification of the activation of an alarm system directly to the
Police Department by any means other than live human voice.



   (G)   The Chief of Police and/or the City Secretary may set
reasonable standards and procedures to be followed by any alarm system
business or telephone answering service when giving notice to the Police
Department of activation of an alarm system. The standards and procedures
shall be set out in writing and made available to any alarm system business
or telephone answering service requesting same.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-12)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.13  REPORT OF ALARM SYSTEM INSTALLATION.



   (A)   Any alarm system business which installs an alarm system
within the city shall provide the City Secretary of the following information
on a form designated by the City Secretary. Providing this information shall
not be deemed application for a permit which is otherwise required under
other sections of this subchapter. The information required shall be:



      (1)   The address where the system is located;



      (2)   The name and address of the person having control over
the property; and



      (3)   The type of alarm system.



   (B)   The City Secretary shall prescribe a form for the purposes of
submitting the information and the same shall be submitted to the City
Secretary not earlier than 20 days prior to the installation of the system
and not later than 48 hours after the system is installed. In the event an
alarm system is installed in conjunction with remodeling, improvements or
other work, the person performing the work shall first inquire as to whether
or not any other permits are required for the work under the terms and
provisions of this code and, if so required, the person making the
installation shall be required to obtain the permits under the procedures and
regulations as herein provided. All information submitted concerning the
installation of an alarm system shall, unless otherwise provided for by law,
be treated as confidential and access thereto shall be restricted to
legitimate law enforcement personnel for law enforcement purposes and in
furtherance of the provisions of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-13)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.14  REQUIREMENTS FOR AN ALARM SYSTEM BUSINESS.



   Any person, partnership, corporation or other entity, whether
physically located with a place of business in the city or not, shall be in
violation of this code and subject to punishment as provided for by law if
the person, partnership, corporation or other legal entity agrees to maintain
or service any alarm system within the city unless the person, partnership,
corporation or other legal entity shall:



   (A)   Ensure that personnel of the business, who are able to render
effective assistance, arrive at the alarm site within one-half hour of
request for assistance by any member of the Police Department or the City
Secretary if the alarm system business has agreed with any person to respond
to the alarm system. This requirement shall not be applicable to alarm system
businesses that have specifically, by agreement, excluded any obligation to
personally attend to an alarm device;



   (B)   Ensure that sufficient personnel of the business are available
to provide service and to repair any alarm system the business has agreed to
maintain or service within 72 hours after notification that the system is in
need of repair is received from any person in control of the property, from a
member of the Police Department of the city, or from the City Secretary; and



   (C)   Keep a written record of the date and time of repair and a
description of the specific repair which was performed on any alarm system
when the repair was made in response to notification by the person in control
of the property, by a member of the Police Department or by the City
Secretary or any member of his or her staff, that the alarm system was in
need of repair. This written record shall be maintained for at least two
years and shall be made available for inspection and duplication by any
member of the Building Official's staff, designated by the Building Official,
or any member of the Police Department, designated by the Chief of Police, to
inspect the records when that member of the Building Official's staff or the
Police Department makes demand at the office of the alarm system business
during regular business hours.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-14)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.15  NOTIFICATION DUTIES OF ALARM SYSTEM BUSINESS/TELEPHONE ANSWERING
SERVICE GENERALLY.



   Any alarm system business which operates a central station and any
telephone answering service which agrees with any person to provide services
relating to an alarm system which is located on an alarm site in the city
shall:



   (A)   Have sufficient personnel, trained in the procedures to be
followed in receiving and relaying notice of the activation of any alarm
system, on duty at all times to ensure that emergency messages or alarm
signals received by the business can be relayed immediately to the Police
Department;



   (B)   Notify the person in control of the property or his or her
designated employee of the activation of the alarm system within 24 hours of
the time the alarm was activated by telephone or by placing the notice in the
mail, addressed to the person in control of the property;



   (C)   Keep a written record of the date and time each notification
of the activation of an alarm system is received and the date, time and
method the person in control of the property or his or her designated
employee was notified. These written records shall be maintained for at least
two years and shall be made available for inspection by the City Secretary,
or any member of his or her staff, or any member of the Police Department
upon reasonable demand at the office of the City Secretary;



   (D)   Test or cause to be tested all equipment used by the central
station or telephone answering service relating to the receipt of
notification of the activation of any alarm system and the equipment used in
relaying those notifications to the Police Department, at least one time in
every calendar year and, where a test result is unsatisfactory, correct or
cause to be corrected, within a reasonable period of time not to exceed seven
days, the cause of the unsatisfactory test result;



   (E)   Produce evidence of the results of tests conducted pursuant to
division (D) above upon request of a member of the staff of the City
Secretary designated by the City Secretary to perform such services, or to
any member of the Police Department. The requirements of this division shall
be satisfied if the results are made available at the office of the City
Secretary on the next regular business day after demand is made; and



   (F)   Not violate any provisions of the laws of the state or the
city relating to operating and licensing.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-15)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.16  FEES AND CHARGES FOR FALSE ALARMS.



   (A)   No penalty or fee for signaling a false alarm by an alarm
system shall be made unless at least five other false alarms have occurred
during the preceding 12 months. A false alarm shall not be deemed to have
occurred unless a response is made by the city police or fire service within
30 minutes of the alarm notification and the police or fire service
determines from an inspection of the interior or exterior of the premises
that the alarm was false.



   (B)   In the event a false alarm occurs and there have been at least
five previous false alarms during the preceding 12 months, owner or occupant
shall pay a fee as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-16)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992; Ord. 92-15, §
1, passed 2-25-1992; Am. Ord. 2012-18, passed 6-26-2012)  Penalty, see §
92.99



§ 92.17  SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION OF A PERMIT.



   (A)   The city shall not, at any time, terminate its law enforcement
response to an alarm held by a permit holder because of excess false alarms,
if the false alarm fees are paid in full. No permit shall be terminated or
fail to be renewed without the City Secretary giving at least 30 days'
written notice to the permit holder. The notice shall be in writing and shall
be mailed certified mail, return receipt requested, by the City Secretary to
the address of the permit holder or to the address for the permit site.



   (B)   No permit may be canceled, nor renewal denied, without fully
complying with the terms and provisions of this section, and prior to
termination, the permit holder may request a hearing before the Mayor of the
city. The notice of termination and/or the intent not to renew shall specify
the reasons for termination and/or non-renewal. If a hearing is requested by
the permit holder, the City Secretary shall advise the permit holder, the
Chief of Police and the Mayor as to the date, time and place of the hearing.
The permit holder may appear in person or represented by counsel, may present
testimony and cross-examine all witnesses.



   (C)   All hearings shall be conducted under rules consistent with
the nature of the proceedings; provided, however, that the following rules
shall apply to such hearings:



      (1)   All parties shall have the right to representation by a
licensed attorney although an attorney is not required;



      (2)   Each party may present witnesses in his or her own
behalf;



      (3)   Each party has the right to cross-examine all witnesses;
and



      (4)   Only evidence presented before the hearing officer at
the hearing may be considered in rendering a final order.



   (D)   If the permit holder fails to appear at the hearing at the
date, time, and place specified, the city shall, at the time of the hearing,
present sufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case showing that five
or more false alarms, for which responding officers have been unable to find
proof of robbery or attempted robbery, burglary or attempted burglary, any
criminal felony, fire, smoke, arson or attempted arson, have been activated
within the current calendar year or the calendar year immediately preceding
the date of the noticed hearing.



   (E)   If the Mayor finds that grounds exist for revocation of the
permit for the alarm system, the Mayor may revoke the permit and/or decline
to renew any expired permit. The City Secretary shall give written notice to
the permit holder of that decision. Upon receipt of this notice, the permit
holder may, on or before the expiration of ten days from the date of receipt
of the notice, file a request with the City Secretary for a hearing de novo
before the City Council of the city. The request shall be accompanied by a
fee in an amount as shall be established by the City Secretary to cover the
costs of the hearing and all notification required. The City Council shall
conduct a hearing in accordance with the terms and provisions of law and
shall hear such witnesses as shall reasonably be presented and shall make
findings thereon in the same format as was previously required of the Mayor.
If the City Council finds that grounds exist for the revocation of the permit
for the alarm system, it may revoke the permit and shall instruct the City
Secretary to give written notice to the permit holder of the revocation. The
decision of the City Council shall be final and binding.



   (F)   Upon receipt of a final notice of termination and/or
nonrenewal as herein provided, the permit holder shall disconnect the alarm
system immediately and shall surrender any previously issued permit to the
City Secretary or any member of the Police Department.



   (G)   Final written notice shall be given to the permit holder as to
the results of any final hearing before the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-17)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.18  REINSTATEMENT OF REVOKED PERMIT.



   After a permit for an alarm system has been revoked, the person in
control of the property on which the alarm system is located may make
application to the city for reinstatement of the permit. In addition to the
information required in any permit application, an applicant for
reinstatement shall also submit to the city an affidavit of an alarm
inspector employed by an alarm system business. The affidavit shall certify
that the alarm system for which permit reinstatement is sought is
mechanically sound and free of defects which tend to produce false alarms.
Upon receipt of the application and affidavit, the city shall reinstate the
alarm permit upon deposit by the applicant with the city as set forth by City
Council in a schedule of fees. The deposit may be made in cash or in the form
of a performance bond issued by a good and sufficient surety, acceptable to
the city, on condition that the sum of money subject to the bond is payable
to the city upon demand by the city in the event that the terms and
provisions of this subchapter are not complied with or in any way breached.
The deposit shall be held by the city for a period of one full calendar year
following the date of reinstatement, at the end of which time, if the subject
alarm has produced five or fewer false alarms during the calendar year, the
deposit shall be returned to the permit holder. However, if in the event of
more than five alarms during that period, any fees and charges assessed under
the terms and provisions of this subchapter may be charged against the
deposit, and the balance of the deposit will not be returned to the permit
holder until further revocation of the permit or until the completion of one
calendar year in which five or fewer false alarms occur, whichever shall
occur first. The city shall be permitted to charge the deposit as herein
required for the costs incurred by reason of the false alarms which may occur.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-18)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992; Am. Ord.
2012-18, passed 6-26-2012)  Penalty, see § 92.99



§ 92.19  MAYOR MAY ESTABLISH RULES.



   (A)   The Mayor of the city is authorized, from time to time, to
establish rules for implementation and interpretation of this subchapter. Any
such rules so prescribed shall be filed with the City Secretary and shall
become final and binding within 20 days after being so filed with the City
Secretary unless prior to the expiration of the 20-day period the City
Council, by majority vote, passes a resolution suspending the prescribed
rules.



   (B)   The City Secretary, upon receipt of the prescribed rules,
shall cause a copy of the prescribed rules to be published by posting the
same in the customary place reserved for posting legal notifications within
the city.



(Prior Code, § 9.5-19)  (Ord. 92-07, § 1, passed 1-28-1992)



§ 92.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another to violate
any provision of §§ 92.03, 92.16 and 92.18 shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not
more than $500.  Each occurrence of any such violation of §§ 92.03, 92.16
and 92.18 shall constitute a separate offense.  Each day on which any such
violation of §§ 92.03, 92.16 and 92.18 occurs shall constitute a separate
offense.



(Ord. 2012-18, passed 6-26-2012)



CHAPTER 93:  FIRE PROTECTION AND PREVENTION



Section



General Provisions



   93.01   Arson reward



Fire Department



   93.15   Establishment



   93.16   Fire Chief



   93.17   Equipment and property



   93.18   Emergency circumstances and conditions



   93.19   Extraordinary circumstances and conditions



   93.20   Volunteer Fire Department



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 93.01  ARSON REWARD.



   (A)   The city hereby offers a reward of $250 to anyone who secures
and furnishes information necessary to and which results in arrest and
conviction of any person or persons who commit the crime of arson within the
corporate limits of the city.  This reward is a standing offer and shall be
paid out of the General Fund of the city.



   (B)   The City Secretary and/or Fire Marshal is hereby directed to
have prepared and posted, in at least six public buildings located within the
city, an arson reward notice bearing the language as set out in division (A)
of this section. Placards bearing such notice language shall be eight inches
by 12 inches in size and shall be placed in wooden frames under glass.



   (C)   The City Secretary is hereby directed to provide a certified
copy of this section, one of the placards and a list of places where the
placards have been posted, to the office of the State Board of Insurance. 



(Prior Code, § 13-2)  (Ord. 84-066, § 1, passed 9-25-1984; Ord. 86-04, §
1, passed 1-28-1986)



FIRE DEPARTMENT



§ 93.15  ESTABLISHMENT.



   There is hereby established a City Fire Department, which shall consist
of either volunteers as members of a Volunteer Fire Department or employed
fire officers who shall be compensated in accordance with law. The
composition of the Fire Department shall be within the discretion of the
Mayor as chief administrative officer of the city, based upon policy as shall
from time to time be established by the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 13-75)  (Ord. 86-030, § 1, passed 7-30-1986)



§ 93.16  FIRE CHIEF.



   (A)   The Mayor, with concurrence of the City Council, shall appoint
a Fire Chief who shall serve in that capacity from time to time as the Mayor
shall direct. The Fire Chief shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and/or
City Council.



   (B)   The Fire Chief shall be the chief fire officer of the city,
and shall at all times be in command of the Fire Department, either volunteer
or regularly paid officers. The Fire Chief shall have all powers provided for
by law and shall have the power to issue orders, make directives and delegate
to subordinates the responsibility for the conduct of the Department as shall
from time to time be deemed necessary, just and proper by the Fire Chief.



(Prior Code, § 13-76)  (Ord. 86-030, § 1, passed 7-30-1986)



§ 93.17  EQUIPMENT AND PROPERTY.



   All fire apparatus and Fire Department equipment that shall at any time
be acquired by the city shall be city property and shall not be neglected or
wasted. The use thereof may be dictated by the Mayor pursuant to a policy
established by the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 13-77)  (Ord. 86-030, § 1, passed 7-30-1986)



§ 93.18  EMERGENCY CIRCUMSTANCES AND CONDITIONS.



   In addition to the requirements of law, the Fire Chief shall from time
to time have the right to promulgate such rules and regulations as deemed
necessary, to be placed in force and effect under emergency circumstances or
conditions or during the training or routine duty of any member of the
Department. Any person failing to obey any order of the Fire Chief or to
respond to any direction of the Fire Chief communicated to that person shall
be deemed to be in violation of this code and guilty of a misdemeanor.



(Prior Code, § 13-78)  (Ord. 86-030, § 1, passed 7-30-1986)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 93.19  EXTRAORDINARY CIRCUMSTANCES AND CONDITIONS.



   If at any time there exist circumstances and conditions which require
the restraint of persons, the arrest of persons suspected of offenses
relating to fires or other actions deemed necessary to preserve the health
and safety of the city, the Fire Chief is authorized to take all appropriate
action necessary to preserve and protect the health, safety and well-being of
the residents, citizens and inhabitants of the city. To this end, in the
absence of a peace officer, the Fire Chief may, when deemed necessary for the
protection of the health, safety and well-being, restrain persons and/or
effect an immediate arrest in furtherance of his or her duties, obligations
and responsibilities.



(Prior Code, § 13-79)  (Ord. 86-030, § 1, passed 7-30-1986)



§ 93.20  VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT.



   The Volunteer Fire Department of the city may organize as a chartered
volunteer fire department if the members of the Department so elect and may
appoint and elect officers as the members may choose. However, the members of
the Volunteer Fire Department, regardless of office held with the volunteer
organization, shall serve as directed by the Fire Chief and shall perform
only such actions and assume such duties as shall from time to time be
designated and directed by the Fire Chief. Volunteer firefighters shall not
have any right of continuation in office but may be discharged from duties,
responsibilities and obligations as the Fire Chief may from time to time
direct. In addition, membership in a Volunteer Fire Department shall not be
deemed to provide any additional authority in the Fire Department of the city.



(Prior Code, § 13-80)  (Ord. 86-030, § 1, passed 7-30-1986)



CHAPTER 94:  PARKS AND RECREATION



Section



General Provisions



   94.01   Purpose



   94.02   Regulation of parks and public grounds



   94.03   Park hours




Park Pavilion, Community Center and Swimming Pool




   94.15   Provisions applicable to the Park Pavilion use and rental
only



   94.16   Provisions applicable to the Community Center use and rental
only



   94.17   Provisions applicable to the Swimming Pool use and rental
only



   94.18   Provisions applicable to the Park Pavilion, the Community
Center, and the Swimming Pool



   94.19   Provisions applicable to barbeque pit rentals



   94.20   Provisions applicable to kayak rentals



   94.21   Provisions applicable to tennis court rentals



 



   94.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 94.01  PURPOSE.



   In order to facilitate all public recreational programs in the city and
to ensure that all park land, including presently existing park land and park
land which may be acquired in the future, is properly administered, planned
and developed to its maximum potential for the benefit of the citizens and
inhabitants of the city, the Parks and Recreation Department of the city is
established.



(Prior Code, § 21.5-1)  (Ord. 85-030, §§ 1, 2, passed 10-22-1985; Ord.
2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



§ 94.02  REGULATION OF PARKS AND PUBLIC GROUNDS.



   The Director of Parks and Recreation of the city shall be empowered to
post signs, barriers, notices, or other regulatory devices as may be from
time to time deemed necessary or proper because of certain circumstances or
conditions that may be in effect or existence at that time.



(Prior Code, § 21.5-6)  (Ord. 85-030, §§ 1, 2, passed 10-22-1985; Ord.
92-01, § 1, passed 1-14-1992; Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 94.03  PARK HOURS.



   All city park hours shall be 6:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m., unless otherwise
provided for in this section.



(Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



PARK PAVILION, COMMUNITY CENTER AND SWIMMING POOL



§ 94.15  PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE PARK PAVILION USE AND RENTAL ONLY.



   (A)   Any person desiring to use a park pavilion, shall submit a
park pavilion application to the city and apply a rental fee and a deposit as
set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees. An applicant must be 21
years of age or older and in good financial standing with the city. If the
city denies the rental application, the city shall refund the fee and
cleaning deposit to the applicant no later than five business days after the
date the city denies the rental application. If the city approves the rental
application, the city shall refund the cleaning deposit no later than ten
business days after rental unless the applicant fails to clean the park
pavilion, owes the city other fees associated with rental of any city
facility, applicant causes property damage to the park pavilion, or fails to
adhere to the terms and conditions of this section or any other city
ordinance.



   (B)   Rentals of park pavilions are for the entire time that the
park is open.



   (C)   The applicant shall submit an application to the city not less
than two business days before the rental date and not earlier than 90 days
before the rental date.



   (D)   The applicant shall remove all items brought into the park
pavilion. Applicant shall clean the park pavilion. Clean-up includes removing
all trash and debris after placing such items in city approved trash bags and
placing such trash bags in the city’s receptacle for solid waste; removing
all decorations; cleaning and returning all tables and chairs to their proper
place of storage.



   (E)   No rental of the park pavilion shall continue later than 10:00
p.m. the use of the park pavilion outside the city approved reservation is
strictly prohibited and may result in forfeiture of the security deposit.
Moreover, criminal trespass charges may be filed by the city for a violation
of this section.



(Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



§ 94.16  PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE COMMUNITY CENTER USE AND RENTAL ONLY.



   (A)   Any person desiring to use the Community Center, shall submit
a Community Center application to the city and pay a rental and cleaning fee
as well as a damage deposit as set forth by the City Council in a schedule of
fees. An applicant must be 21 years of age or older and in good financial
standing with the city. If the city denies the rental application, the city
shall refund the rental and cleaning fee and damage deposit to the applicant
no later than five business days after the date the city denies the rental
application.



   (B)   The city shall provide a key to the applicant only which may
be picked up from the city on the last business day prior to the day for
which rental is authorized and the applicant shall return the key to the city
no later than 4:00 p.m. on the next business day after rental.



   (C)   In addition to the rules established by § 94.18, the
following rules shall apply to Community Center use and rental:



      (1)   Limitation of reservation. The applicant shall submit an
application to the city not less than ten business days before the rental
date and not earlier than one year before the rental date. The applicant may
rent the interior facilities and patio only. Renters may use the kitchenette
refrigerator, microwave, tables, and chairs; however, the ice machine,
projector, and screen are not for use.



      (2)   Swimming pool access. No one may enter the swimming pool
area without prior approval by the Director of Parks and Recreation.
Violation of this rule shall result in forfeiture of the applicant’s
exclusion from the Community Center and Swimming Pool for one calendar year.



      (3)   Decorations. Any decoration attached to the walls or
ceilings must be approved by the Parks and Recreation Department. Decorations
may not be permanently attached. Tape of any kind is prohibited on all
surfaces. Wall putty may be used to hang or mount decorations.



      (4)   Tablecloths. Tablecloths shall be used on tables if
food, liquids, decorations, or material or objects are used, which may stain
or scratch the surface of the table.



      (5)   Thermostats. Thermostats shall be returned to the posted
temperatures at the conclusion of the rental.



      (6)   Capacity. Building capacity shall not exceed 165 people.



      (7)   Securing the Community Center. All doors shall be locked
at the conclusion of the rental. Interior furnishings shall remain inside the
building and exterior or swimming pool furniture shall remain outside the
building.



      (8)   Cleaning. The city shall clean the Community Center
after use.



      (9)   Time reserved. No rental of the Community Center shall
continue later than 10:00 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday and 11:45 p.m. on
Friday and Saturday, except the Community Center rental may continue until
1:00 a.m. on January 1. Rental of the Community Center is limited to the
hours specified on the reservation. The use of the Community Center outside
the city approved reservation is strictly prohibited and may result in
forfeiture of the security deposit. Moreover, criminal trespass charges may
by the city for a violation of this section.



(Ord. 2014-08, passed 5-27-2014; Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



§ 94.17  PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SWIMMING POOL USE AND RENTAL ONLY.



   (A)   Availability of swimming pool for public use.



      (1)   Seasonal access. A public swimming pool may be owned and
operated by the city and may be made available for the recreational use of
residents of the city who purchase a seasonal wristband and subject to the
following conditions:



         (a)   Seasonal wristband fees shall be set by City
Council in the Schedule of Fees set forth in § 37.01.



         (b)   Seasonal wristbands are valid during the season
time frame set by the city. If a wristband holder moves out of the city, then
seasonal use shall cease. The city shall not provide any refunds.



         (c)   Seasonal wristbands may be issued for each member
of the household. Each member of the household who has been issued a city
wristband may admit one guest to the swimming pool.



         (d)   A valid driver's license with a Meadows Place
address or a current Meadows Place water bill must be shown to purchase a
seasonal wristband.



      (2)   Day access. Non-residents may purchase a one-day
swimming pool wristband. These wristbands may be purchased at the swimming
pool during normal operating hours at a fee as set by City Council in the
Schedule of Fees set forth in § 37.01 .



      (3)   Concessions. Concession punch cards may be issued by the
city for the purchase of prepackaged concessions available at the pool.



      (4)   The city shall determine the day and hours of operation
of the pool.



   (B)   (1)   Swimming pool rental. Any person desiring to rent the
swimming pool shall submit a swimming pool application to the city and pay a
rental fee and security deposit as may be set forth by City Council in the
Schedule of Fees set forth in § 37.01 . An applicant must be 21 years of age
or older and in good financial standing with the city. If the city denies the
rental application, the city shall refund the rental fee to the applicant no
later than five business days after the date the city denies the rental
application. If city staff determines for any reason that the swimming pool
should not be in use, including but not limited to inclement weather, for one
and one-half hours or more, then the applicant shall receive a full refund of
the rental fee and security deposit from the city.



      (2)   In addition to the rules established by § 94.16, the
following rules shall apply to swimming pool rentals:



         (a)   Limitation of reservation. The applicant shall
submit an application to the city not less than two business days before the
rental date and not earlier than 90 days before the rental date.



         (b)   Swimming pool reservations are allowed for a
maximum time of three and one-half hours and are scheduled only after public
use hours. No rental of the swimming pool shall continue later than 10:00
p.m. on Sunday through Thursday or 11:45 p.m. on Friday and Saturday, except
the swimming pool rental may continue until 1:00 a.m. on January 1. Rental of
the swimming pool is limited to the hours specified on the reservation. The
use of the swimming pool outside the city approved reservation is strictly
prohibited and may result in forfeiture of the security deposit. Moreover,
criminal trespass charges may be filed by the city for a violation of this
section.



         (c)   Glassware prohibited. No glassware shall be
brought in the swimming pool.



         (d)   Lifeguards. Swimming pool rentals are subject to
availability of lifeguards. The city shall determine the number of lifeguards
required to supervise a reservation based on the anticipated number of people
in attendance and the type of event.



   (C)   The renter of the swimming pool shall remove all items brought
into the swimming pool. The renter shall clean the swimming pool area.
Clean-up includes removing all trash and debris after placing such items in
city-approved trash bags and placing such trash bags in the city's receptacle
for solid waste; removing all decorations; cleaning and returning all tables
and chairs to their proper place of storage. A violation of this section may
result in the forfeiture of the renter's security deposit.



(Ord. 2014-08, passed 5-27-2014; Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016; Ord.
2017-14, passed 4-25-2017)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.18  PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE PARK PAVILION, THE COMMUNITY CENTER,
AND THE SWIMMING POOL.



   (A)   No commercial use allowed. Commercial use of the park
pavilion, community center, and swimming pool is prohibited, unless approved
in writing by the Director of Parks and Recreation or Mayor. Commercial use
shall mean and include all professional exhibitions or contests, promotional
and public dances, shows, classes, and other attractions sponsored, hosted,
or held by profit-making organizations or individuals, regardless of whether
such event, activity, or program is conducted at no charge and open to the
public. Commercial use does not include non-profit organizations with a
current Federal tax-exempt status designation.



   (B)   Reservations not transferrable. Reservations of the Park
Pavilion, Community Center, and Swimming Pool are not transferrable.



   (C)   Nondiscrimination policy. Reservations for the park pavilion,
community center, and swimming pool are on a first come, first served basis.
It is the policy of the city to make the park pavilion, community center, and
swimming pool available for rental to as broad a spectrum of groups and
individuals as is feasible. The city may revoke rental privileges or deny a
rental application based on an applicant’s or group’s past rental or
usage history.



   (D)   Changes to reservations. All changes, cancellations, and
additions to park pavilion, community center, and swimming pool reservations
shall be made no later than seven days prior to the time originally reserved.
The city may deny any changes or additions to reservations if made outside
this timeframe. Cancellation of reservations made outside this timeframe
shall result in applicant’s loss of the security deposit or rental fee.



   (E)   Conflicts with city activities. Activities conducted by the
city at the park pavilion, community center, or swimming pool shall be given
priority at all times even over existing reservations, and the city reserves
the right to cancel any reservations that may conflict with a city-sponsored
activity.



   (F)   Supervision of youth groups required. Groups shall have one
adult present at all times for every ten individuals 17 years of age and
younger.



   (G)   Smoking prohibited. There shall be no smoking in the park
pavilion, community center, or swimming pool.



   (H)   Setup. Applicant shall set up tables, chairs, and any other
items necessary for use of the park pavilion, community center, and swimming
pool. The amount of time needed to set up shall be included in the time
reserved.



   (I)   Indemnification of city. The applicant agrees to indemnify and
hold harmless the city and its officials, officers, agents, employees,
contractors, and subcontractors, from any and all actions, claims, costs,
demands, damages, and expenses, including but not limited to attorney’s
fees and court costs, arising out of the use of the park pavilion, community
center, and swimming pool. Furthermore, such indemnification shall apply with
respect to all acts or omissions of the applicant and the applicant’s
guests, family, friends, invitees, licensees and their respective invitees or
licensees associated with the use of the park pavilion, community center, and
swimming pool.



   (J)   City not liable for losses or damages. The city is not liable
for lost, damaged, or misplaced property at the park pavilion, community
center, or swimming pool. Furthermore, applicant releases and discharges the
city from any and all liability for loss, injury, or damage to persons or
property, including death that may be sustained arising out of the use of the
park pavilion, community center, or swimming pool.



   (K)   Compliance with applicable laws. The applicant is required to
be present at the park pavilion, community center, or swimming pool, as
applicable, and available to city personnel during the entire time reserved.
Applicant and the applicant’s guests, family, friends, invitees, licensees
and their respective invitees and licensees shall comply with all Federal,
state, and local laws. Furthermore, the applicant assumes full responsibility
and liability for the acts and omissions of his or her guests, family,
friends, invitees, licensees and their respective invitees and licensees that
may result in a violation of Federal, state, or local laws.



   (L)   Small objects prohibited. Rice, birdseed, confetti or similar
small objects are prohibited in the park pavilion, community center, and
swimming pool.



   (M)   Liability insurance. As part of the application to rent the
park pavilion, community center, or swimming pool, the city may require the
applicant to furnish proof of general liability insurance, require the
applicant to name the city as an additional insured, and include a waiver of
subrogation or waiver of right of recovery under such policy. Liability
insurance amounts shall be determined by the City Council which would ensure
adequate coverage for possible personal injury, death, or property damage
that may arise out of the rental and use of the park pavilion, community
center, or swimming pool by the applicant. If applicant rents a bounce house
or similar type amusement, applicant shall provide proof of general liability
insurance for not less than $1,000,000, name the city as an additional
insured, and include a waiver of subrogation or waiver of right of recovery
under such policy. Swim teams also shall provide proof of general liability
insurance for not less than $ 1,000,000, name the city as an additional
insured, and include a waiver of subrogation or waiver of right of recovery
under such policy.



   (N)   Liquids with coloring, dyes, or chemicals which may stain
prohibited. Liquids, including but not limited to juice or punch, which
contain coloring, dyes, or chemicals which may stain or discolor surfaces or
fabrics of the park pavilion, community center, or swimming pool are
prohibited.



   (O)   Maintenance issues. If the park pavilion, community center, or
swimming pool experience plumbing, mechanical, structural, or other such
problems while in use, the applicant shall immediately contact the city and
report such problem.



   (P)   Parking. Parking shall be limited to the lot in front of
Community Center and the parking lot west of the Community Center across the
bridge.



   (Q)   Open flames and combustible materials prohibited. No person
shall bring into or use at the park pavilion, community center, or swimming
pool, whether inside or outside, an open flame, a flame-producing device, or
any flammable or combustible material such as, but not limited to, candles,
incense, and charcoal.



   (R)   Alcohol. Alcohol is allowed in the park pavilion, community
center, and swimming pool; however, applicant shall pay an increased rental
fee if alcohol is consumed. Such rental fee shall be set by City Council in a
schedule of fees.



   (S)   Removal. If the applicant or applicant’s family, friends,
guests, invitees, licensees, or anyone associated or affiliated with
applicant violates any of the rules and regulations of this subchapter, the
city may require the immediate vacation of the park pavilion, community
center, and swimming pool of some or all people. Furthermore, the city may
refuse any applicant's future application to use or rent the park pavilion,
community center, or swimming pool.



   (T)   Security. The city may require applicant to hire certified
peace officers. Applicant shall comply with the city’s instructions
regarding security personnel.



   (U)   Closure. The city may close, either temporarily or
permanently, the park pavilion, community center, or the swimming pool at any
time the city finds it necessary to undertake repairs or maintenance, or in
the interest of the health, safety, or welfare of the community.



(Ord. 2014-08, passed 5-27-2014; Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



§ 94.19  PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO BARBEQUE PIT RENTALS.



   (A)   Any persons desiring to use the stationary barbeque pit in
McDonald Park shall submit a barbeque pit rental application with the city
and pay a rental fee and deposit as set forth by City Council in a schedule
of fees.



   (B)   (1)   Any person desiring to use the city's mobile barbeque
pit shall submit a barbeque pit rental application with the city and pay a
rental fee and deposit as set forth by the City Council in a schedule of
fees. The city’s mobile barbeque pit may be rented by the Meadows Place
Swim Team, Meadows Place Home and Garden Club, youth sports leagues, Fort
Bend Independent School District, Meadows Place Neighborhood Watch, scouting
groups, and any other community related entity as approved by the Director of
Parks and Recreation or the Mayor.



      (2)   The city shall deliver and pick up the mobile barbeque
pit. Except for Fort Bend Independent School District, the mobile barbeque
pit shall be located on city property. Fort Bend Independent School District
may locate the mobile barbeque pit on its school property within the city
only.



(Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



§ 94.20  PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO KAYAK RENTALS.



   (A)   No boat, kayak, canoe, inner tube, or other similar equipment
or devices shall be allowed in the city’s lake, except for the city’s
kayaks.



   (B)   Any person desiring to use the city’s kayak, shall submit a
kayak rental application and pay a rental fee as set forth by City Council in
a schedule of fees. The rental application with fee must be submitted to the
city at least two days before the use. No person, group, association, entity,
or organization may rent more than four of the city's kayak’s at one time.
Weekend kayak use begins on Friday and ends Monday morning at 8:00 a.m.



   (C)   Upon approval of the rental application, the city will provide
the applicant with a key to the gate in which the kayaks are housed and a
lock code to the specific kayak rented.



   (D)   A life jacket shall be worn at all times the kayak is in use.



(Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



§ 94.21  PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO TENNIS COURT RENTALS.



   (A)   Any city resident desiring to use the city’s tennis courts,
shall submit a tennis application and pay a rental fee as set forth by City
Council in a schedule of fees. The city shall issue only two access cards per
family.



   (B)   If a resident moves from the city, the resident shall return
the access card(s) to the city upon moving.



(Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



§ 94.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another to violate
any provisions of this sections hall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500
unless such violation implicates fire safety, zoning, or public health and
sanitation including dumping of refuse in which case the fine amount shall
not be more than $2,000. Each occurrence of any such violation of this
section shall constitute a separate offense. Each day on which any such
violation of this section occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 2014-08, passed 5-27-2014; Ord. 2016-10, passed 7-26-2016)



CHAPTER 95:  TELECOMMUNICATIONS

Antennas and Towers

structure and the issuance of a tower permit
