ANTENNAS AND TOWERS



§ 95.01  DEFINITIONS.



   As used in this code, the following terms shall have the meanings
indicated, and any other meanings or provisions in this code relating to such
terms that may be in conflict herewith shall be of no force and effect and
the meanings as herein provided shall be applicable.



   ALTERNATIVE TOWER STRUCTURE.  Human-made trees, clock towers, bell
steeples, light poles, and similar alternative-design mounting structures.



   ANTENNA. Any exterior apparatus designed for telephonic, radio,
television, or any other type of communications through the sending and/or
receiving of electromagnetic waves.



   FAA. The Federal Aviation Administration.



   FCC.  The Federal Communications Commission.



   GOVERNING AUTHORITY.  The City Council of the City of Meadows Place.



   HEIGHT. When referring to a tower or other structure, the distance
measured from ground level to the highest point on the tower or other
structure, even if the highest point is an antenna.



   TOWER.  Any structure that is designed and constructed primarily for
the purpose of supporting one or more antennas, including self-supporting
lattice towers, guy towers or monopole towers. The term includes radio and
television transmission towers, microwave towers, common-carrier towers,
cellular telephone towers and the like.



   TOWER PERMIT. A permit issued by the City Council under the authority
of this code and the provisions of this chapter. Any construction,
maintenance or use of a tower or antenna not in accord with the provisions of
this chapter shall be deemed illegal and the owner or operator thereof may be
fined to the maximum extent permitted by law for each day a violation shall
occur and each day shall be deemed a separate and distinct violation.



(Prior Code, § 27-1)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.02  APPLICABILITY.



   (A)   District height limitations. The requirements set forth in
this code shall govern the location of towers and antennas in the city.



   (B)   Public property. Antennas or towers located on publicly owned
property shall be exempt from the requirements of this code, provided a
license or lease authorizing the antenna or tower has been approved by the
City Council.



   (C)   Amateur radio and receive-only towers. This code shall not
govern any tower, or the installation of any antenna, that is under 100 feet
in height and is owned and operated by a federally-licensed amateur radio
station operator or is used exclusively as a receive-only antenna.



   (D)   Grandfathered towers and antennas. Any tower or antenna
existing on the effective date of this section shall not be required to meet
the requirements of this code other than the requirements of this code for
grandfathered towers and antennas. Any towers or antennas that fail to meet
the requirements of this code shall be referred to as "grandfathered towers"
or "grandfathered antennas."



   (E)   Network nodes. This chapter shall not apply to network nodes
installed and operational on or after September 1, 2017, as such term is
defined by Tex. Local Government Code Chapter 284.



(Prior Code, § 27-2)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997; Ord. 2017-02,
passed 1-24-2017; Ord. 2018- 06, passed 3-27-2018)



§ 95.03  GUIDELINES AND REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of this subchapter is to establish rules
and regulations for the siting and maintenance of towers and antennas of the
type as herein defined and set out. The goals of this chapter are to
encourage and to provide for the location of towers in nonresidential areas
and minimize the total number of towers throughout the community, and to
encourage strongly the joint use of new and existing towers. In addition, it
is the purpose of these regulations to encourage the use of towers and
antennas to be located in areas where the adverse impact on the community is
minimal and to encourage the user of towers and antennas to configure them in
a way that minimizes the adverse visual impact of the towers and antennas,
and to enhance the ability of the providers of telecommunications services to
provide such services to the community quickly, effectively and efficiently.



   (B)   Existing sites. Each applicant for a tower permit shall
provide the City Council an inventory of its existing towers, including
specific information about the location, height and design of each tower. The
City Council shall review the data and information as may be submitted, and
all data submitted in conjunction with an application as herein provided
shall be deemed a part of the open and public record.



   (C)   Lighting. The guidelines set forth in this code shall govern
the location of all towers and the installation of all antennas; provided,
however, that the governing body may in its sole discretion provide other
regulations or other requirements that accomplish the objectives of this code
where it is found that the goals and purposes of this chapter and this code
are better served by such exceptions.



   (D)   Requirements. Towers shall either be constructed to maintain a
galvanized steel finish or, subject to any applicable standards of the FAA,
be painted sky blue or gray so as to reduce visual obtrusiveness.



   (E)   Design requirements. At a tower site, the design of buildings
and related structures shall, to the extent possible, use materials, colors,
textures, screening and landscaping that will blend the tower facilities to
the natural setting and built environment.



(Prior Code, § 27-3)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.04  INSTALLATION OF AN ANTENNA ON A STRUCTURE OTHER THAN A TOWER.



   If an antenna is installed on a structure other than a tower, the
antenna and supporting electrical and mechanical equipment must be of a
neutral color that is identical to or closely compatible with the color of
the supporting structure so as to make the antenna and related equipment as
visually unobtrusive as possible.



(Prior Code, § 27-4)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.05  LIGHTING OF TOWERS PROHIBITED.



   Towers shall not be artificially lighted unless required by the FAA or
other applicable authority. If lighting is required, the City Council shall
approve the design for lighting and the design must take into effect existing
and contemplated uses of surrounding property and be configured in a way as
to cause the least disturbance to the surrounding views.



(Prior Code, § 27-5)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.06  FEDERAL AND OTHER GOVERNMENTAL REQUIREMENTS.



   All towers must meet or exceed current standards and regulations of the
FAA, the FCC and any other agency of the federal government or any other
governmental entity with the authority to regulate towers and antennas. If
the standards and regulations are changed, then the owners of the towers and
antennas governed by this code shall bring the towers and antennas into
compliance with the revised standards and regulations within six months of
the effective date of the revised standards and regulations. Failure to bring
towers and antennas into compliance with the revised standards and
regulations shall constitute an immediate and automatic revocation of the
authority granted under this chapter and the city may require the removal of
any tower antenna in noncompliance at the cost of the owners.



(Prior Code, § 27-6)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.07  BUILDING CODES; SAFETY STANDARDS.



   To ensure the structural integrity of towers, the owner of a tower
shall ensure that it is maintained in compliance with standards contained in
the Building Codes of the city and the applicable standards for towers that
are published by the Electronic Industries Association, as amended from time
to time. The city, through the Building Official or other persons so
designated, may inspect towers and antennas at any time, and if the Building
Official finds and concludes that the tower or an antenna fails to comply
with such codes and standards and/or constitutes a danger to persons or
property, then the Building Official, upon notice being provided to the owner
of the tower, may order that the tower and antenna be brought into compliance
with the codes and standards within a period not to exceed 30 days. If the
owner fails to bring the tower into compliance within 30 days, the City
Council may order the removal of the tower and antennas at the expense of the
owner. In the event a removal is ordered, the city shall not assume any
liability for the removal and shall be entitled to a lien upon the personal
property, fixtures or real estate for the purpose of paying its cost incurred
in the removal.



(Prior Code, § 27-7)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.08  TOWER PLACEMENT PERMIT REQUIRED.



   The City Council finds and determines that it is in the best interest
of the health, safety and well-being of the residents, citizens and
inhabitants of the city that no tower or antenna shall be constructed,
erected or maintained in the city unless a permit, hereinafter referred to as
a tower permit, shall have first been issued by the City Council for the
placement, location and maintenance of the tower and antenna.



(Prior Code, § 27-8)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.09  APPLICATION AND FEES.



   From time to time the City Council may adopt an application form or
procedure for the issuance of a tower permit. In addition, the City Council
may specify fees, costs and expenses that must be paid by the applicant as an
application fee prior to the review or issuance of the tower permit. In the
event the City Council shall fail to specify or provide for tower permit
application or a procedure for the issuance of a tower permit, then the
Building Official is hereby directed to establish such procedure as shall be
reasonable and necessary to accomplish the objectives of this code. The
application fee approved by the City Council shall be in an amount sufficient
to cover the cost incurred by the city in reviewing the application and
material submitted by the applicant. In addition, prior to the issuance of
any permit and as a condition for the issuance of a tower permit, the
applicant shall pay any additional cost as may be incurred by the city,
including but not limited to professional fees incurred in the review of any
application.



(Prior Code, § 27-9)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.10  REQUIREMENTS OF AN APPLICATION.



   Each application filed hereunder shall show and attach thereto all
relevant documents showing compliance with all laws and regulations
promulgated by the federal government, including laws and regulations
relating to the FAA or the FCC or any other governmental entity. In addition,
no authority granted under this code shall be deemed to have any final
authority until an application for a building permit has finally been
approved by the Building Official of the city.



(Prior Code, § 27-10)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.11  SHORTENED ADMINISTRATIVE PROCESS.



   (A)   The City Council recognizes that there are certain
circumstances where a tower permit may be issued administratively by the
Building Official without review by the City Council, and in this regard the
Building Official is hereby directed and authorized to issue a tower permit
as provided for under this chapter without referral to or review by the City
Council. The applicant for a tower permit by administrative approval shall
first comply with all other requirements of this code including making
application on such form as may be from time to time provided by the city and
paying the required fee. The authority herein granted to the Building
Official shall be deemed discretionary by the Building Official and the
Building Official may decline to issue a tower permit administratively and
may refer the application to the City Council for approval in accordance with
the other provisions of this chapter.



   (B)   The Building Official may approve a tower permit
administratively if it is found that one or more of the following conditions
or circumstances shall exist:



      (1)   The proposed tower or antenna, including the placement
of additional buildings or other supporting equipment used in connection with
the tower or antenna, will be located in an industrial or heavy commercial
district or area of town. An industrial or heavy commercial area is one that
is separated from any platted lot of record that is in residential use or
intended for residential use by at least 1,000 feet from the closest point of
any lot platted or used for residential purposes or, in the case of
non-platted property, 1,000 feet from any structure actually used for
residential purposes. In measuring or determining any of the distances as
herein provided, measurements should be taken from the closest point of the
lot or structure to the base or structural point of the tower closest to the
residential lot or residential structure.



      (2)   The installation of an antenna is on an existing
structure other than a tower (such as a building, sign, light pole, water
tower or other free-standing nonresidential structure) that is at least 50
feet in height or greater so long as the additional antenna adds no more than
20 feet to the height of the existing structure.



      (3)   The installation of an antenna is on an existing tower
of any height so long as the addition of the antenna adds no more than 20
feet to the height of the existing tower. The tower permit issued under this
section shall not permit the placement of additional buildings or other
supporting equipment used in connection with the antenna.



(Prior Code, § 27-11)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.12  GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR APPROVAL OF AN ANTENNA TOWER OR STRUCTURE
AND THE ISSUANCE OF A TOWER PERMIT.



   The following general provisions shall govern the issuance of a tower
permit and shall control all applications for a tower permit. Each applicant
requesting a tower permit under this code shall submit a scaled site plan and
a scaled elevation view and other supporting drawings, calculations, or other
documentation signed and sealed by appropriate professional engineers showing
the location and dimensions of the improvement, including information
concerning topography, radio frequency coverage, tower height requirements,
setbacks, drives, parking, fencing, landscaping, adjacent uses, and other
information necessary to assess compliance with this code, including such
other and additional information as may be deemed necessary and required by
the City Council.



(Prior Code, § 27-12)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.13  FACTORS CONSIDERED IN GRANTING THE TOWER PERMIT.



   The City Council shall consider the following factors in determining
whether or not to issue a tower permit and such other factors as may be
deemed appropriate and necessary in order to determine that the goals of the
code are properly served:



   (A)   Height of the proposed tower;



   (B)   Proximity of the tower to residential structures and
residential districts; however, the City Council shall not approve any tower
which is closer than 1,000 feet to any lot platted for residential use or
from any structure in residential use;



   (C)   Nature of uses on adjacent and nearby properties;



   (D)   Surrounding topography;



   (E)   Surrounding tree coverage and foliage;



   (F)   Design of the tower with particular reference to design
characteristics that have the effect of reducing or eliminating visual
obstructiveness; and



   (G)   The availability of suitable and existing towers and other
structures presently constructed which are suitable for antenna location.



(Prior Code, § 27-13)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.14  AVAILABILITY OF SUITABLE TOWERS OR OTHER STRUCTURES.



   No new tower permit shall be issued unless the applicant demonstrates
to the reasonable satisfaction of the City Council that no existing tower or
structure can accommodate the applicant's proposed antenna. Evidence
submitted to demonstrate that no existing tower or structure can accommodate
the applicant's proposed antenna or tower may consist of any of the following.



   (A)   No existing towers or structures are located within the
geographic area required to meet applicant's engineer's requirements.



   (B)   Existing towers or structures are not of sufficient height to
meet applicant's engineer's requirements.



   (C)   Existing towers or structures do not have sufficient
structural strength to support applicant's proposed antenna and related
equipment.



   (D)   The applicant's proposed antenna would cause electromagnetic
interference with the antennas on the existing towers or structures or the
antennas on the existing towers or structures would cause interference with
the applicant's proposed antenna.



   (E)   The fees or costs required to share an existing antenna or
structure which will be paid at the beginning of a sharing relationship or
will be paid within one year from the date of the inception of any sharing
relationship exceed the cost of constructing a new tower.



   (F)   Property owner(s) of existing towers or structures are
unwilling to accommodate reasonably the applicant's needs. The applicant must
specify the reason for property owner(s) refusing to accommodate and submit
satisfactory proof of non-accommodation, including documents evidencing
appropriate financial tenders.



   (G)   The applicants demonstrate that there are other limiting
factors that render existing towers and structures unsuitable.



(Prior Code, § 27-14)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.15  SETBACKS.



   The following setbacks and separation requirements shall apply to all
towers and antennas for which a tower permit is required; provided, however,
that the governing body may, in its discretion, provide for other or
different regulations if it finds that the goals of this code are better
served by such modifications.



   (A)   Towers must be set back a distance equal to 200 feet from the
nearest point to any lot platted for residential use or any structure in
residential use. If the height of the antenna tower is deemed to be greater
than 500 feet, then the setback as herein provided shall be three times the
height of the tower.



   (B)   Towers, guys and accessory facilities must be constructed in a
way to avoid adverse impact upon adjoining properties and the uses thereof.
In addition, all such structures and apparatus must be properly screened by a
visual barrier or fence of a height not less than eight feet and shall be
appropriately marked.



   (C)   In all areas other than industrial and heavy commercial areas
which are separated from lots platted for residential use or from structures
in residential use by more than 1,000 feet, towers over 90 feet in height
shall not be located within one-quarter mile from an existing tower that is
over 90 feet in height.



(Prior Code, § 27-15)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.16  SECURITY.



   In addition to the fencing requirements as herein set out, all fencing
shall be locked and secured and shall be equipped with appropriate
anti-climbing devices; provided, that if the City Council finds and
determines that, because of natural barriers or the existence of other
apparatus or conditions, this requirement is not necessary, the City Council
may in an appropriate case modify the screening and fencing requirements as
herein set out.



(Prior Code, § 27-16)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.17  LANDSCAPING.



   (A)   All towers constructed and maintained within the city limits
shall be landscaped and maintained in accordance with the provisions as
herein set out. The City Council, however, upon appropriate application, may
modify the provisions of this code when it is deemed appropriate in
accordance with the circumstances and conditions then existing.



   (B)   The requirements as herein provided are:



      (1)   Tower facilities shall be landscaped with a buffer of
plant materials that effectively screen the view of the tower compound. The
standard buffer shall consist of a landscaped strip at least four feet wide
outside the perimeter of the compound. The applicant for a tower permit shall
file with the city a landscape plan which shall be approved by the City
Council in conjunction with any application filed in accordance herewith. In
the case of an application for administrative approval, the requirements for
a landscape plan may be approved by the Building Official without City
Council approval if a request for administrative approval is granted. It
shall be the duty of the applicant to fully maintain any landscaping as
herein provided as a condition for the maintenance of the permit; and



      (2)   Existing mature tree growth and natural land forms on
the site shall be preserved to the maximum extent possible. In some cases,
such as towers sited on large, wooded lots, natural growth around the
property perimeter may be deemed by the City Council to be a sufficient
buffer.



(Prior Code, § 27-17)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.18  REMOVAL OF ABANDONED ANTENNAS AND TOWERS.



   Any antenna or tower that is not operated for a continuous period of 12
months shall be deemed abandoned, and the owner of the antenna or tower shall
remove the same within 30 days of the receipt of a notice from the City
Council notifying the owner of the abandonment. If the antenna or tower is
not removed within the required 30 days, or such additional period as may be
allowed by the City Council upon application, the City Council may remove the
antenna or tower at the expense of the owner and may file a lien upon the
real estate and any personal property or fixtures found to pay the cost of
removal.



(Prior Code, § 27-18)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.19  ANTENNAS AND TOWERS EXISTING AS OF THE DATE OF THE ADOPTION OF
THIS SUBCHAPTER.



   (A)   Any antenna or tower that would otherwise be subject to
regulation under the terms and provisions of this code that had been
constructed and lawfully in existence at the date of adoption of this chapter
shall be deemed grandfathered and shall not be subject to the regulations
provided under this code for the issuance of a tower permit. However, all
other provisions of this code applicable to the maintenance or renovation of
an antenna or tower shall be deemed applicable and in existence.



   (B)   The owner of a previously existing antenna tower shall be
entitled to grandfathered status only if the owner and/or lessee of the
antenna or tower shall file a declaration and claim of grandfathered status
on or before the expiration of six months from the date of adoption of this
chapter. Any person failing to timely claim grandfathered status shall be
required as a condition of the maintenance of an antenna or tower to obtain a
tower permit as herein required for a newly constructed antenna or tower.



(Prior Code, § 27-19)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.20  APPLICANT SHALL ACQUIRE NO VESTED RIGHTS.



   (A)   No applicant for a tower permit or person intending to apply
for a tower permit shall at any time acquire any vested rights to a tower
permit or other authority or privilege to maintain an antenna or tower in the
city limits. Nor shall any person who shall have previously constructed and
maintained an antenna or tower otherwise subject to regulation under this
chapter be deemed to have acquired any vested rights or property rights to
maintain the tower or antenna in the city.



   (B)   The city declares that the provisions of this chapter are
necessary for the preservation of the health, safety and well-being of the
residents, citizens and inhabitants of the city and as such the health,
safety and well-being of the residents, citizens and inhabitants of the city
require that this chapter and code be enforced to the maximum extent
permitted by law and that all rights of property shall at all times be
subordinate to the regulations as herein set out.



(Prior Code, § 27-20)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)



§ 95.21  REGULATIONS TO THE EXTRATERRITORIAL JURISDICTION.



   The City Council finds and determines that its regulation of antennas
and towers is important for the maintenance of the health, safety and
well-being of the residents, citizens and inhabitants of the city and, as
such, declares that the regulations contained in this chapter and code shall,
to the extent that may from time to time be permitted under the laws of the
state, be applicable to all towers and antennas that may be permitted and
constructed in the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city.



(Prior Code, § 27-21)  (Ord. 97-33, § 1, passed 10-28-1997)

CHAPTER 110:  BUSINESS LICENSING GENERALLY



Section



   110.01   Expiration of permits, licenses and authorities



§ 110.01  EXPIRATION OF PERMITS, LICENSES AND AUTHORITIES.



   (A)   All permits, licenses and authorities issued by the city on or
after February 1, 2000 shall expire on the date provided by other applicable
law for the issuance of a permit, license and authority if a date is
provided, or 180 days after the date of issuance of the permit, license and
authority if no date is otherwise provided.



   (B)   Any person previously having any right or authority under an
expired permit shall have the right at any time to seek renewal or reissuance
of the permit or authority.



(Ord. 2000-08, passed 2-22-2000)



CHAPTER 111:  PEDDLERS



Section



General Provisions



   111.01   Definitions



   111.02   Exceptions



   111.03   Right of property owners and tenants to specify “no
solicitation”



   111.04   Misrepresentation



   111.05   Hours of operation



   111.06   Prohibition



License



   111.17   License required



   111.18   Application

   111.27   Advertising restricted



   111.28   Suspension or revocation



 



   111.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 111.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   GOODS.  Tangible personal property, including but not limited to
newspapers and magazines, and subscriptions to tangible personal property.



   INTERSTATE COMMERCE. Soliciting, selling, or taking orders for, or
offering to take orders for, any goods which, at the time the order is taken,
are in any federal district or territory, any commonwealth, or in any state,
other than Texas, or will be produced in any federal district or territory,
any commonwealth, or any state, other than Texas, and shipped or introduced
into the city in fulfillment of such orders.



   NONCOMMERCIAL PURPOSE or CAUSE.  A purpose or cause not created,
existing or espoused for the generation of profit or the remuneration of
individuals, including, but not limited to, the religious or charitable
solicitation of contributions, seeking political support or contributions,
the promotion of civic causes, the promotion of conservation of resources or
animals, or advocating a philosophy or religion.



   PEDDLING.  Going from house to house or from place to place in the
city, whether by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck, or any other means of
conveyance, for the purpose of soliciting, selling or taking orders for or
offering to sell or take orders for any goods or services.  This definitions
shall also include the use or occupancy of any building, structure, tent,
table, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodging house, apartment, shop, or
any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples
and taking orders for future delivery.



   PREMISES.  Any residence, commercial business, home, or other place in
the city.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.02  EXCEPTIONS.



   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to sales made to dealers
by commercial travelers or sales agents in the usual course of business, or
to sales made under authority and by order of law, or to vendors of farm or
dairy products.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.03  RIGHT OF PROPERTY OWNERS AND TENANTS TO SPECIFY “NO
SOLICITATION.”



   (A)   Any property owner or tenant within the city may place or
affix on the front of any premises owned or rented by them a sign or other
identifying marker stating: “No Solicitation” or “No Solicitors.”



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon or to in any
way request entry upon any premises for the purpose of peddling, where a sign
or other identifying marker authorized by division (A) is placed or affixed.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.04  MISREPRESENTATION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the activity of peddling
to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality of his or her
goods, wares, merchandise, or services for the purpose of inducing another to
purchase the same.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.05  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the activity of
peddling by going from house to house or from place to place within the city
between the hours of one-half hour before sunset and one-half hour after
sunrise the following morning, except by specific appointment with or
invitation from the prospective customer.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.06  PROHIBITION.



   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, it shall be
unlawful for any person to engage in the activity of peddling to or from a
vehicle, cart, wagon, trailer or other means of conveyance, which is parked
or stopped upon a public street or right-of-way in the city.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



LICENSE



§ 111.17  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   Except as provided by division (B) of this section, it shall
be unlawful for any person or entity to engage in the activity of peddling
without having first applied for and obtained a license from the City
Secretary.



   (B)   No license or fee shall be required for any person or entity
to go from house to house or from place to place in the city solely for a
noncommercial purpose.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.18  APPLICATION.



   Any person or entity who is required by this chapter to obtain a
license from the City Secretary shall submit a written application to the
City Secretary, which application shall give the following information:



   (A)   Name, date of birth, home address and local address, if any,
of applicant;



   (B)   Name and address of the person, firm or corporation, if any,
that he or she represents, or from whom or through whom, orders are to be
solicited or cleared;



   (C)   Nature of the goods or services which are to be sold, or for
which orders are to be solicited;



   (D)   Whether applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand or
receive or accept payment or deposit of money, in advance of final delivery;



   (E)   A statement that the applicant has not been convicted of any
felonies of any nature or any other crimes of moral turpitude in this state
or any other state; or if having been so convicted, a full statement as to
the place of conviction, date of conviction and crime for which applicant was
convicted;



   (F)   Period of time which applicant wishes to engage in the
activity of peddling in the city; and



   (G)   Any other information requested by the city.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.19  IDENTIFICATION.



   A the time of filing an application for a license, the applicant shall
submit, for inspection by the City Secretary, written proof of his or her
identity, which may be in the form of an automobile operator’s license or
an identification letter or card issued to registrant or applicant by the
person, firm or corporation for whom or through whom orders are to be
solicited or cleared.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.20  FALSE INFORMATION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false or misleading
information in connection with his or her application for a license required
by this chapter.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.21  SERVICE OF PROCESS.



   At the time of filing an application for a license required by this
chapter and before any license shall be issued under this chapter, there
shall also be filed with the City Secretary an instrument in writing, signed
by the applicant under oath, nominating and appointing the Secretary of State
of the State of Texas as his or her true and lawful agent, with full power
and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and one the
behalf of the applicant, and service of summons in any action brought upon
the applicant’s bond shall be deemed made when served on the Secretary of
State of the State of Texas.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.22  BOND.



   (A)   The applicant for a license required by this chapter shall pay
a bond as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees.  The bond shall
be signed by the applicant and signed as surety by a surety company
authorized to do business in the state, conditioned for the final delivery of
goods or performance of services in accordance with the terms of an order
obtained prior to delivery or performance, and also conditioned to indemnify
any and all purchases or customers from any and all defects in material or
workmanship that may exist in any goods or services sold by the principal of
that bond, at the time of delivery or performance, and that may be discovered
by the purchaser or customer within 30 days after delivery or performance,
and which bond shall be for the use and benefit of all persons or entities
that may make any purchase or give any order to the principal on the bond,
either directly or indirectly.



   (B)   In the event one bond, bond form, or one surety company shall
be the surety for a number of applicants, then the bond, bond form, or
undertaking shall clearly set out that the liability of the surety is for
each applicant making application.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.23  FEE.



   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in this section, any person or
entity required to obtain a license under this chapter shall pay a fee as set
forth by City Council in a schedule of fees; provided, however, when any
person or entity engages the activity of peddling through one or more agents
or employees, the person shall, in addition to the fee above-mentioned, pay a
license fee as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees for each agent
or employee so engaged.  The fees herein required shall be used for the
purpose of defraying expenses incident to the issuance of the licenses. 
However, nothing herein contained shall be construed or shall in any way
waive the requirement of each applicant to adhere to any other provisions of
this chapter.



   (B)   A person or entity is exempt from the fee provided for by this
section if the person or entity is engaged in the activity of peddling which
is:



      (1)   Solely interstate commerce; or



      (2)   Solely for the exclusive benefit of a nonprofit
corporation, nonprofit association, or other  nonprofit entity that has a
valid designation by the federal government, provided that evidence of the
nonprofit status of such corporation, association, or entity is submitted
with the person or entity’s license application.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.24  PROCEDURES FOR ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.



   (A)   Within five business days after receipt of an application by
the City Secretary, any person may file written objections with the Mayor,
stating in full the grounds for objection to the issuance of a license.



   (B)   The Mayor shall investigate the objections, if any, and shall
also investigate the application of the applicant and shall, within five
business days, either approve or disapprove the application for a license. 
The Mayor shall take into consideration in making this determination the
health, safety, and well-being of the citizens, and such other facts as shall
properly come to his or her attention.



   (C)   In the event the Mayor shall approve or disapprove the
issuance of a license, then, within ten business days after the date of the
decision of the Mayor, any party aggrieved thereby shall have the right to
appeal the same to the City Council, by giving notice of the appeal in
writing to the City Secretary.  The City Secretary shall, upon receipt of
the notice, place the appeal on the agenda for the next regular meeting of
the City Council.



   (D)   The City Council shall hear such testimony and examine such
facts and evidence as to the issuance of the license and shall approve or
disapprove the issuance, taking into consideration the health, safety, and
well-being of the citizen of the city, and such other matters as shall
properly come to their attention.  The decision of the City Council shall be
final as to all matters determined herein and shall not be appealable.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.25  DURATION.



   Every license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be
valid for a period not to exceed three months from the date of its issuance.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.26  DISPLAY.



   Any person or entity having a license and engaging in the activity of
peddling within the city shall display his or her license upon the request of
any person.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.27  ADVERTISING RESTRICTED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person or entity holding a license granted
under this chapter to advertise in any manner whatsoever, other than by
display upon request as provided by § 111.26, that the person is the holder
of the license, or to claim in any manner that such license is an endorsement
by the city.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.28  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.



   (A)   Any person who shall violate the laws of the United States of
America, the state, or the city, or any of the terms or provisions of this
chapter shall be subject to suspension or revocation of any license.  Upon a
written complaint of such violations being filed by any person with the City
Secretary, a hearing shall be held, within 15 days from the date of the
receipt of the compliant, before the Mayor to hear all evidence with
reference to the complaint.  The Mayor shall, within ten days of the date of
the conclusion of the hearing, enter an order, in writing, dismissing the
complaint, suspending the license, or revoking the license.



   (B)   In the event that the Mayor shall either suspend or revoke any
license, the holder of the license may, upon giving written notice within ten
days of the date of the order entered by the Mayor, have the right of appeal
to the City Council.  The City Council shall hear all evidence and shall
either sustain or reverse the decision made by the Mayor.  If no appeal is
taken from the action of the Mayor within ten days, as set out herein, then
the decision of the Mayor shall be final and binding.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



§ 111.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates or causes, allows, or permit another to violate
any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500
or, in the case of a violation of a provision of this chapter that governs
fire safety, zoning, or public health and sanitation, including dumping of
refuse, a fine of not more than $2,000.  Each occurrence of any such
violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.  Each day on
which any such violation of this chapter occurs shall constitute a separate
offense.



(Ord. 2014-09(B), passed 6-24-2014)



CHAPTER 112:  SALES



Section



Garage Sales



   112.01   Defined



   112.02   Duration, frequency



   112.03   Permit suspension or revocation



GARAGE SALES



§ 112.01  DEFINED.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   GARAGE SALE.  The offering for sale of 20 or more items of used
personal property from a residence, and shall include "patio sales," "porch
sales" and "driveway sales."



(Prior Code, § 15-1)  (Ord. 84-047, § 1, passed 6-12-1984)



§ 112.02  DURATION, FREQUENCY.



   No garage sale shall be held at any single location for a period of
more than two successive days, nor more than four times on specific
designated weekends in the calendar year. For the purposes of this section,
WEEKEND means Friday and Saturday. The specific designated weekends are the
second weekend in the calendar months of February, May, August and November
of each year.



(Prior Code, § 15-3)  (Ord. 84-047, § 1, passed 6-12-1984; Ord. 2003-13,
passed 5-27-2003; Ord. 2006-40, passed 12-19-2006; Ord. 2010-06, passed
3-23-2010)



§ 112.03  PERMIT SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.



   (A)   Any person who shall violate the laws of the United States of
America, the state or of the city, or any of the terms or provisions of this
chapter, shall be subject to suspension or revocation of any license, permit
or authority of any nature whatsoever granted under the terms or provisions
of this chapter. Upon a written complaint of such violations being filed by
any person with the City Secretary, the Mayor shall have the right to
immediately suspend any license, permit or authority granted hereunder,
pending a hearing to be held by the Mayor within 15 days of the date of
receipt of the  complaint, at which hearing the Mayor shall hear all
evidence with reference to the complaint. The Mayor shall, within ten days of
the date of the conclusion of the hearing, enter an order, in writing, either
dismissing the complaint or suspending or revoking the license, permit or
such other authority as granted hereunder.



   (B)   In the event that the Mayor shall either suspend or revoke any
license, permit or other authority of any nature granted hereunder, the
holder of the permit, license or authority may, upon giving written notice
within ten days of the date of the order entered by the Mayor, have the right
of appeal to the City Council. The City Council shall hear all evidence and
shall either sustain or reverse the suspension and/or revocation made by the
Mayor. If no appeal is taken from the action of the Mayor within ten days, as
set out herein, then the decision of the Mayor shall, in all things, be final
and binding.



(Prior Code, § 15-4)  (Ord. 84-047, § 1, passed 6-12-1984)

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 113.01  SCOPE.



   The terms and provisions of this chapter shall apply to the operation
of entertainment and/or amusement facilities in the city.



(Prior Code, § 5-1)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.02  DUTY OF OWNER.



   Either the owner or a responsible employee formally designated by the
owner under the provisions of this chapter shall be in attendance on the
premises of the business or facility during all hours of operation; and it
shall be the duty of the owner at all times to maintain on file with the City
Secretary a current written designation of the responsible employee or
employees together with the employee affidavit(s) hereinafter required.



(Prior Code, § 5-2)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



LICENSES AND PERMITS



§ 113.15  LICENSES AND PERMITS; GENERALLY.



   It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to perform any work or
engage in any activity which requires a license or permit under the terms and
provisions of this chapter, as hereinafter set out, without having first
obtained the license or permit from the city. Only a person who complies with
the requirements of this chapter shall be entitled to receive and/or to
retain such a license or permit. Licenses and permits issued under the terms
and provisions of this chapter are not transferrable, nor shall they be
subject to assignment or conveyance; and upon the attempted transfer,
assignment or conveyance, the same shall become immediately void. The
licenses and permits shall be posted at the places of business for which the
same are issued as hereinafter specified.



(Prior Code, § 5-11)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 113.16  APPLICATION.



   (A)   Any person or entity desiring to perform any work or engage in
any activity covered under the terms and provisions of this chapter, for
which a license or permit is required as hereinafter set out, shall, prior to
the opening or operation of the business or facility, file written
application with the City Secretary for the license or permit, which
application shall contain the following information:



      (1)   Either:



         (a)   The name, home address and principal business
address of each owner of the business or enterprise seeking the license or
permit hereunder, if the business or enterprise be unincorporated; or



         (b)   If the business or enterprise be incorporated, the
name, home address and principal business address of each and every officer
and director thereof, including a statement of the office or position held by
each.



      (2)   A statement as to the specific type of business or
entertainment and amusement facility for which the license or permit is
sought;



      (3)   The address and location within the city at which the
business or entertainment and amusement facility is to be operated;



      (4)   A statement that the applicant, including each and every
owner and/or each and every officer and director of an owner corporation, if
any, has not been convicted of any felonies of any nature or any other crimes
of moral turpitude in this state or any other state; and if having been so
convicted, a full statement as to the place of conviction, date of conviction
and crime for which applicant was convicted; and



      (5)   Any further information as may be required under the
terms and provisions of this chapter for the type of business or
entertainment and amusement facility specified.



   (B)   The application shall be accompanied by an affidavit in a form
as hereinafter set out, signed by the individual applicant, or in the event
of a partnership by one of the partners thereof, or in the event of a
corporation by an officer of the corporation, verifying and affirming the
information set out in the application as being true and correct and, in the
event of ownership other than by an individual owner, attesting that the
person signing the application and affidavit is a bona fide representative of
the partnership or corporation. The form to be used is as follows:



   STATE OF TEXAS



   COUNTY OF FORT BEND



   BEFORE ME, the undersigned authority, a Notary Public, on this day
personally appeared the undersigned Affiant, who after being by me first duly
sworn, on his or her oath deposed and said:



"My name is___________________________________________.



I am____________________________________________ (here, state Affiant is
doing business individually, is a partner in a partnership or is an officer
in a corporation).  I state that I have read the application to which this
Affidavit is attached, and I have personally reviewed the information therein
provided, and I state that such information is true and correct.



   (For a partnership or corporation, add:)



"I further state that I am ___________________________(here, state Affiant is
a partner in a partnership or an officer in a corporation), the applicant
herein, and that I am authorized to execute this Affidavit as a
representative of the applicant."



                        _____________________________



                        Affiant



   SWORN TO AND SUBSCRIBED TO before me this, the day of________,
20________.



                        ______________________________



                        Notary Public in and for



                        Fort Bend County, Texas



   (C)   The application shall be accompanied by the owner's written
designation of the responsible employee or employees who shall be in
attendance on the premises of the business or facility during all hours of
operation. The application shall further be accompanied by an affidavit of
each such designated responsible employee, signed by the employee and
containing the following information:



      (1)   The full name and home address of the employee; and



      (2)   A statement that the employee has not been convicted of
any felonies of any nature or any other crimes of moral turpitude in this
state or any other state; and if having been so convicted, a full statement
as to the place of conviction, date of conviction and crime for which the
employee was convicted.



   (D)   At the time of filing of the application, it shall be the duty
of the applicant to secure and place on file with the City Police Department,
in the form and manner as shall be prescribed by the Chief of Police of the
city, the fingerprints of the owner or owners, if a proprietorship or
partnership, or if a corporation, of the officer(s) and/or director(s) having
direct responsibility for the operation of the business or facility, and of
any responsible employee or employees designated hereunder.



   (E)   The application shall be accompanied by a certificate
verifying insurance coverage as follows:



      (1)   Worker's compensation insurance on each and every one of
applicant's employees, such insurance being in accordance with the provisions
of the Worker's Compensation Act of the state;



      (2)   Public liability insurance to the extent of $300,000 per
occurrence and $500,000 in the aggregate;



      (3)   Property damage insurance to the extent of $300,000 per
occurrence and $500,000 in the aggregate.



   (F)   The application shall further be accompanied by the license or
permit fee hereinafter prescribed for the specific license or permit sought,
which fee shall be returned only upon denial of the license or permit.



(Prior Code, § 5-12)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.17  PROCEDURE FOR ISSUANCE.



   (A)   Within 20 days after filing of an application herein, any
person having knowledge bearing upon the application, relating to statements
made in the application or the applicant's compliance with the code of
ordinances, may file with the Mayor written objections to the issuance of a
license or permit, stating the grounds for the objections and a full
explanation therefor.



   (B)   The Mayor shall investigate such objections and the
application and shall, within 30 days after filing of the application, either
approve or disapprove the application for a license or permit. In making the
decision, the Mayor shall take into consideration the health, safety and
well-being of the citizens and such other facts as shall properly come to his
or her attention. The City Secretary shall mail written notice of the Mayor's
decision to the applicant.



   (C)   In the event the Mayor shall deny the license or permit
sought, then the applicant shall have the right to appeal the decision to the
City Council by filing written notice of the appeal with the City Secretary
within 15 days of the mailing of written notice of the Mayor's decision. Upon
receipt of the notice of appeal, the City Secretary shall place the same on
the agenda of the City Council for the next regular meeting of the City
Council.



   (D)   At that regular meeting, the City Council shall hear all
testimony and examine all facts and evidence as to the issuance of the
license or permit; and as soon as practicable after the completion of the
hearing, the City Council shall either approve or disapprove the issuance,
taking into consideration the health, safety and well-being of the citizens
of the city and such other matters as shall properly come before Council. The
decision of the City Council shall be final as to all matters determined
herein and shall not be appealable. The City Secretary shall mail written
notice of the City Council decision to the applicant.



(Prior Code, § 5-13)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.18  RECORD.



   The City Secretary shall keep a permanent record of all licenses and
permits issued under this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-14)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.19  FALSE INFORMATION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false or misleading
information in connection with his or her application for a license or permit
required by this chapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-15)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 113.20  CURRENT INFORMATION.



   In the event of any change, at any time, in the information provided in
the application filed under the terms and provisions of this chapter, or
simultaneously therewith, including but not limited to changes in home
addresses and principal business addresses or changes in the names and
addresses of the officers and directors of a corporation, it shall be the
duty of the licensee or permittee, prior to the effective date of this change
in information, to file with the City Secretary an affidavit providing the
new information and setting out the effective date thereof. It shall further
be the duty of the licensee or permittee to maintain on file with the Police
Department the fingerprints of all individuals whose fingerprints are
required under § 113.16.



(Prior Code, § 5-16)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.21  CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP.



   In the event of the sale, transfer or assignment of a business or
entertainment and amusement facility holding a license or permit under the
terms and provisions of this chapter, resulting in a change in ownership of a
proprietorship or a change in the identity of partners in a partnership or a
change in ownership of more than one-third of the outstanding shares in a
corporation, then, prior to the effective date of the change in ownership and
operation of the business or facility by the new owner, the new owner shall
make application for a license or permit as herein required and shall not
operate the business or facility until the license or permit shall have been
issued.



(Prior Code, § 5-17)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.22  DURATION.



   Unless otherwise specified, each and every license and permit issued
under the terms and provisions of this chapter shall be valid from the date
of issuance until January 1 following the date of issuance. Annual license
and permit fees specified in this chapter shall be prorated based upon the
number of months during which the business or facility will be in operation
prior to the expiration of the license or permit on January 1.



(Prior Code, § 5-18)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.23  RENEWAL.



   Any licensee or permittee desiring to renew a license or permit issued
under the terms and provisions of this chapter shall, on or before December 1
immediately preceding the January 1 expiration of the license or permit, file
an application with the City Secretary for renewal of the same. The
application shall be accompanied by the license or permit fee prescribed for
the specific license or permit sought.



(Prior Code, § 5-19)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.24  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION.



   (A)   Any person who shall violate the laws of the United States of
America, the state or the city, or any of the terms or provisions of this
chapter shall be subject to suspension or revocation of any license, permit
or authority of any nature whatsoever granted under the terms and provisions
of this chapter.



   (B)   Upon receipt of a written complaint of such violations, filed
by any person including any employee of the city, the City Secretary shall
provide the licensee or permittee with a copy of the complaint and written
notice of the date and time of a hearing to be conducted by the Mayor. The
hearing shall be held not less than 15 days from the date of mailing of
written notice thereof to the licensee or permittee.



   (C)   At the date and time specified for hearing, the Mayor shall
hear all evidence relating to the complaint. Within ten days of the
conclusion of the hearing, the Mayor shall enter an order, in writing, either
dismissing the complaint or suspending or revoking the license, permit or
such other authority as granted hereunder. The City Secretary shall mail a
copy of the Mayor's order to the licensee or permittee.



   (D)   In the event that the Mayor shall either suspend or revoke any
license, permit or other authority of any nature granted hereunder, then the
holder of the license, permit or authority shall have the right to appeal the
decision to the City Council by filing written notice of the appeal with the
City Secretary within 15 days of the mailing of written notice of the Mayor's
decision. Upon receipt of notice of appeal, the City Secretary shall place
the same on the agenda of the City Council for the next regular meeting of
the City Council.



   (E)   At that regular meeting, the City Council shall hear all
testimony and examine all facts and evidence; and as soon as practicable
after the completion of the hearing, the City Council shall either sustain or
reverse the suspension or revocation order of the Mayor. The decision of the
City Council shall be final as to all matters determined herein and shall not
be appealable. The City Secretary shall mail written notice of the City
Council's decision to the licensee or permittee.



   (F)   If no appeal is taken from the action of the Mayor within 15
days, as set out herein, then the decision of the Mayor shall, in all things,
be final and binding.



(Prior Code, § 5-20)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.25  APPLICATION AFTER REVOCATION.



   Whenever a revocation of a license or permit has become final, the
holder of the revoked license or permit may make written application for a
new license or permit.



(Prior Code, § 5-21)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



REGULATION OF AMUSEMENT RIDES



§ 113.35  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, operate,
manage or sponsor any Ferris wheel, merry-go-round or other amusement ride
operated for hire or for the purpose of promoting or advertising any trade or
business within the city without first obtaining a permit therefor pursuant
to the procedures specified in §§ 113.15 through 113.25.



   (B)   Upon application therefor, a permit may be issued hereunder if
the use is deemed to be in accordance with the land use ordinances then in
effect in the city. However, the city shall not be required to make any
inspection or determination of the safety of the rides or equipment covered
by the permit; and by issuance of the permit, the city assumes no liability
or responsibility for the safety of the rides. Therefore, no permit fee shall
be charged herein. Any permit issued shall state on the face thereof, in
clear, large and conspicuous type, as follows: "THE CITY OF MEADOWS PLACE,
TEXAS ASSUMES NO RESPONSIBILITY OR OBLIGATION FOR MAINTENANCE, OPERATION OR
PERFORMANCE OF THE RIDES OR EQUIPMENT COVERED BY THIS PERMIT."



(Prior Code, § 5-41)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 113.36  POSTING OF PERMIT.



   It shall be the duty of the permittee to post the required permit for
operation of amusement rides at a conspicuous location upon the site of the
operation of the rides in such a manner that the same can be easily read by
any member of the public coming upon the site. The permit shall remain posted
continuously during the term of the permit.



(Prior Code, § 5-42)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



REGULATION OF COIN-OPERATED MACHINES



§ 113.45  SCOPE OF SUBCHAPTER.



   Except as hereinafter provided in §§ 113.47, 113.48 and 113.52, this
subchapter shall be deemed applicable to any house, place of business, place
of amusement or other place wherein there are maintained four or more
coin-operated amusement machines or skill or pleasure coin-operated machines,
which shall include every coin-operated amusement machine of any kind or
character whatsoever, when the machine dispenses or is used or capable of
being used or operated for amusement or pleasure, or where the machine is
operated for the purpose of dispensing or affording skill or pleasure. The
following classes and types of machines are specifically exempted from
coverage under this subchapter: gas meters, pay telephones, food vending
machines, confection vending machines, beverage vending machines, merchandise
vending machines, cigarette vending machines, stamp vending machines and
service coin-operated machines including coin-operated computers which are
used for purposes other than amusement.



(Prior Code, § 5-51)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



Statutory reference:



   Coin-operated services, see Tex. Occup. Code Ch. 4153



§ 113.46  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager, employee, representative
of the owner, lessee or any person who may be in charge and having care and
management of any place of business covered by this subchapter to open,
operate or conduct the same without having first obtained a license therefor
from the city. In addition to the licensing requirements specified in §§
113.15 through 113.25, an applicant for a license hereunder shall provide
proof of payment of the annual occupation tax for each machine as hereinafter
required.



(Prior Code, § 5-52)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 113.47  LICENSE FEE.



   (A)   A business covered by the terms and provisions of this
subchapter shall pay an annual license fee as set forth by City Council in a
schedule of fees.



   (B)   Exception:  Any bona fide charitable organization desiring to
make use of coin-operated amusement machines or skill or pleasure
coin-operated machines, for charitable purposes, on a temporary basis, shall,
upon proof of its status as a charitable organization and of the charitable
purposes contemplated herein by filing of an affidavit with the City
Secretary, in a form which shall be prescribed by the city, be exempt from
the payment of the license fee herein required.



(Prior Code, § 5-53)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984; Am. Ord.
2012-20, passed 6-26-2012)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.48  OCCUPATION TAX.



   (A)   Notwithstanding the provisions of § 113.45 as to the scope of
coverage of this subchapter, every owner who owns, controls, possesses,
exhibits, displays or who permits to be exhibited or displayed in the city,
any coin-operated amusement machines or skill or pleasure coin-operated
machines, shall pay on every such machine, except as hereinafter set out, an
annual occupation tax in the maximum amount allowed by state law. The
occupation tax shall be payable to the city:



      (1)   When no license is required, prior to commencement of
the initial use of each machine and, thereafter, prior to December 1 of each
year of continuing use;



      (2)   When a license is required, prior to or simultaneously
with the filing of an application for the issuance of a license hereunder; or



      (3)   In the case of a license renewal, prior to or
simultaneously with the filing of an application for renewal, on or before
December 1 immediately preceding the January 1 expiration of the license.



   (B)   The occupation tax shall be prorated based upon the number of
months during which the machines will be in operation prior to January 1
immediately following payment of the tax.



   (C)   Exceptions.



      (1)   Any bona fide charitable organization desiring to make
use of coin-operated amusement machines or skill or pleasure coin-operated
machines, for charitable purposes, on a temporary basis, shall, upon proof of
its status as a charitable organization and of the charitable purposes
contemplated herein by filing of an affidavit with the City Secretary, in a
form which shall be prescribed by the city, be exempt from the payment of the
occupation tax herein required.



      (2)   Any amusement machine removed from the premises for
temporary repair or maintenance may be temporarily replaced for a period not
exceeding 30 days without payment of an additional occupation tax.



(Prior Code, § 5-54)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984; Ord. 84-073,
§ 1, passed 11-8-1984; Ord. 86-11, § 1, passed 4-7-1986)



§ 113.49  POSTING OF LICENSE AND CERTIFICATE OF PAYMENT.



   (A)   Any license issued under the terms and provisions of this
subchapter shall be posted at a conspicuous location at the place of business
or facility wherein the subject coin-operated machines are in use, in such a
manner that the same can be easily read by any member of the public coming
upon the premises. The license shall remain posted continuously during the
term of the license.



   (B)   For each machine upon which the required occupation tax has
been paid, or which has been herein expressly exempt from the payment of the
occupation tax, the City Secretary shall issue a certificate evidencing
payment or exemption; and the certificate shall be securely attached to the
machine in a manner that will require continued application of steam and
water to remove the same, or the certificate shall be posted in a conspicuous
place at or near the machine so as to be easily seen by the public. The
certificate affixed to the machine shall be valid only for the particular
machine which must be identified by serial number, and it shall be unlawful
to move the machine to a different location or place of business within the
city without prior written notification to the city.



   (C)   Any person who shall fail to post a license as required by
this section or who shall exhibit, display or have in his or her possession
within the city, any coin-operated amusement machine or skill or pleasure
coin-operated machine, without having annexed or attached thereto a valid
certificate issued by the city showing payment of the tax due thereon for the
current year or exemption therefrom, shall be deemed to have violated this
subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-55)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 113.50  SEALING MACHINE FOR NONPAYMENT.



   (A)   The Mayor or his or her designee may seal, in a manner that
will prevent further operation, any coin-operated amusement machine or skill
or pleasure coin-operated machine subject to the payment of the occupation
tax upon which the tax levied by this subchapter has not been paid. Any
person subject to this section shall be required to pay a fee as set forth by
City Council in a schedule of fees for release of any machine sealed under
this section for nonpayment of the tax.



   (B)   Whoever shall break the seal, pursuant to this subchapter, or
exhibit, display or remove any machine on which the seal has been broken,
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be in violation of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-56)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984; Am. Ord.
2012-20, passed 6-26-2012)  Penalty, see § 113.99



§ 113.51  POLICE PROTECTION.



   Whenever more than 25 persons are present in any area or room where
four or more coin-operated amusement machines or skill or pleasure
coin-operated machines are kept, a certified, uniformed peace officer, who
shall be compensated by the owner of the place of business, shall be on duty
on the premises of any place of business, covered under this subchapter. No
more than 25 persons may be admitted to the area or room where four or more
coin-operated amusement machines or skill or pleasure coin-operated machines
are kept unless a certified, uniformed peace officer is on duty.



(Prior Code, § 5-57)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984; Ord. 86-14, §
1, passed 4-22-1986)



§ 113.52  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   (A)   Any place of business deemed covered by this subchapter shall
be permitted to be open for business from 10:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. Sunday,
Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, from 10:00 a.m. Friday until 1:00
a.m. Saturday, and from 10:00 a.m. Saturday until 1:00 a.m. Sunday of each
calendar week.



   (B)   Exception: Any house, place of business, place of amusement or
other place which shall otherwise be covered under this subchapter shall not
be deemed covered or subject to the hours of operation specified in this
section if the place of business, place of amusement or other place shall be
equipped with partitions, doors or other method of closure which would allow
the closing of that portion of the place of business wherein four or more
coin-operated amusement machines or skill or pleasure coin-operated machines
are maintained, and the portion of the place of business is in fact closed
daily in compliance with this section.



(Prior Code, § 5-58)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.53  PROHIBITING INTOXICATING LIQUIDS OR CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES.



   Neither intoxicating liquids, other than beer and wine, not any type of
controlled substances may be sold, consumed or possessed on the premises of
any place of business covered under this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-59)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 113.54  DOORS AND OPENINGS; UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW.



   (A)   Any place of business deemed covered by this subchapter shall
provide, from the normal point or points of entry into the place of business,
an unobstructed view of the entire public area wherein there are located four
or more coin-operated amusement machines or skill or pleasure coin-operated
machines.



   (B)   Doors and openings in partitions within the public area of any
place of business covered under this subchapter shall not be less than 50
square feet. At all times when any place of business covered under this
subchapter shall be open for business as provided herein, all such doors and
openings in partitions within the public area shall be unobstructed by doors,
curtains, gates or other obstructions.



   (C)   All partitions shall be constructed of a noncombustible
material of a one-hour fire rated assembly.



(Prior Code, § 5-60)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.55  AMPLIFIED SOUND.



   No sound of any nature may be amplified or otherwise be audible beyond
the property limits of a place of business covered under this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-61)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)  Penalty, see
§ 10.99



§ 113.56  LIGHTING.



   Lighting shall be maintained at an intensity of not less than 30
foot-candle power, three feet from the floor, measured at any location in any
room open to the public, which shall be operative during all hours of
operation of any place of business covered under this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 5-62)  (Ord. 84-072, § 1, passed 10-23-1984)



§ 113.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates or cause, allows or permit another to violated
any provision of §§ 113.47 or 113.50 shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not
more than $500.  Each occurrence of any such violation of §§ 113.47 or
113.50 shall constitute a separate offense.  Each day on which any such
violation of §§ 113.47 or 113.50 occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 2012-20, passed 6-26-2012)



CHAPTER 114:  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES



Section



   114.01   Definitions



   114.02   Permit required



   114.03   Permit application



   114.04   Fee required, exceptions



   114.05   Renewal required



   114.06   Late hours permit



 



   114.99   Penalty



§ 114.01  DEFINITIONS.



   The words in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed by Tex.
Alcoholic Beverage Code, § 1.04. except where the context clearly indicates
a different meaning.



(Ord. 2015-12, passed 4-28-2015)



§ 114.02  PERMIT REQUIRED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, distill, brew,
sell, possess, for the purpose of sale, import, export, transport,
distribute, warehouse, store, solicit or take orders or for the purpose of
sale, bottle, rectify, blend, treat, fortify, mix, or process beer, wine, or
any other alcoholic beverage or engage in any other activity for which a
state permit or license is required under Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code until
the city issues a permit or renews a permit for such allowable activity
within the city.



(Ord. 2015-12, passed 4-28-2015)



§ 114.03  PERMIT APPLICATION.



   A person who is required to receive a permit from the city under this
chapter shall complete and submit to the city and alcohol permit application
form as provided by the city. Each alcohol permit application submitted to
the city shall include a copy of a valid state permit or license as required
by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code.



(Ord. 2015-12, passed 4-28-2015)



§ 114.04  FEE REQUIRED, EXCEPTIONS.



   (A)   If the city approved an alcohol permit application, the city
shall issue a permit to the applicant after the applicant pays to the city a
fee not to exceed one-half the state fee for each permit issued for premises
located within the city as permitted pursuant to the provisions of Tex.
Alcoholic Beverage Code, §§ 11.38 and 61.36. The city hereby levies and is
authorized to collect such fee.



   (B)   The following are exempt from the fee authorized by division
(A) of this section, but are not exempt from completing and submitting an
alcohol permit application to the city and receiving a permit from the city;



      (1)   Agent’s, airline beverage, passenger train beverage,
industrial, carrier’s, private carrier’s, private club registration,
local cartage, storage, and temporary wine and beer retailer’s permits;



      (2)   A wine and beer retailer’s permit issued for a dining,
buffet, or club car;



      (3)   A mixed beverage permit during the three-year period
following the issuance of the permit;



      (4)   Temporary beer license; and



      (5)   Agent’s beer license.



   (C)   After the third-year period following the issuance of a mixed
beverage permit, such permit holder shall complete and submit to the city an
alcohol permit application form as provided by the city. Each alcohol permit
application submitted to the city shall include a copy of a valid state
permit or license as required by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code. If the city
approves an alcohol permit application, the city shall issue a permit to the
applicant after the applicant pays to the city a fee not toe exceed one-half
the state fee for each permit issued for premises located within the city as
permitted pursuant to the provisions of Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code.



(Ord. 2015-12, passed 4-28-2015)



§ 114.05  RENEWAL REQUIRED.



   (A)   Permits issued under this chapter shall be renewed with the
city no later than the fifteenth day after the date a state permit or license
is renewed. Renewal permits require the completion  and submission to the
city of an alcohol permit application. If the city approves an alcohol permit
application, the city shall issue a renewal permit to the applicant after the
applicant pays to the city a fee not to exceed one-half the state fee for
each permit issued for premises located within the city.



   (B)   If a state permit or license ir expired, revoked, or
terminated, then the city’s permit is automatically expired, revoke, or
terminated.



(Ord. 2015-12, passed 4-28-2015)



§ 114.06  LATE HOURS PERMIT.



   The sale of beer and mixed beverages in the city is hereby authorized
between 7:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. on any day except Sunday and, on Sunday,
between 12:00 midnight and 2:00 a.m. and between noon and midnight, provided
that the seller of the same shall hold a mixed beverage late hours permit
and/or a retail dealer’s on-premises late hours license for the sale of
beer as required by Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code.



(Ord. 2015-12, passed 4-28-2015)



§ 114.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another to violate
any provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500
unless such violation is governed by fire safety, zoning, or public health
and sanitation including dumping of refuse in which case the fine amount
shall not be more than $2,000, except where state law provides otherwise, in
which case the range of fine shall be as provided by in such state law. Each
occurrence of any such violation of this section shall constitute a separate
offense.



(Ord. 2015-12, passed 4-28-2015)



CHAPTER 115:  FOOD SERVICE
