GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 115.01  STATE RULES ON FOOD SERVICE SANITATION ADOPTED.



   (A) City of Meadows Place, Texas, ("city") adopts the 2015 Edition of
the Texas Food Establishment Rules (TFER) as published by the Texas
Department of State Health Services, Division for Regulatory Services,
Environmental and Consumer Safety Section, Policy, Standards, and Quality
Assurance Unit, Public Sanitation and Retail Food Safety Group, a copy of
which has been filed with the city, save and except those section(s) amended
in § 115.02. The words REGULATORY AUTHORITY shall mean the City of Meadows
Place. If any provision of this chapter conflicts with the rules and
regulations contained in the TFER, the more stringent provision shall control.



   (B)   A copy of the 2015 Texas Food Establishment Rules shall be
maintained by the cty. If a provision of said code is found to be in conflict
with a provision of any zoning, building, fire, safety, or health ordinance
or any regulation adopted pursuant thereto or any other ordinance or code or
regulation of the cty, the provision which establishes the higher standard
for the promotion of health and safety shall control.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014; Ord. 2018-29, passed 9-25-2018)



§ 115.02  AMENDMENTS TO STATE RULES ON FOOD SERVICE SANITATION.



    The Texas Food Establishment Rules adopted in § 115.01 are amended as
follows:



   228.2  Definitions. The following definitions apply in the
interpretation and application of this Code:



      (57)   Food Establishment -



         (D)   food establishment does not include an
establishment that offers only prepackaged foods that are not time or
temperature controlled for safety food, a produce stand that only offers
whole, uncut fruits and vegetables, a food processing plant, a cottage food
industry, an area where cottage food is prepared, sold or offered for human
consumption, a Bed and Breakfast Limited facility as defined in these rules,
or a private home that receives catered or home-delivered food.



         (E)   Includes a food processing plant, a child care
center (daycare), or a warehouse holding and/or distributing food, whether
for TCS food or non-TCS food.



      (143)   Temporary Food Establishment. A food establishment
that operates for a period of no more than 14 consecutive days in conjunction
with a single event or celebration. A farmer's market is defined as a
temporary food service establishment, but may operate for one year with a
valid permit.



   228.221  Mobile Food Units.



         (a)   Mobile Food Unit provisions.



            (2)   Restricted Operation. Mobile Food Units will
be permitted only on public or private property in conjunction with a
temporary event. The operator of said Mobile Food Unit must first i) obtain a
Temporary Food Establishment Permit from the regulatory authority, and ii)
obtain written permission from the property owner or lawful tenant for
placement of the Mobile Food Unit on said property, Mobile Food Units that
serve only food that is prepared, packaged in individual servings,
transported and stored under conditions meeting the requirements of this
Chapter, or beverages that are non-time/temperature controlled for safety
(NTCS) food and are dispensed from covered urns or other protected equipment,
need not comply with the requirements of these rules pertaining to the
necessity of water and sewage system nor to those requirements pertaining to
the cleaning and sanitization of equipment and utensils of the required
equipment for cleaning and sanitization exists at its central preparation
facility.



            (4)   Initial permitting requirements. The mobile
unit must be totally operable at time of inspection, including but not
limited to handwash/warewash facilities, refrigeration and wastewater
disposal. The regulatory authority shall require a Mobile Food Unit to
provide the following documentation at least 15 days prior to the event:



               (A)   Certified Food Manager Certification.



               (B)   Central Preparation Facility
Authorization (if required). A signed letter of authorization is required. to
verify facility use. if the Central Preparation Facility is not owned by the
mobile unit operator.



               (C)   Central Preparation Facility
Inspection Report. A copy of the most current health inspection of the
central preparation facility must be maintained on the mobile unit at all
times.



               (D)   Servicing Area Authorization. A signed
letter of authorization may be required by the regulatory authority to verify
service area use. if the servicing area is not owned by the mobile unit
operator.



               (E)   Menu of all food items to be sold.



               (F)   A floor plan of the mobile unit
showing all of the internal and external equipment that has been added to the
vehicle for the purpose of Mobile Vending submitted as a part of the
temporary food permit submittal.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014; Ord. 2018-29, passed 9-25-2018)



§ 115.03  RESPONSIBILITY FOR ENFORCEMENT.



   The Health Official of the city shall be charged with the
responsibility for enforcement of the rules and regulations of this chapter.
The Health Official may be an employee of the city or an independent
contractor.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



APPLICATION AND PERMIT



§ 115.15  APPLICATION AND PERMIT FOR FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT OR
TEMPORARY FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT.



   (A)   To operate a food service establishment or a temporary food
service establishment, a person or entity shall first complete and submit to
the city a food service establishment or temporary food service establishment
application and pay a permit fee as set forth by City Council in a schedule
of fees.



   (B)   The food service establishment and temporary food service
establishment application shall contain the following information:



      (1)   Either:



         (a)   The name, home address and principal business
address of each owner of the food service establishment or temporary food
service establishment; or



         (b)   If the business or entity is incorporated, the
name and principal business address of at least two responsible officers or
directors, including a statement of the office or position held by each; and



      (2)   A statement as to the specific type of proposed food
service establishment or temporary food service establishment for which the
permit is sought;



      (3)   The address (premises) within the city at which the food
service establishment or the temporary food service establishment is to be
operated;



      (4)   A copy of building construction plans approved by the
city's Building Official, Fire Marshal, and Health Officer for a food service
establishment;



      (5)   The signature of the applicant or applicant's authorized
representative; and



      (6)   Any additional information as may be required by the
Health Official to determine the qualifications of the applicant for the
permit.



   (C)   Food service establishment permits are valid for 12 months,
unless suspended or revoked as provided for in this chapter.



   (D)   A valid food service establishment or temporary food service
establishment permit shall be visibly posted at the premises indicated on the
permit where members of the public are able to view such permit.



   (E)   Food service establishment and temporary food service
establishment permits are not transferrable. Any change in ownership by a
person or entity in whose name the food service establishment permit or the
temporary food service establishment permit is in, as the case may be, shall
require the new owner(s) to submit an application for a new food service
establishment or temporary food service establishment permit with the city
and pay a permit fee as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees.



   (F)   At least 15 days before but no more than 30 days before the
anniversary date of the issuance of a permit, the food establishment permit
holder shall complete and submit to the city a written application with the
City Secretary for a renewal permit and pay to the city a renewal permit fee
in the amount set by City Council in a schedule of fees. The renewal
application shall contain the same information as the original application as
set forth in division (B) of this section.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



INSPECTIONS



§ 115.20  INSPECTIONS.



   (A)   Once the city receives a completed application and payment of
a permit fee for a food service establishment or a temporary food service
establishment, the Health Official will conduct an inspection of the premise
to determine if the rules and regulations contained in this chapter are met.
If the rules and regulations of this chapter are met and the food service
establishment or temporary food service establishment receives an inspection
score of 70 or above, the Health Official shall issue a permit to operate the
food service establishment or the temporary food service establishment.



   (B)   The Health Official shall inspect a food service establishment
at least three times in a 12- month period with such 12-month period being
the same time period as the food service establishment permit.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



§ 115.21  RE-INSPECTIONS.



   If a re-inspection is required as set forth in § 115.23 of this
chapter, then the Health Official shall conduct a re-inspection and the
permit holder shall pay a re-inspection fee as set forth by City Council in a
schedule of fees.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



§ 115.22  INSPECTION REPORT.



   After each inspection, the Health Official shall prepare an inspection
report. The inspection report shall summarize the requirements of this
chapter and the rules and regulations adopted and shall set forth a weighted
point value for each requirement.  Inspection remarks shall be written to
reference the section number of the relevant TFER. The rating score shall be
the total of the weighted point values for all violations, subtracted from
100. A copy of the inspection report shall be given to the person in charge
of the food service establishment or the temporary food service establishment
at the conclusion of the inspection, if possible.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



§ 115.23  CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS.



   (A)   The inspection report shall specify a reasonable time period
for the correction of any violations found, and correction of the violations
shall be accomplished within the period specified and in accordance with this
section.



      (1)   Food service establishment permit holders shall correct
all four and five-point violations no later than the tenth day after the
inspection. Temporary food service establishment permit holders shall correct
all four and five-point violations no later than 24 hours after the
inspection. The Health Official shall conduct a re-inspection of the food
service establishment after the tenth day after the inspection to confirm
that all four and five-point violations have been corrected. The Health
Official shall conduct a re-inspection of the temporary food service
establishment after 24 hours after the inspection. If all four and five-point
violations have not been corrected by the re-inspection, then the Health
Official shall suspend the food service establishment permit or the temporary
food service establishment permit, as applicable.



      (2)   Food service establishment permit holders shall correct
all one, two, and three- point violations by the next inspection with such
next inspection being at least 30 days after the previous inspection.
Temporary food service establishment permit holders shall correct all one,
two, and three- point violations within 48 hours after the inspection. The
Health Official shall conduct a re-inspection of the temporary food service
establishment 48 hours after the inspection to confirm that all one, two, and
three-point violations have been corrected. If all one, two, and three-point
violations have not been corrected by the next inspection or re-inspection as
the case may be, the Health Official may suspend the food service
establishment permit or the temporary food service establishment permit.



      (3)   If a food service establishment or temporary food
service establishment receives an inspection rating of less than 70, then the
permit holder shall correct violations no later than 48 hours after the
inspection.  The Health Official shall conduct a re-inspection of the food
service establishment 48 hours after the inspection to confirm that the
violations have been corrected which brings the inspection rating to more
than 70 with no four or five-point violations. If the inspection rating is
less than 70 at the re-inspection, then the Health Official shall suspend the
food service establishment permit or the temporary food service establishment
permit.



   (B)   The Health Official may order the immediate destruction of
food if in his or her determination the food presents an imminent danger to
the public if consumed or if allowed to remain at a premises. The permit
holder, owner, manager, or operator shall immediately comply with the Health
Official's food destruction order.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



§ 115.24  ACCESS TO PREMISES.



   If the food service establishment permit holder or temporary food
service establishment permit holder restricts access of the Health Official
to the premises during hours that the food service establishment or the
temporary food service establishment is regularly open for business or if the
food service establishment is not regularly open for business, then between
the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Sunday or at any time in
the determination of the Health Official that an imminent health hazard
exists, then the Health Official shall suspend the food service establishment
permit.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF PERMIT



§ 115.30  SUSPENSION OF PERMIT.



   (A)   The Health Official may suspend the food service establishment
or the temporary food service establishment permit if the permit holder does
not comply with the rules and regulations of this chapter or if the operation
of the food service establishment or a temporary food service establishment
constitutes an imminent health hazard. Suspension is effective upon service
of the notice required by this chapter. When a permit is suspended, food
service operations shall cease immediately and the premise shall close. Any
conditions on the following list are conclusive, but not exhaustive, that an
imminent health hazard exists:



      (1)   Inoperable water supply at the premise;



      (2)   Inoperable sanitary sewer at the premise;



      (3)   Inoperable electricity for 60 or more minutes at the
premise;



      (4)   Lack of hot water that is capable of reaching 110
degrees at the premise;



      (5)   Rodent or pest infestation that will likely cause the
spread of disease at the premise;



      (6)   Spoiled food stored at the premise; or



      (7)   Premises which are exposed to the elements if such
exposure will likely cause the spread of disease.



   (B)   When a food service establishment or temporary food service
establishment permit is suspended, the permit holder, the owner or operator,
or any employee shall be notified in writing that the permit is immediately
suspended and that an opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written
request for a hearing is filed with the City Secretary by the permit holder
no later than 5:00 p.m. on the tenth day after the Health Official orders
suspension. If no written request for a hearing is filed as provided herein,
the suspension is sustained.



   (C)   If a suspension is sustained, either at a hearing or by
operation of law, a suspension shall be in effect as long as the reason for
the suspension exists. A permit holder may schedule a re-inspection and pay a
re-inspection fee to the city so that the city may determine whether the
reason for the suspension still exists. After the re-inspection, the Health
Officer shall either lift the suspension or sustain the suspension.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



§ 115.31  REVOCATION.



   (A)   The city may, after providing opportunity for a hearing,
revoke a food service establishment or temporary food service establishment
permit for serious or repeated violations of any of the rules and regulations
of this chapter or for interference with the Health Official in the
performance of his or her duties. Prior to revocation, the city shall notify
the permit holder, the owner or operator, or any employee or person in
charge, in writing, of the reason for which the permit is subject to
revocation, and that the permit shall be revoked at the end of the tenth
calendar day following service of notice unless a written request for a
hearing is filed with the City Secretary by the permit holder by 5:00 p.m. at
the end of the tenth calendar day. If a hearing request is timely filed, the
permit holder will be afforded an opportunity for a hearing no later than 20
days after the city receives the hearing request. If no hearing request is
filed or if the request is not timely filed, the revocation of the permit
becomes final.  When a permit is revoked, food service operations shall
cease immediately and the premise shall close.



   (B)   If the city revokes a food service establishment or temporary
food service establishment permit and the permit holder desires to operate a
food service establishment or temporary food service establishment, then the
permit holder shall complete a new application for a food service
establishment or temporary food service establishment and pay a permit fee.
The city shall treat such application as a new, original application and
applicant shall comply with all the rules and regulations of this chapter
before the city will issue a new permit.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



§ 115.32  SERVICE OF NOTICES.



   A notice provided for in this chapter is properly served when it is
hand delivered to the food service establishment or the temporary food
service establishment permit holder, the owner or operator, or any employee
or person in charge of the premise. Notice also may be properly served when
it is sent by certified mail with return receipt requested to the last known
address of the permit holder. Notice also may be properly served when it is
posted on the premises.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



§ 115.33  HEARING.



   Any hearing under this chapter shall be conducted by the City
Council.  Based upon evidence presented at the hearing, the City Council
shall either sustain the action of the Health Official if it finds by a
preponderance of the evidence that the Health Official's actions were
justified or overturn the action of the Health Official if it finds by a
preponderance of the evidence that the Health Official's actions were not
justified. The judgment of the City Council shall be given to the food
service establishment or the temporary food service establishment permit
holder and filed with the City Secretary. The judgment of the City Council is
final and binding on all parties.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



MISCELLANEOUS



§ 115.40  CITY BARBEQUE PIT.



   The city may allow the rental of its barbeque pit to charitable
organizations or not-for-profit or non-profit entities whose mission benefits
the city, sports groups whose membership consists of a majority of city
residents, or youth groups whose membership consists of a majority of city
residents if such entity or groups pays a rental fee as set forth by the City
Council in a schedule of fees.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



115.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another to violate
any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500
unless such violation is governed by fire safety, zoning, or public health and



sanitation including dumping of refuse in which case the fine amount shall
not be more than $2,000. Each occurrence of any such violation of this
chapter shall constitute a separate offense. Each day on which any such
violation of this chapter occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 2014-16, passed 11-25-2014)



CHAPTER 116:  CREDIT ACCESS BUSINESS



Section



   116.01   Short title and purpose



   116.02   Definitions



   116.03   Violations; penalty



   116.04   Defenses



   116.05   Registration required



   116.06   Registration application



   116.07   Issuance and display of certificate of registration;
presentment upon request



   116.08   Expiration and renewal of certificate of registration



   116.09   Non-transferability



   116.10   Maintenance of records



   116.11   Restriction on extension of consumer credit



   116.12   Requirement of consumer understanding of agreement



   116.13   Referral to consumer credit counseling



§ 116.01  SHORT TITLE AND PURPOSE.



   (A)   This chapter may be known and cited as "Credit Access
Businesses Regulation."



   (B)   The purpose of this chapter is to protect the welfare of the
citizens of the city by monitoring credit access businesses in an effort to
reduce abusive and predatory lending practices. To this end, this chapter
establishes a registration program for credit access businesses, imposes
restrictions on extensions of consumer credit made by credit access
businesses, and imposes recordkeeping requirements on credit access
businesses.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.  A certificate of registration issued by
the Director under this chapter to the owner or operator of a credit access
business.



   CONSUMER.  An individual who is solicited to purchase or who purchases
the services of a credit access business.



   CONSUMER'S LANGUAGE OF PREFERENCE. The language the consumer
understands best.



   CREDIT ACCESS BUSINESS.  Has the meaning given that term in Tex.
Finance Code § 393.601.



   DEFERRED PRESENTMENT TRANSACTION. Has the meaning given that term in
Tex. Finance Code § 393.601.



   DIRECTOR.  The Director of the department designated by the City
Council, Mayor, or Mayor's Designee, to enforce and administer this chapter.



   EXTENSION OF CONSUMER CREDIT. The meaning given that term in Tex.
Finance Code § 393.001.



   MOTOR VEHICLE TITLE LOAN.  Has the meaning given that term in Tex.
Finance Code § 393.601.



   PERSON.  Any individual, corporation, organization, partnership,
association, financial institution, or any other legal entity.



   REGISTRANT.  A person issued a certificate of registration for a
credit access business under this chapter and includes all owners and
operators of the credit access business identified in the registration
application filed under this chapter.



   STATE LICENSE.  A license to operate a credit access business issued
by the Texas Consumer Credit Commissioner under Tex. Finance Code Ch. 393,
Subch. G.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.03  VIOLATIONS; PENALTY.



   (A)   A person who violates a provision of this chapter, or who
fails to perform an act required of the person by this chapter, commits an
offense. A person commits a separate offense for each and every violation
relating to an extension of consumer credit, and for each day during which a
violation is committed, permitted, or continued.



   (B)   An offense under this chapter is punishable by a fine of not
more than $500.



   (C)   A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of
an offense under this chapter and need not be proved.



   (D)   The penalties provided for in division (B) are in addition to
any other remedies that the city may have under city ordinances and state law.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.04  DEFENSES.



   It is a defense to prosecution under this chapter that at the time of
the alleged offense the person was not required to be licensed by the state
as a credit access business under Tex. Finance Code Ch. 393, Subch. G.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.05  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.



   A person commits an offense if the person acts, operates, or conducts
businesses as a credit access business without a valid certificate of
registration. A certificate of registration is required for each physically
separate credit access business.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.06  REGISTRATION APPLICATION.



   (A)   To obtain a certificate of registration for a credit access
business, a person must submit an application on a form provided for that
purpose to the Director. The application must contain the following:



      (1)   The name, street address, mailing address, facsimile
number, and telephone number of the applicant.



      (2)   The business or trade name, street address, mailing
address, facsimile number, and telephone number of the credit access business.



      (3)   The names, street addresses, mailing addresses, and
telephone numbers of all owners of the credit access business, and the nature
and extent of each person's interest in the credit access business.



      (4)   A copy of a current, valid state license held by the
credit access business pursuant to Tex. Finance Code, Ch. 393, Subch. G.



      (5)   A copy of a current, valid certificate of occupancy
showing that the credit access business is in compliance with the City of
Meadows Place Code of Ordinances.



      (6)   A non-refundable application fee for the amount
established.



   (B)   An applicant or registrant shall notify the Director within 45
days after any material change in the information contained in the
application for a certificate of registration, including, but not limited to,
any change of address and any change in the status of the state license held
by the applicant or registrant.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.07  ISSUANCE AND DISPLAY OF CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION; PRESENTMENT
UPON REQUEST.



   (A)   The Director shall issue to the applicant a certificate of
registration upon receiving a completed application under § 116.06.



   (B)   A certificate of registration issued under this section must
be conspicuously displayed to the public in the credit access business. The
certificate of registration must be presented upon request to the Director or
any peace officer for examination.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.08  EXPIRATION AND RENEWAL OF CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.



   (A)   A certificate of registration expires on the earliest of:



      (1)   One year after the date of issuance; or



      (2)   The date of revocation, suspension, surrender,
expiration without renewal, or other termination of the registrant's state
license.



   (B)   A certificate of registration may be renewed by making
application in accordance with § 116.06. A registrant shall apply for
renewal at least 30 days before the expiration of the registration.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.09  NON-TRANSFERABILITY.



   A certificate of registration for a credit access business is not
transferable.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.10  MAINTENANCE OF RECORDS.



   (A)   A credit access business shall maintain a complete set of
records of all extensions of consumer credit arranged or obtained by the
credit access business, which mush include the following information:



      (1)   The name and address of the consumer;



      (2)   The principal amount of cash actually advanced;



      (3)   The length of the extension of consumer credit,
including the number of installments and renewals;



      (4)   The fees charged by the credit access business to
arrange or obtain an extension of consumer credit; and



      (5)   The documentation used to establish a consumer's income
under § 116.11 of this chapter.



   (B)   A credit access business shall maintain a copy of each written
agreement between the credit access business and a consumer evidencing an
extension of a consumer credit (including, but not limited to, any
refinancing or renewal granted to the consumer).



   (C)   A credit access business shall maintain copies of all
quarterly reports filed with the Texas Consumer Credit Commissioner under
Tex. Finance Code § 393.627.



   (D)   The records required to be maintained by a credit access
business under this section must be retained for at least three years and
made available for inspection by the city upon request during the usual and
customary business hours of the credit access business.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.11  RESTRICTION ON EXTENSION OF CONSUMER CREDIT.



   (A)   The cash advanced under an extension of consumer credit that a
credit access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in
obtaining in the form of a deferred presentment transaction may not exceed
20% of the consumer's gross monthly income.



   (B)   The cash advanced under an extension of consumer credit that a
credit access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in
obtaining in the form of a motor vehicle title loan may not exceed the lesser
of:



      (1)   Three percent of the consumer's gross annual income; or



      (2)   Seventy percent of the retail value of the motor vehicle.



   (C)   A credit access business shall use a paycheck or other
documentation establishing income to determine a consumer's income.



   (D)   An extension of consumer credit that a credit access business
obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining and that provides
for repayment in installments may not be payable in more than four
installments. Proceeds from each installment must be used to repay at least
25% of the principal amount of the extension of consumer credit. An extension
of consumer credit that provides for repayment in installments many not be
refinanced or renewed.



   (E)   An extension of consumer credit that a credit access business
obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining and that provides
for a single lump sum repayment may not be refinanced or renewed more than
three times. Proceeds from each refinancing or renewal must be used to repay
at least 25% of the principal amount of the original extension of consumer
credit.



   (F)   For purposes of this section, an extension of consumer credit
that is made to a consumer within seven days after a previous extension of
consumer credit has been paid by the consumer will constitute a refinancing
or renewal.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.12  REQUIREMENT OF CONSUMER UNDERSTANDING OF AGREEMENT.



   (A)   Every agreement between the credit access business and a
consumer evidencing an extension of consumer credit (including, but not
limited to, any refinancing or renewal granted to the consumer), must be
written in the consumer's language of preference. Every credit access
business location must maintain on its premises, to be available for use by
consumers, agreements in the English and Spanish languages.



   (B)   For every consumer who cannot read, every agreement between
the credit access business and a consumer evidencing an extension of consumer
credit (including, but not limited to, any refinancing or renewal granted to
the consumer) must be read to the consumer in its entirety in the consumer's
language of preference, prior to the consumer's signature.



   (C)   For every consumer who cannot read, every disclosure and
notice required by law must be read to the consumers in its entirety in the
consumer's language of preference, prior to the consumer's signature.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)



§ 116.13  REFERRAL TO CONSUMER CREDIT COUNSELING.



   A credit access business shall provide a form, to be prescribed by the
Director, to each consumer seeking assistance in obtaining an extension of
consumer credit which references non-profit agencies that provide financial
education and training programs and agencies with cash assistance programs.
The form will also contain information regarding extensions of consumer
credit, and must include the information required by § 116.10(A)(l)-(5) of
this chapter specific to the loan agreement with the consumer. If the
Director has prescribed a form in the consumer's language of preference, the
form must be provided in the consumer's language of preference.



(Ord. 2013-32, passed 12-17-2013)
