roof deck; and



         (f)   If a new roof covering is to replace an existing
roof, all existing roof material shall be removed first before installation
of the new roof.



      (6)   Solid roof sheathing, one-half inch minimum exterior
plywood and approved minimum one-half inch OSB board shall be used for new
roof construction where applicable.



      (7)   All roofing materials shall be installed in accordance
with manufacturer’s recommendations as contained in such literature as from
time to time is published and disseminated by the manufacturer.



   (E)   The following additional requirements shall be met for
replacement roofing:



      (1)   If placing fiberglass composition shingles over existing
wood shingles, fiberglass composition shingles meeting the requirements of
division (D)(1) above, with one course minimum 30# felt paper, shall be used;



      (2)   If removing wood shingles for replacement by fiberglass
composition shingles, a one-half inch minimum exterior treated plywood or an
approved minimum one-half inch OSB board for the sub-base or sheathing shall
be used with a minimum 15# felt paper, with a minimum four-inch in 12-inch
slope shall be used; and



(Ord. 99-19, passed 8-24-1999)



      (3)   If the existing wood roof is to be covered, the edge of
the wood shingle must be trimmed back to the fascia board. If the valley is
exposed, the valley metal must be acid washed, primed and painted with a
quality metal paint.



   (F)   Failure to obtain a roofing permit as required herein and the
installation of roofing materials without a permit shall constitute a
violation of this code. The violation shall be punishable by fine in the
Municipal Court in an amount of not less than the maximum jurisdictional
amount provided for under the laws of the state for violations of municipal
ordinances of this type, unless the defendant charged with the offense shall,
prior to the court date set in the citation issued for the violation, comply
with the requirements specified in division (G) below, in which event the
Judge of the Municipal Court may, in the exercise of his or her sound
discretion, assess a fine in a lesser amount.



   (G)   Each and every person or entity who has filed to obtain a
roofing permit required by this section prior to the installation of roofing
materials shall make application to the city for a permit to maintain the
installed roofing materials, and the requirements for the application and the
issuance of the permit shall be the same as for a roofing permit properly and
timely issued prior to the installation of the roofing materials; provided,
however, that a permit shall only be issued under this division following
inspection of the completed roofing installation and approval of the
application by the Building Official or his or her designee. A permit
obtained under the provisions of this division may be produced in court as
evidence that the roofing materials installed are in compliance with this
code.



   (H)   (1)   The maintenance of installed residential roofing
materials without a permit shall constitute prima facie evidence that the
roofing materials are not in conformity with this code and are of a class or
grade inferior to the requirements of this code. As such, each day that the
roofing materials installed without a permit issued pursuant to divisions (A)
through (E) of this section shall be permitted to remain on a residential
structure without a permit issued under division (G) of this section shall
constitute a separate violation of this code.



      (2)   Each separate and distinct daily violation of this code
shall be punishable by fine in the Municipal Court in an amount of not less
than the maximum jurisdictional amount provided for under the laws of the
state for violations of municipal ordinances of this type, unless the
defendant charged with the offense shall, prior to the court date set in any
citation issued for the violation, comply with the requirements for a
post-installation permit as specified in division (G) above, in which event
the Judge of the Municipal Court may, in the exercise of his or her sound
discretion, assess a fine for each such violation in a lesser amount.



   (I)   In the event of violation of any provision of this section,
the property owner(s), occupants, contractors, employees and any persons
acting in concert with the named persons or entities to permit the violation
to continue shall each be deemed guilty of a separate violation and be
subject to fine and penalty to the extent as herein provided.



   (J)   (1)   The City Council finds that the maintenance of
installed unpermitted residential roofing materials in the city constitutes a
hazard and a threat to the health, safety and well-being of all residents,
citizens, inhabitants and property owners of the city. As such, the Mayor,
the Building Official or their designees are hereby authorized to enter upon
private property, without further authorization, to remove the unpermitted
materials and are further authorized to proceed directly or in any court of
competent jurisdiction to require the immediate vacation of any structures to
which the materials are applied, including, without limitation, boarding up
the structure and erecting appropriate safeguards to prevent re-entry.



      (2)   In the event that the Building Official shall make a
determination that a noncomplying roof exists, the Mayor and the Building
Official, or either of them, are hereby authorized to revoke the certificate
of occupancy for the premises and to immediately notify all servicing
utilities that further occupation and use of the premises is unlawful and
illegal and to request that servicing utilities immediately terminate utility
services of every type provided to the premises.



   (K)   The following additional requirements shall be met for
installation of solar energy devices:



      (1)   In this section, “solar energy device” means a
system or series of mechanisms designed primarily to provide heating or
cooling or to produce electrical or mechanical power by collection and
transferring solar-generated energy.  The term includes a mechanical or
chemical device that has the ability to store solar-generated energy for use
in heating or cooling or in the production of power.



      (2)   Prior to the installation of a solar energy device, the
owner shall apply for and obtain a solar energy device permit and pay the
application fee as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees.



      (3)   On a roof with a slope of not more than three inches of
rise in 12 inches of run, a solar energy device may be installed where it is
not visible from any public street right-of-way.



      (4)   On a roof with a slope of at least three inches of rise
in 12 inches or run or greater, a solar energy device may be installed on the
back slope of the roof apex parallel to a public street right-of-way that is
not also a front slope of a roof apex parallel to another public street
right-of-way.



      (5)   The building official or their designee shall inspect
the proposed installation location of the solar energy device prior to the
issuing of the permit.



(Prior Code, § 9-50)  (Ord. 88-017, § 1, passed 5-24-1988; Ord. 2013-05,
passed 4-23-2013; Ord. 2014-01, passed 1-28-2014; Ord. 2016-30, passed
11-22-2016)  Penalty, see § 150.99



SUBSTANDARD BUILDINGS



§ 150.35  BUILDING OFFICIAL.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Building Official or other
designee as appointed by the Mayor to inspect all buildings reported or
believed to be in violation of the minimum standards for continued use and
occupancy set forth in this subchapter, to present preliminary reports on the
inspections to the City Council, to give all notices required by this
subchapter and to present evidence at all public hearings required by this
subchapter.



   (B)   For any notice required to be given under this subchapter, the
Building Official or other designee as appointed by the Mayor shall make a
diligent effort to identify the person or entity entitled to receive notice
and to identify the post office address of such person or entity by searching
the following records:



      (1)   County real property records of the county in which the
building is located;



      (2)   Appraisal district records of the appraisal district in
which the building is located;



      (3)   Records of the Secretary of State;



      (4)   Assumed name records of the county in which the building
is located;



      (5)   Tax records of the City of Meadows Place; and



      (6)   Utility records of the City of Meadows Place.



(Ord. 2013-25, passed 10-22-2013)



§ 150.36  MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR CONTINUED USE AND OCCUPANCY.



   Any building in the city meeting one or more of the following
descriptions, regardless of the date of construction, shall be in violation
of the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy:



   (A)   Building that is dilapidated, substandard, or unfit for human
habitation. A building that is dilapidated, substandard, or unfit for human
habitation and a hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare due to any
of the following conditions:



      (1)   Deteriorated building. A building which has become
deteriorated through natural causes or by damage as a result of exposure to
the elements to the extent that the roof, windows and doors or portions of
the building which protect from the weather will no longer reasonably protect
from the elements.



      (2)   Fire hazard. A building which, because of its wiring,
construction or present status, constitutes a fire hazard.



      (3)   Pestilence. A building in or around which there exist
conditions caused by accumulations of refuse, vegetation, or other matter
that creates breeding and living places for insects and rodents.



      (4)   Structural deformities. A building which has been built
or constructed in such a manner as to be in jeopardy of collapse or not
reasonably capable of withstanding customary and ordinary exposure to the
elements or which is unsafe or dangerous because of the deficiency of its
materials, methods or means of construction, including the foundation,
structural elements, wiring or apparatus, plumbing and fixtures, entrances or
exits.



      (5)   Inadequate fire safety provisions. A building in or
around which exist conditions constituting inadequate fire safety provisions
because of the materials used, types of construction or design, warning
devices, sprinklers or other fire suppression devices, availability of water
supply for extinguishing fires, or location, design or width of the entrances
or exits.



      (6)   Other. A building in or around which there exist
conditions or circumstances which may from time to time be delineated under
the terms and provisions of law and within the scope of authority of the City
Council to be a hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare.



   (B)   Unoccupied building. A building which has been unoccupied by
its owners, lessees, or other invitees for a period of 90 days unless the
owner has:



      (1)   Secured the building from unauthorized entry to the
extent that it cannot be entered or used by vagrants or other uninvited
persons as a place of harborage and cannot be entered or used by children,
provided that the securing of a building by means of boarding up with plywood
or other similar material shall be prohibited;



      (2)   Posted emergency contact information in a conspicuous
place near each entrance to the building that faces a public right-of-way,
which shall be printed on a rigid, weather-resistant material and shall
include the words "UNOCCUPIED BUILDING" in all capital letters, followed by
the owner's name, the owner's post office address, and a telephone number
where the owner or an agent of the owner authorized to respond in the case of
an emergency can be reached 24 hours a day, seven days a week;



      (3)   Submitted to the Building Official or other designee as
appointed by the Mayor a plan for bringing the building back into occupancy,
which shall indicate the owner's intent to sell, lease, demolish or otherwise
bring the building back into occupancy and shall set forth steps the owner
plans to take to accomplish same; and



      (4)   Submitted to the Building Official or other designee as
appointed by the Mayor a certificate showing coverage by the following
minimum insurance, which shall be written by an accredited company under the
supervision of the State Board of Insurance Commissioners and shall not
exclude coverage due to the building being unoccupied:



         (a)   Public liability insurance to the extent of
$500,000 for any one accident and $100,000 for any one person; and



         (b)   Property damage insurance to the extent of
$100,000 for any one accident and $500,000 in the aggregate.



   (C)   Inadequately secured building. A building that is secured in
any manner if:



      (1)   The building constitutes a danger to the public even
though secured from entry; or



      (2)   The means used to secure the building are inadequate to
prevent unauthorized entry to the extent that it could be entered or used by
vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of harborage or could be
entered or used by children, provided that the securing of a building by
means of boarding up with plywood or other similar material shall be
prohibited.



(Ord. 2013-25, passed 10-22-2013)



§ 150.37  PROCEDURE FOR DETERMINATION OF SUBSTANDARD BUILDING.



   (A)   After reviewing the preliminary reports provided by the
Building Official or other designee appointed by the Mayor or on its own
initiative, the City Council may hold a public hearing to determine whether a
building violates the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy. At
such hearing, the owner of the building shall have the burden of proof to
demonstrate the scope of any work that may be required to comply with the
minimum standards for continued use and occupancy and the time it will take
to reasonably perform the work.



   (B)   The Building Official or other designee as appointed by the
Mayor shall give notice to the owner of a building subject to a hearing
authorized by this section on or before the tenth day before the date of the
hearing by posting the notice at the building and by personal delivery, by
certified mail with return receipt requested, or by delivery by the United
States Postal Service using signature confirmation service to the owner's
post office address. If a notice is mailed in accordance with this section
and the United States Postal Service returns the notice as "refused" or
"unclaimed," the validity of the notice is not affected, and the notice is
considered delivered. The notice required by this section shall contain:



      (1)   An identification of the date, time and location set for
the hearing;



      (2)   An identification, which is not required to be a legal
description, of the building and the property on which it is located;



      (3)   A description of each violation of the minimum standards
for continued use and occupancy believed to be present at the building;



      (4)   A statement that the City Council may order the owner to
vacate, secure, repair, remove or demolish the building or relocate the
occupants of the building if the City Council determines that the building
violates the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy; and



      (5)   A statement that the owner will be required to submit at
the hearing proof of the scope of any work that may be required to comply
with the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy and the time it
will take to reasonably perform the work.



(Ord. 2013-25, passed 10-22-2013)



§ 150.38  PROCEDURE FOR ABATEMENT OF SUBSTANDARD BUILDING.



   (A)   If after a hearing authorized by § 150.37 the City Council
determines that the building violates the minimum standards for continued use
and occupancy, the City Council may order the owner to:



      (1)   Secure the building from unauthorized entry within 30
days; or



      (2)   Repair, remove, or demolish the building within a
reasonable time not to exceed:



         (a)   Thirty days, unless at the hearing the owner
establishes that the work cannot reasonably be performed within 30 days and
the order establishes specific time schedules for the commencement and
performance of the work and requires the owner to secure the property in a
reasonable manner from unauthorized entry while the work is being performed,
as determined by the hearing official; and



         (b)   Ninety days, unless at the hearing the owner
establishes that because of the scope and complexity of the work, the work
cannot reasonably be completed with 90 days and submits a detailed plan and
time schedule for the work and the order requires the owner to regularly
submit progress reports to the Building Official or other designee appointed
by the Mayor to demonstrate compliance with the time schedules established
for commencement and performance of the work.



   (B)   If the City Council allows the owner more than 90 days to
repair, remove, or demolish the building and the owner owns property,
including structures or improvements on property, within the municipal
boundaries of the city that exceeds $100,000 in total value, the city may
require the owner to post a cash or surety bond in an amount adequate to
cover the cost of repairing, removing, or demolishing the building. In lieu
of a bond, the city may require the owner to provide a letter of credit from
a financial institution or a guaranty from a third party approved by the
city. The bond must be posted, or the letter of credit or third party
guaranty provided, not later than the 30th day after the date the city issues
the order.



   (C)   An order by the City Council to demolish a building shall
explicitly find that repairs to the building cannot be made without
substantial reconstruction and that the building is a hazard to the public
health, safety and welfare, which findings shall be subject to review under
the substantia! evidence rule as provided by Tex. Government Code § 2001.174.



   (D)   if the City Council orders the owner to vacate, secure,
repair, remove or demolish the building as authorized by this section, the
Building Official or other designee as appointed by the Mayor shall promptly
mail by certified mail with return receipt requested, deliver by the United
States Postal Service using signature confirmation service, or personally
deliver a notice of the order and a copy thereof to the owner of the building
and to any lienholder or mortgagee of the building.



   (E)   Within ten days after the date that an order authorized by
this section is issued, the Building Official or other designee as appointed
by the Mayor shall:



      (1)   File a copy of the order in the office of the City
Secretary; and



      (2)   Publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the
city a notice containing:



         (a)   The street address or legal description of the
property;



         (b)   The date of the hearing;



         (c)   A brief statement indicating the results of the
order; and



         (d)   Instructions stating where a complete copy of the
order may be obtained.



   (F)   If the owner does not vacate, secure, repair, remove or
demolish the building within the time allotted under an order authorized by
this section, the Building Official or other designee as appointed by the
Mayor shall make a diligent effort to discover each mortgagee and lienholder
having an interest in the building or having an interest in the property on
which the building is located and shall mail by certified mail with return
receipt requested, deliver by the United States Postal Service using
signature confirmation service, or personally deliver a notice to each
mortgagee or lienholder identified. The notice required by this section shall
contain:



      (1)   An identification, which is not required to be a legal
description, of the building and the property on which it is located;



      (2)   A description of each violation of the minimum standards
for continued use and occupancy determined to be present at the building; and



      (3)   A statement that the municipality will vacate, secure,
repair, remove, or demolish the building or relocate the occupants of the
building if the ordered action is not taken within an additional reasonable
time equal to the time provided in the order for action by the owner.



   (G)   If the building is not vacated, secured, repaired, removed, or
demolished, or the occupants are not relocated within the allotted time, the
city may, at its own expense:



      (1)   Vacate, secure, or remove the building or relocate the
occupants;



      (2)   Repair the building, unless the city assesses a civil
penalty against the owner for failure to repair the building, but only to the
extent necessary to bring the building into compliance with the minimum
standards for continued use and occupancy and only if the building is a
residential building with ten or fewer dwelling units; or



      (3)   Demolish the building, provided that the city shall not
demolish the building until 30 days have elapsed since the date the last
owner, mortgagee, or lienholder receives a copy of the order by personal
delivery, first class mail with certified return receipt requested, or
delivery by the United States Postal Service using signature confirmation
service.



   (H)   If the city vacates, secures, removes, or demolishes the
building or relocates the occupants at its own expense, the city may assess
the expenses it incurs on, and the city has a lien against, unless it is a
homestead as protected by the Texas Constitution, the property on which the
building is located. If the city repairs the building at its own expense, the
city shall assess the expenses it incurs on and shall impose a lien against
the land on which the building stands, and promptly after such lien is
imposed, shall file for record, in recordable form in the office of the
County Clerk of the county in which the land is located, a written notice of
the imposition of the lien, which must contain a legal description of the
land.



   (I)   Any owner, lienholder, or mortgagee of record of property
jointly or severally aggrieved by an order of the City Council issued under
this section may appeal such order as provided by Tex. Local Government Code
§ 214.0012.



(Ord. 2013-25, passed 10-22-2013)



§ 150.39  AUTHORITY TO SECURE SUBSTANDARD BUILDING.



   (A)   The City Council may order the Building Official or other
designee as appointed by the Mayor to secure a building if the City Council
determines that:



      (1)   The building violates the minimum standards for
continued use and occupancy; and



      (2)   The building is unoccupied or is occupied only by
persons who do not have a right of possession to the building.



   (B)   Before the 11th day after the date the building is secured,
the Building Official or other designee as appointed by the Mayor shall give
notice to the owner by:



      (1)   Personally serving the owner with written notice;



      (2)   Depositing the notice in the United States mail
addressed to the owner at the owner's post office address;



      (3)   Publishing the notice at least twice within a ten-day
period in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the
building is located if personal service cannot be obtained and the owner's
post office address is unknown; or



      (4)   Posting the notice on or near the front door of the
building if personal service cannot be obtained and the owner's post office
address is unknown.



   (C)   The notice required under this section must contain:



      (1)   An identification, which is not required to be a legal
description, of the building and the property on which it is located;



      (2)   A description of the violation of the minimum standards
for continued use and occupancy that is present at the building;



      (3)   A statement that the city will secure or has secured, as
the case may be, the building; and



      (4)   An explanation of the owner's entitlement to request a
hearing about any matter relating to the city's securing of the building.



   (D)   If within 30 days after the date the building is secured, the
owner files with the City Council or the Building Official or other designee
as appointed by the Mayor a written request for a hearing, the City Council
shall conduct a hearing within 20 days after the date the request is filed,
at which the owner may testify or present witnesses or written information
about any matter relating to the securing of the building.



   (E)   The city may assess the expenses it incurs in exercising its
authority under this section on, and the city has a lien against, unless it
is a homestead as protected by the Texas Constitution, the property on which
the building was located.



(Ord. 2013-25, passed 10-22-2013)



§ 150.40  ASSESSMENT OF CIVIL PENALTY.



   (A)   If the city orders a property owner to repair, remove, or
demolish a building as authorized by this subchapter and the owner fails to
take the required action within the time allotted, the city may assess a
civil penalty against the owner for failure to repair, remove, or demolish
the building and provide for that assessment, the mode and manner of giving
notice, and the means of recovering the assessment, provided the city shall
not assess a civil penalty against the owner for failure to repair the
building if the city repairs the building at its own expense. If the city
assesses a civil penalty as authorized by this section the city shall impose
a lien against the land on which the building stands or stood, unless it is a
homestead as protected by the Texas Constitution, to secure the payment of
the civil penalty. Promptly after imposition of the lien, the city shall file
for record, in recordable form in the office of the County Clerk of the
county in which the land is located, a written notice of the imposition of
the lien, which must contain a legal description of the land.



   (B)   In addition to the city's authority to require the vacation,
relocation of occupants, securing, repair, removal, or demolition of a
building under this subchapter, the city by order may assess and recover a
civil penalty against a property owner at the time of an administrative
hearing on violations of an ordinance, in an amount not to exceed $1,000 a
day for each violation or, if the owner shows that the property is the
owner's lawful homestead, in an amount not to exceed $10 a day for each
violation, if the city proves:



      (1)   The property owner was notified of the requirements of
the ordinance and the owner's need to comply with the requirements; and



      (2)   After notification, the property owner committed an act
in violation of the ordinance or failed to take an action necessary for
compliance with the ordinance.



(Ord. 2013-25, passed 10-22-2013)



§ 150.41  PROCEDURE FOR ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION HEARING.



   (A)   Before the city assesses a civil penalty as authorized by this
subchapter, the city shall conduct an administrative adjudication hearing as
provided by this section.



   (B)   At the hearing authorized by this section, the Mayor shall
preside as the hearing officer and shall, at the conclusion of the hearing,
issue an order stating:



      (1)   Whether the owner of the property is liable for either
violation of the minimum standards for continued use and occupancy or for
failure to repair, remove, or demolish the building in the time allotted as
ordered by the City Council; and



      (2)   The amount of a civil penalty assessed against the owner.



   (C)   On or before the tenth day before the date fixed for the
hearing, the Building Official or other designee as appointed by the Mayor
and authorized to do so shall issue a citation to the owner of the building
charged with violation of the minimum standards for continued use and
occupancy, which shall:



      (1)   Notify the owner of the requirements of the ordinance or
order that they are charged with violating and of their need to comply with
the requirements;



      (2)   Notify the owner that they have the right to a hearing;
and



      (3)   Provide information as to the time and place of the
hearing.



   (D)   After the hearing authorized by this section, the city may
assess a civil penalty in an amount not to exceed $1,000 a day for each
violation or, if the owner shows that the property is the owner's lawful
homestead, in an amount not to exceed $10 a day for each violation, if the
city proves:



      (1)   The property owner was notified of the requirements of
the ordinance or order and the owner's need to comply with the requirements;
and



      (2)   After notification, the property owner committed an act
in violation of the ordinance or order or failed to take an action necessary
for compliance with the ordinance or order.



   (E)   Any owner who is found by the hearing officer to have violated
an ordinance or order under this section may appeal the determination as
provided by Tex. Local Government Code § 54.044.



(Ord. 2013-25, passed 10-22-2013)



§ 150.42  LIABILITY OF CITY.



   Neither the city nor any authorized agent acting under the terms of
this subchapter shall be liable or have any liability by reason of orders
issued or work done in compliance with the terms of this subchapter.



(Ord. 2013-25, passed 10-22-2013)



LANDSCAPE DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS FOR COMMERCIAL DEVELOPMENT



§ 150.55  APPLICABILITY.



   (A)   Land and development covered.  The provisions of this
subchapter shall apply to all land located in the city which is either in
commercial use or which may come into commercial use subsequent threreto. 
The term COMMERCIAL USE shall be used to denote any use of land other than as
a building site for single-family and two-family residences where only one
structure is constructed per lot.



   (B)   One structure on lot.  The requirements herein shall be
deemed applicable to all property other than property in single-family and
multi-family use where only one structure is constructed per lot.



(Prior Code, § 9-300)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.56  DEFINITIONS.



   The following words and phrases as herein set out are deemed to be
words and phrases of unique or special meaning and are defined as being
applicable to the provisions of this subchapter. Other words and phrases of
customary and common meaning and understanding shall be applicable even
though not directly set out herein, and any words defined herein shall not be
applicable to other parts, subchapters or chapters of this code.



   BERM. A human-made earthform covered by vegetation consisting of a
minimum height of 36 inches above surrounding finished grade and possessing a
maximum slope of 3:1, excluding retaining walls or terracing improvements.



   CALIPER. The diameter of a tree measured six inches above the ground
when planted for any tree up to six inches in diameter size. For any tree
larger than six inches in diameter at six-inch height from planting grade,
the D.B.H. or "diameter at breast height" shall be measured for calculations
toward the satisfaction of requirements of this subchapter. (International
Society of Aboriculture Standards for Tree Evaluation, latest edition)



   LANDSCAPED AREA. The area within the boundaries of a given lot or where
applicable, the adjoining street right-of-way, which is devoted to and
consists of plant material, including but not limited to grass, trees,
shrubs, flowers, vines and other groundcover, native plant materials,
planters, brick, stone, natural forms, water forms, aggregate and other
landscape features, but not including the use of smooth concrete or asphalt;
provided, however, that the use of brick, stone, aggregate or other inorganic
landscape materials shall not exceed 20% of the required LANDSCAPE AREA.



   STREET YARD. The area of a lot which lies between the street
right-of-way and the actual front wall line of the building. It is intended
that the term "front wall or front building line" shall be the front of the
building wall fronting on a street, whether regular or irregular in dimension.



      (1)   In the case of corner lots or other irregularly
configured lots, the STREET YARD shall include that portion of property that
may be on two streets as determined by the actual location of the front
building wall which shall include that portion of the building wall on the
abutting corner street or an irregularly configured lot. In determining the
actual building wall of the building for the purposes of street yard, steps
and unenclosed porches shall be excluded, but the building wall lines shall
follow and include the irregular indentions of the building. As such, the
building wall line shall extend from the outward corner of the building until
the imaginary extensions of the front building line intersect with side
property lines.



      (2)   When there are multiple buildings on a lot, the STREET
YARD shall consist of all the area of the lot between the street right-of-way
line(s) and an imaginary line, or building line, beginning at one side of the
property line, running parallel to the street, connecting to the front most
corner of the building wall fronting the street and nearest the side property
line, then following and connecting the front most walls of all buildings
fronting on the street, and then extending to the other property line,
running parallel to the street. If a building has a rounded front, the front
building wall corners shall be the points closest to the side boundaries.



(Prior Code, § 9-301)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.57  HORTICULTURAL SITE PLAN FOR STREET YARD DEVELOPMENT REQUIRED.



   (A)   When an application is made for a horticultural site plan
approval or an approval preliminary to the issuance of a building permit, a
plan under this section is required to be submitted by the owners or
developers of all property covered under this subchapter.



   (B)   The horticultural site plan required shall contain the
following information:



      (1)   The date, graphic scale, north arrow, title and name of
owner;



      (2)   The location of existing boundary lines, easements and
dimensions of the tract;



      (3)   The approximate location of existing water courses; the
approximate location of significant drainage features; and the location and
size of existing and proposed streets and alleys, existing and proposed
easements on or adjacent to the lot, and existing and proposed paving/walks
or any other similar improvement;



      (4)   The location, size, and type (tree or shrub, groundcover
or grass) of proposed landscaping in proposed landscaped areas; and the
location and size of proposed landscaped areas;



      (5)   The location and species of existing trees in the street
yard and parking lots having trunks eight inches caliper or larger and the
approximate size of their crowns;



      (6)   The proposed plan shall identify the requirements of
this subchapter and shall state whether or not all the requirements have been
met by certification of the plat preparer or owner and a statement as to
whether or not there is any qualification for bonus credit;



      (7)   An indication of how the applicant plans to protect the
existing trees which are proposed to be retained from damage during
construction;



      (8)   The proposed irrigation system as required under this
subchapter; and



      (9)   The certification by an architect, landscape architect
or professional engineer, currently registered in the state. This
certification shall state that the plans fully satisfy the requirements of
this subchapter and other provisions of the code of ordinances of the city.



(Prior Code, § 9-302)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.58  REQUIREMENTS.



   In order for a plan to be approved under the terms and provisions of
this subchapter, the following requirements must be met:



   (A)   At least 20% of the street yard must be landscaped unless the
City Council, upon the request of a property owner, shall grant a variance to
the provisions of this section under the procedures as herein set out;



   (B)   On lots having a street yard of 10,000 square feet or less, up
to 50% of the requirement as herein provided under division (A) of this
section may be placed in the non-paved street right-of-way abutting the lot;



   (C)   On lots having a street yard in excess of 10,000 feet, up to
25% of the requirements as specified under division (A) of this section may
be placed in the non-paved street right-of-way abutting the lot;



   (D)   No existing newly planted trees in the right-of-way shall at
any time be counted toward the satisfaction of any requirements as herein set
out;



   (E)   In order for the property owner to use the right-of-way for
any purposes, the right-of-way must be landscaped; however, all landscaping
in the right-of-way shall be subject to the following requirements:



      (1)   The city shall at all times reserve the right to remove,
replant or destroy the landscaping and the city, its contractors or its
employees contractors or agents shall have no liability of any kind, nor
shall a claim lie for the removal, transplanting or destruction;



      (2)   Prior to the installation of any planting materials as
may be otherwise provided for by this subchapter, the same shall be approved
by the Building Official of the city to be in accordance with the
requirements of all other provisions of this code or interpretations thereof
provided by the Building Official of the city;



      (3)   No planters or other permanent structures may at any
time be placed within the right-of-way. In the event of a conflict as to
whether or not a proposed landscape development is or shall constitute a
planter or permanent structure, the Building Official shall provide an
interpretation which shall be deemed final; and



      (4)   All landscaping installed as herein required shall be
maintained by the property owner or persons designated by the property owner
and/or the property owner may require as a condition of the leasehold or
lease rights that the maintenance occur. In the event the landscaping as
herein required shall not be maintained in a healthy and well-planned
environment as shall be determined by the Building Official, no further
permits or certificates of occupancy for any remodeling, additions or
continued construction as may be sought and required under this chapter may
be issued.



   (F)   (1)   The City Council, upon application of a property
owner, may grant a variance to the provisions of this section upon the City
Council finding the existence of one or both of the following circumstances
and conditions:



         (a)   Unusual size and configuration of property that
makes compliance impossible or impracticable; and/or



         (b)   Pre-existing development and/or landscaping that
would make literal compliance impossible or impracticable.



      (2)   In addition, the City Council may approve a variance if
the City Council finds the existence of such other facts and circumstances
relating to existing or proposed development, including existing or proposed
landscaping, which require a differing approach to accomplish the objectives
of this subchapter or any part thereof.



      (3)   If a variance is requested, the City Council may, at its
discretion, consider the request and conduct the hearings and/or
investigations as it may deem just or prudent. However, in no event shall the
City Council be required to receive, hear or decide a request for variance
if, in the discretion of the City Council, the best interests of the city and
the objectives of this subchapter require some other disposition.



      (4)   A variance may be granted by the City Council by motion
made, seconded and carried. No amendatory ordinance shall be necessary, and
the City Secretary shall be instructed to attach a copy of the portion of the
Council minutes granting the variance to any request for a building permit or
other permit as necessary under any other provision of this code.



(Prior Code, § 9-303)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.59  REQUIREMENTS FOR NEW TREES.



   All newly planted trees shall be planted in a pervious area no less
than five feet wide in any direction. In the street yard, at least one tree
of at least one and one-half inch caliper (either existing or planted) shall
be included and replaced as necessary to maintain the following minimum
ratios:



   (A)   In street yards up to 10,000 square feet, one tree per 1,000
square feet, or fraction thereof, of street yard;



   (B)   In street yards between 10,000 and 110,000 square feet, one
tree per 2,500 square feet, or fraction thereof, of street yard over 10,000
square feet is added to the requirement of ten trees; and



   (C)   In street yards over 110,000 square feet, one tree per 5,000
square feet, or fraction thereof, of street yard area over 110,000 square
feet, is added to the requirement of 50 trees.



(Prior Code, § 9-304)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.60  VEHICULAR USE AREAS, PARKING LOTS AND AREAS ADJACENT TO PUBLIC
STREET RIGHTS-OF-WAY.



   The following provisions shall be applicable to all vehicular use
areas, public areas, parking lots or lots adjacent to public street
rights-of-way and shall control any development thereof.



   (A)   If a vehicular use area, parking area or parking lot,
including the vehicles contemplated to be parked thereon, shall have
effective buffering from street view in lieu of a berm or wall, the plant
material must be no more than 36 inches on center and five-gallon size when
installed. (Standard: American Association of Nurserymen, American Standards
for Nursery Stock, latest edition.)



   (B)   In all vehicular use areas and parking areas of a street yard,
a minimum of 90 square feet for each 12 parking spaces shall be devoted to
landscaped islands, peninsulas or medians.



   (C)   The number, size and shape of required islands, peninsulas and
medians in street yards shall be at the discretion of the owner of the
property. However, no parking space shall be located farther than 50 feet
from a tree in a pervious landscaped island, peninsula or median. All
islands, peninsulas and medians required in the areas stated above shall be
more or less evenly distributed throughout the parking areas, respectively;
however, the distribution and location of landscaped islands, peninsulas and
medians may be adjusted to accommodate existing trees or other natural
features so long as the total area requirement for landscaped islands,
peninsulas and medians for the respective parking areas is satisfied. Only
landscaped islands, peninsulas and medians in the street yard shall count
toward fulfilling the requirements of this section.



   (D)   All landscaping which is in required landscaped areas and
which is adjacent to pavement shall be protected with concrete curbs.



   (E)   The existing natural landscape character (including but not
limited to native oaks, elms and pecan trees) shall be preserved to the
extent reasonable and feasible. The plan as herein required for the proposed
landscape shall identify the trees to be removed and shall clearly show the
reasons that the removal is necessary and appropriate.



   (F)   No horticultural plan shall be approved if the proposed
landscaping does or will likely obstruct the view between the street and
access drives and parking isles near the street yard entries and exits, nor
shall any landscape which is likely to create an obstruction of view be
approved which is located in the radius of any curb turn.



(Prior Code, § 9-305)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.61  CREDIT/BONUSES.



   The following system of credit/bonuses shall be applicable to the
required horticultural site plan for street yard development as well as other
requirements of this subchapter.



   (A)   Each square foot of pervious landscaped area within the
dripline of a tree at least four inches caliper shall count as two square
feet of landscaped area for the purpose of satisfying the provisions of this
subchapter.



   (B)   In order to encourage the early maturation of landscaped
cover, newly planted trees between four and eight inches caliper, such trees
may receive special credit for twice the area of the dripline, provided that
the increased credit area contiguous to the dripline is pervious. This credit
shall not apply to palm trees or such other trees as shall be determined by
the Building Official as being inappropriate and not in accord with the
requirements of this division which relates to wooded trees.



   (C)   Any existing tree which is at least eight inches caliper or at
least six inches caliper and at least 15 feet tall shall be considered as two
trees for the purpose of satisfying the requirements as herein specified.



   (D)   The following shall not be eligible for 200% credit:



      (1)   Overlapping dripline areas;



      (2)   Dripline areas with less than 50% pervious cover; and



      (3)   Dripline areas that have had damaging changes in the
original grade. Changes in grade required by city ordinances or action by the
city such as sidewalks, curbing, driveway approaches or other similar
improvements shall not be considered as damaging changes.



   (E)   In no case shall the actual landscaped area in the street yard
be less than 50% of the required minimum percentages as herein provided.



(Prior Code, § 9-306)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.62  FEES AND INSPECTIONS.



   (A)   The Mayor of the city shall from time to time prescribe a fee
schedule in such an amount as is reasonable and necessary to cover all costs
incurred by the city in accordance with the administering of the requirements
of this subchapter and approval of all plans as may be submitted. The fee
schedule shall be promulgated in a manner sufficient to recover for the city
such costs as it may incur in administering the requirements of this
subchapter.



   (B)   The Building Official may inspect each site prior to the
issuance of any permits or certificates of compliance with the plan as
required. In the event for other reasons it is not practicable to cause the
landscaping to be put in place, in order to secure the issuance of other
permits as may be required, the developer/owner shall, in accordance with
such procedures as may be from time to time established by the Mayor and/or
the City Council of the city, provide a bond, certificate of deposit or
letter of credit payable to the order of the city in a form provided by the
city as set forth by City Council in a schedule of fees to ensure that the
required landscaping will be installed.



   (C)   Any developer/owner wishing to make the payment in lieu of
installation shall, upon acceptance by the city, be deemed to have granted
the city permission to enter upon the land owned or controlled by the
developer/owner which is subject to the payment for the purpose of installing
the required landscaping in the event that the landscaping is not in place at
such time as determined reasonable by the Building Official. The city shall
release any bond, certificate of deposit or letter of credit if the
landscaping is put in place and approved by the Building Official within 90
days of the issuance of the required certificate of occupancy.



(Prior Code, § 9-307)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995; Am. Ord.
2012-27, passed 6-26-2012)  Penalty, see § 150.99



§ 150.63  EXHIBITS.



   In order to provide for administration of the terms and provisions of
this subchapter, the City Council adopts certain illustrative exhibits which
shall be entitled "Street Yard Graphic Examples," and although the same are
examples, orders the same to be filed and codified as a part of this code and
as Exhibit "A" attached to Ord. 95-03, which is hereby adopted by reference
as if set out in full herein. The illustrations are approved for exemplary
purposes only and in the event of conflict with or the same is alleged not to
be in accordance with the terms and provisions of this subchapter, the
provisions of this subchapter shall be deemed controlling and not otherwise
superseded by the examples.



(Prior Code, § 9-308)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.64  OBSTRUCTIVE VEGETATIVE GROWTH.



   (A)   In the event the Building Official shall at any time determine
that any vegetative growth has become excessive and a potential hindrance to
the health, safety and well-being of the residents, citizens and inhabitants
of any property or of the city in that the same obstructs the view between
the street and access drives and parking isles near street yard entries and
exits, or has created an obstruction of view in the radius of any curb, the
Building Official is authorized to notify the property owner, managing
owner's agent or other person responsible of the necessity to prune, remove,
cut back or otherwise alter the vegetation. The Building Official shall
provide notice by hand delivery or certified mail, return receipt requested,
and upon receipt of the notice, it shall be the duty of the property owner,
managing owner's agent or other person responsible to cause appropriate
action to be taken to remove the obstruction.



   (B)   In the event the property owner, managing owner's agent or
other person responsible fails to take such action within the period of time
as herein provided, then each day beyond the provided ten days shall
constitute a separate and distinct violation of the code and may be punished
as required by law.



   (C)   In addition, the Building Official shall be authorized to
enter upon the private property or public street right-of-way maintained by a
property owner to remove the offending vegetation and may place a lien upon
the property either adjoining the public street right-of-way where the work
is to be accomplished or abutting thereto, if the right-of-way is to any
extent used by the abutting property owner, to pay the cost incurred.



(Prior Code, § 9-309)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.65  LANDSCAPE AREAS TO BE MAINTAINED FREE OF DEBRIS AND LITTER.



   It shall be unlawful for any property owner or abutting property owner
having control of a street yard to permit the area to be strewn with debris
and litter. Failing to remove the debris and litter upon notification shall
constitute a violation of this code.



(Prior Code, § 9-310)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)  Penalty, see
§ 150.99



§ 150.66  REPLACEMENT OF DEAD, DYING OR DISEASED LANDSCAPING MATERIALS.



   In the event the Building Official determines that any required
vegetative landscaping material has died, is dying or is so badly diseased
that the same cannot be saved or otherwise rehabilitated, the Building
Official may direct the property owner being in control of the street yard to
replace the dead, dying or diseased vegetative materials with like or similar
replacement materials. It shall be a violation of the code in the event the
same is not replaced upon direction of the Building Official.



(Prior Code, § 9-311)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.67  PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY.



   No permits or certificates of occupancy shall at any time be issued for
any property unless a plan has been submitted, approved and has been complied
with in accordance with the terms and provisions of this subchapter. The
Building Official shall further be authorized to deny any permits otherwise
required or subject to being issued under this code if there exist any
violations of this subchapter.



(Prior Code, § 9-312)  (Ord. 95-03, § 2, passed 1-24-1995)



§ 150.99  PENALTY. 



   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which
no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to § 10.99.



   (B)   (1)   Any person who shall violate any provision of the
standards adopted or established in the codes adopted in § 150.02 shall be
deemed to have committed a Class C misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be
punished by a fine in an amount as provided in Tex. Local Government Code §
54.001(b).



(Ord. 2009-17, passed 7-28-2009)



      (2)   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits
another to violate any provision of § 150.02(G), (J) or (K) shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a
fine of not more than $500 unless such violation implicates fire safety,
zoning, or public health and sanitation including dumping of refuse in which
case the fine amount shall not be more than $2,000. Each occurrence of any
such violation of § 150.02(G), (J) or (K) shall constitute a separate
offense. Each day on which any such violation of § 150.02(G), (J) or (K)
occurs shall constitute a separate offense.



   (C)   Any person who violates or causes, allows or permits another
to violate any provision of §§ 150.07, 150.09, 150.13, 150.25, or 150.62
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall
be punishable by a fine of nor more than $500.  Each occurrence of any such
violation of §§ 150.07, 150.09, 150.13, or 150.62 shall constitute a
separate offense.  Each day on which any such violation of §§ 150.07,
150.09, 150.13, 150.25, or 150.62 occurs shall constitute a separate
offense.(Ord. 2004-41, passed 11-22-2004)



   (D)   Any person who violates or causes, allows, or permits another
to violate any provisions of § 150.25 shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not
more than $500 unless such violation implicates fire safety, zoning, or
public health and sanitation including dumping of refuse in which case the
fine amount shall not be more than $2,000. Each occurrence of any such
violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. Each day on
which any such violation of this section occurs shall constitute a separate
offense.



   (E)   The civil penalty for failure to comply with an order of the
City Council, as set forth in § 150.39, shall not exceed $1,000 per day for
violation of this code.



(Prior Code, § 9-104)  (Ord. 2005-07, passed 1-25-2005; Ord. 2012-02,
passed 1-24-2012;  Ord. 2012-23, passed 6-26-2012; Ord. 2012-24, passed
6-26-2012; Ord. 2012-25, passed 6-26-2012; Ord. 2012-26, passed 6-26-2012;
Ord. 2012-27, passed 6-26-2012; Ord. 2013-05, passed 4-23-2013; Ord. 2013-19,
passed 9-24-2013; Ord. 2013-20, passed 9-24-2013; Ord. 2013-21, passed
